title: COLUMN: A future educator’s response to school shootings
author: Emma Lindsey
body: Every day, hundreds of thousands of people attend classes. Some are going to school for the first time - plucky preschoolers, excited to meet their teacher and peers. Others, like myself, are walking into their senior year of college, ready to meet the challenges of what their final semesters will bring.  As the excitement waned into focus during syllabus week, I woke up to the news of a school shooting in my hometown of Minneapolis, turning my focus into despair and trepidation. I watched the news unfold, the dead and injured numbers climbing and the endless debate about gun control begin anew. While this news may slowly fade in the background for some, due to some other horrific event, it won’t fade in mine.  My major is Child, Youth and Family Studies, with a focus on Inclusive Early Childhood Education; a long-winded way of saying that I am studying to become an educator of any and all children, zero to eight years old. Like any education student, I have spent hours in lectures and practicums. I’ve learned about curriculum and the subjects that my students need to learn to progress. Unlike some other education students, my major has an additional focus on the social-emotional well-being and regulation of students.  What does that have to do with the senseless gun violence in our nation’s schools? In the quiet moments, I wonder about the traumatized children who will never quite get back to that excitement of their first day. The children who are held tightly for the rest of their adolescent lives by, justly, terrified parents. The teacher who barely escaped.  In observation of smiling children with their parents, I find the creeping thought of the families that lost their children only a week, a year or a decade ago settles. I wonder about the teachers and other professionals in schools around the United States. Are they safe today? Will they be alive in a week, a month or a year? Will I be?  While many of my peers worry about their future career, where they will be working and whether they’ll like their co-workers, future educators carry an extra worry along with them. Will I one day have to shield my students from a brandished weapon? Will I find myself hunkered down with twenty kindergartners, begging them to be as quiet as they can, while bullets are fired down the hall? None of us has these answers. None of us knows, yet I would bet that most education students have considered how they might react if they find themselves in these situations.  In the case of the shooting that took place on Aug. 27 in Minneapolis, the shooter’s past teacher, Sarah Reely, pointed to mental health concerns. “I am posting this to remind people that it’s a snowball effect of multiple system failures at a national level, that every murderer was once a kid in someone’s classroom who needed help, and that this issue is so much deeper and more complicated than we want to admit.”  While there are conversations to be had about gun control and endless debates about why someone would choose to enact such violence, there is an overarching problem that remains true in our country: the mental health of our children is not held paramount to our systems or our government. This is a systematic issue, not an individual one.  One in six children faces a mental condition, while only half of those children get the help that they need. Further, only 15% of students aged 12-17 report receiving mental health services at their schools, despite a growing need for support. With administration from a local to national level concerned more about how our students compare academically to those of other countries, children continue to lose their lives to gun violence at an alarming rate. In fact, children and teens are more likely to die of gun violence than of any other cause. This has only increased in severity in recent years.  I don’t have the solution to these issues. I don’t think there is one answer that explains why these heinous events happen. What I do know is that I experienced a need for additional mental health support during my own time in K-12 schooling. That many of my own educators and administrations failed me. Maybe yours did too.  I don’t blame the teachers, principals or administration in my school district. I blame the systems that demonize both mental illness and the brave individuals who seek support for those needs. When we finally center mental wellness in our homes, schools and country, perhaps we will start to see change. No matter where you stand on the endless debates, I think you’ll agree with me here: children deserve to live full and happy lives.  Emma Lindsey is a senior Child, Youth and Family Studies major. You can reach her at emmalindsey@dailynebraskan.com.  If you or someone you know is experiencing a mental health crisis, CAPS is available to UNL students at little to no cost and the Suicide and Crisis 988 Lifeline is available 24 hours a day.

title: COLUMN: A Guide to Studying Abroad
author: Jocelynn Messersmith
body: Across the pond, I find myself on a journey with my classmates who I don’t really know. Originally, we were 15 students with one thing in common: our study abroad trip.  Over the course of spring break we spent time figuring out the London tube station and how to survive in a foreign country. By the end of the week, I found 15 new friends. From falling into the back of a bus to constantly looking the opposite way while crossing the street, this trip came with many new experiences. This is my guide to studying abroad.  Going into college many students fantasize about taking a study abroad trip. Within my first semester at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, I applied and got accepted into two programs. I was eager to explore the world and learn more about life outside of the United States, as I had never flown internationally before. I didn’t know what to expect on my study abroad trip, and when I got to class the first day of the semester, I quickly realized I knew nobody.  Studying abroad for the first time can be a terrifying experience. I wish I had someone who could tell me what to expect as I prepared for my trip. Luckily, I was able to survive this journey so that I can share my experience.  Step one, find a group and stick to it. I am a very shy person when it comes to talking out loud, so before I left for my trip I didn’t talk to anyone traveling with me.  The second I landed in London, I was on a mission to leave behind my quiet exterior. I met up with my assigned roommate and started making conversation. If I was going to spend the next week in a room with someone, I wanted to make sure I knew who I was spending my time with.  We quickly found another girl in our class who was stupid enough to befriend us. I was shocked at how close I was able to get with a few girls in such a short amount of time. Stepping outside of my comfort zone allowed me to relax and have fun with a great group of girls.  Step two, expect the unexpected. Nothing ever goes as planned when traveling. Whether experiencing delays on London’s underground subway or stumbling upon a random famous person, it is important to not let a change in plans affect the trip.  I am the type of person who needs a schedule planned out. I like knowing when things are happening and what to expect when I wake up in the morning. In London, I left behind my fear of not following a planned schedule and allowed life to guide me.  This led to some of my favorite memories. I was able to stumble upon random famous people during my trip including Kate Middleton, Fergie, possibly the king and queen and even be on a movie set. None of these events would have happened if I tried to control my schedule for the day. It is way more fun to have a relaxed time with friends than sticking to a strict schedule that doesn’t allow for any breathing room.  Step three, remember to live in the moment. I don’t travel often, so having the ability to travel through education was a great way for me to explore the world. Time flies when traveling, and it can be so easy to get caught up in everything that will happen after a trip.  I’m not saying to put off school, work or spend money irresponsibly, but it is important to remember that people only travel so much in a lifetime. When deciding whether or not to get a special souvenir or take a nap, remember that these trips go by so fast. It’s hard to say when we will be able to experience this again, so it is important to live in the moment and make the trip worthwhile.  I understand that studying abroad can be an expense that some people don’t think is worth it. It was hard leaving friends and family behind and worrying about how much money I was spending. Even with these setbacks, studying abroad has been the absolute best part of college, and if I could do it again, I would in a heartbeat.  There is nothing like the experience of being a college student living life around the world. We are only young for so long, and chances like these don’t come along often. It is important to get out into the world and experience the unknown by taking chances and stepping outside of our comfort zones. Studying abroad has been the best part of my college experience, and I highly recommend it to everyone.  Jocelynn Messersmith is a freshman journalism and broadcasting double major. You can reach her at jocelynnmessersmith@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Apply for it all: Even if you think you might not get it.
author: Emma Lindsey
body: With the fall semester halfway gone, students might be looking for ways to get involved or find opportunities that could bring them scholarships or prestige. However, the thought of denial or lack of experience may deter them from applying for their most coveted position or goal.  After all, doesn’t that job want the person who has worked in similar fields for five years? Doesn't the club on campus want someone who was in clubs in high school? Does that scholarship just seem too good to be true?  I’m here to tell you: If you don’t apply, you will definitely never get that call of acceptance.  It seems obvious, but many question why they should apply for a job, scholarship or other opportunities. Whether it’s a lack of experience, specific skills or not believing you are enough; I’ve heard it all. The problem is, not applying does just that: Nothing at all.  As a nontraditional student, I have lived many experiences. Over the past 10 years or so, I have applied to jobs that had requirements that I didn’t have, positions I had no experience doing and opportunities that I didn’t think I was impressive enough for.  From things like helping people with their 401(k)s to being an opinion writer at the Daily Nebraskan, I have worked a litany of jobs that required me to learn new skills. I’ve gotten positions I didn’t have high school experience doing, like president of senate at the local community college to the recent position on University of Nebraska-Lincoln’s homecoming court. I’ve gotten scholarships I was convinced I wasn’t impressive enough for. I tell you these things because we all have doubts, but those doubts should not deter you from applying.  One of the first things you should know is that you’re far more impressive than you think. The things you did in high school, in your college years, in your lifetime? Your experiences and past involvements have likely taught you something, and that is valuable.  Perhaps you’re a brand new college student who wasn’t involved in high school. I wasn’t either, but when I came to college, I looked for ways to get involved on campus. Becoming involved is as simple as thinking about what you care about, a need you see on campus or focusing on a personal interest. Most Registered Student Organizations, even ones that hold some type of ‘prestige,’ aren’t difficult to get into. Most just want to know that you care about their cause and want to be part of it.  While this is true of RSOs, I can hear someone saying, “Well, that’s great…but I can’t just waltz into an interview with that and get the job.” To that person I would say, yes and no. Also, don’t you dare let a job listing’s “requirement list” deter you. Look for what is most important to the company and think of how your skills apply to that job or can benefit the employer. In my experience, an employer is going to be far more interested in you if you’re someone who is willing to learn over someone who has a teeny bit more experience than you. A lot of skills can be learned or built upon, kindness and a willingness to grow are far more attractive qualities.  One of the best things about applying for the things you’re passionate about is that the position will likely bring you new experiences and benefit your life in some way. Whether you end up loving or hating the position, you’ll come out the other side having learned something. You may learn that you need to go all in on this particular passion, that you hated it and need to change your major, or that it was simply something new to try. At the very least, you have something to talk about for future applications. However, you could stumble upon your true passion, lifelong friends, or discover parts of yourself that you didn’t know existed.  I can see why folks don’t put themselves out there. Being turned down or blown over for an opportunity sucks. It really does. There will be jobs that say they won’t hire you, you will likely lose an election for some RSO at some point, and you might be beat out by someone else for that scholarship. I have been in all of those situations. While it often feels disappointing, and sometimes truly awful, it’s all part of the process. This can be a hard pill to swallow, but I promise that your losses will teach you things too. If you never apply, you’ll never get the position.  While the idea of being turned down for something is scary and daunting, the truth is that you’re likely more accomplished than you think you are, skills you need can be learned, and the benefits will ultimately outweigh the cons. At the end of the day, college is a time to be experimental and put yourself out there. Apply. You never know what might happen.  Emma Lindsey is a senior child, youth and family studies major. You can reach her at emmalindsey@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Being a young woman manager
author: Jocelynn Messersmith
body: I race around the bustling kitchen on a Friday night swinging from bar to bar as I help my employees complete orders in a timely fashion and ensure every item is perfect. From dealing with customer complaints over the phone to handling the financials, I’ve done it all. Yet, I still feel like a fraud.  I work as a manager at Davinci’s, a casual Italian restaurant. Although this title seems like an accomplishment for someone who is only 18 years old, I continue to question if I am cut out for the job.  I started with the company when I was only 15 and quickly rose through the ranks to become a shift lead within a year then later a manager. Even though I have proven my ability to work efficiently, I have been challenged since day one.  My mother was the store’s general manager at the time making my promotion seem like a case of nepotism. Even after transferring to a different location this word has followed me.  It started with the other managers calling me “nepo baby.” Since both of my parents were now working at the corporate office, it was hard to refute the claims. Management at my age is something anyone would be proud of, but as a young woman this title is my greatest obstacle.  As a manager I have struggled to gain respect from my coworkers and feel safe when I am left alone in the store. Beyond this, the extra work required has started to interfere with my life as a student.  In a role of authority, respect is required. Since most of my employees are older than me it’s hard for them to take me seriously as their boss. I don’t look or sound threatening so it’s easy for others to undermine me.  While the employees see me as a friend, the other managers see me as another employee. When something went wrong in the store I was the one put on the chopping block because I was the easiest target. When I finally stood up for myself and called out one of the older managers for constantly being on his phone, he shunned me for months.  He would trade shifts to avoid working with me and told the employees that I was psychotic. All because I expressed my disapproval of his work behaviors. I walked into work for months unable to look anyone in the eye because of how afraid I was.  Some employees also find it okay to hit on me even though it is incredibly inappropriate considering I am their boss. I am forced to sit there and laugh it off or accept the compliment and move on. These comments demonstrate that I am not given the same level of respect as the other managers.  Another challenge I face is opening and closing the store as the only person in the building. The thought of having the back door unlocked while I’m alone terrifies me. I constantly think about what would happen if someone randomly walked in. I feel defenseless.  I shouldn’t have to make a plan for what to do if someone is waiting for me when I step out of the door at 11 p.m. Everytime I close by myself I run straight for my car in fear of what happens if I don’t.  Being a manager has also started interfering with my schoolwork. The first week of the semester I worked over 30 hours while taking 18 credit hours.  As a manager I am required to be the last person to leave the store. This means if we close at 10 p.m. I have to help my employees close down the store and wait for my drivers to take all of the deliveries, even if they take an order past close. Afterwards, I do all of the bookwork for the night causing me to leave way past the time we actually close. It’s difficult to find the motivation to go home and work on assignments just to wake up and do it all again.  It should be a blessing to start in a management position at my age. It’s true that I relate to the employees and can easily bond with them. I love talking with everyone and joking around, but this makes it difficult to gain respect.  Being a manager has shaped me into who I am today and I will always be grateful for the opportunity to lead at such a young age. Facing these difficulties has helped me grow as a person, but nothing will stop me from speaking up for women like me.  Jocelynn Messersmith is a freshman journalism and broadcasting double major. You can reach her at jocelynnmessersmith@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Charlie Kirk doesn’t deserve accolades
author: Emma Lindsey
body: Charlie Kirk, a right-wing political activist and media personality, was assassinated on Sept. 10.  Soon after, news feeds were flooded with ‘us versus them’ rhetoric, President Trump ordering flags to be lowered to half-mast for several days and an explosion of anger and grief from people around the country.  As the days bore on, so did accusations. Blame was thrown in every direction, threats materialized against both the shooter and ‘the left’ and Kirk was openly revered as a martyr or even a hero.  More recently, President Trump has declared his intention to award the Presidential Medal of Freedom to Kirk posthumously. There are even talks about printing Kirk’s likeness on US coins.  Kirk did not deserve the accolades he gained in life and he does not deserve these further accolades now. He was not a hero, or a true leader to all and should not have his heinous ideals whitewashed to put him in a better light. Kirk’s legacy is one of hate and misinformation.  Let me be clear: Kirk did not deserve to be assassinated. While there is evidence of some celebrating his death, while others use his death to point the finger, the killing of another human being is always a horrific act.  Kirk should be known as he was: a person who spewed hate against just about anyone who was different from him. He championed the Second Amendment by waving away the deaths of children as ‘necessary evils,’ made racist remarks about a litany of people and spoke loudly against LGBTQ+ rights and the existence of climate change.  He created lists that put professors and school board officials at risk. These lists claim to expose ‘radical’ professors, despite many of the professors on the list simply championing equity, diversity and speaking out against hate.  You are welcome to agree or disagree with these viewpoints. However, what should concern everyone is the clearly biased references and the skewing of language to leave out pertinent information on these sites. These lists continue to prove worrisome for the safety of educators in higher education and with a little research, one can find information that is not manipulated.  It was unlikely that Kirk and I agreed on many things, but I do agree that free speech is important. I agree that debate and conversations are paramount to disagreements.  However, many of his debates avoid actual conversation, focus on semantics and work to ‘beat’ the person he’s talking to. He would attack at one slight misstep, preach against higher education but then suggest certain colleges to children who came to speak with him and insulted well-spoken people when he had no real answer or, presumably, felt attacked.  Almost every video wherein Kirk was debating, he would lash out with insults, jeers or personal attacks. He would continually redirect to his personal beliefs, instead of referring to sound research or directly answering the question.  Kirk wasted moments when real opportunities arose to talk about a myriad of issues through debate. Instead, he’d get lost in the tiniest of nuances or talk over someone, unable to absorb what the other side was saying. He’d sling incorrect statements as if they were fact and interrupt those with the knowledge to retort.  Kirk was not participating in academic debates: He was pivoting in every moment toward misinformation and his own opinion and away from a consensus of any kind.  Kirk has been revered as a leader, a great debater and a hero by many. If true, he might deserve accolades like the Presidential Medal of Freedom, to stand alongside folks like Rosa Parks or Steven Spielberg. However, these accolades are reserved for people who use their lives to impact our communities and country in positive and impactful ways.  Kirk did not deserve to be assassinated and he does not deserve these high praises. Kirk’s legacy of hate and misinformation cannot be forgotten because of his heinous death. We must continue to critically engage with what he said, what he believed and what he created.  Americans must stop demeaning and devaluing each other. We must begin to have respectful and knowledgeable debates wherein we truly hear each other. Otherwise, we’ll just be arguing endlessly.  Emma Lindsey is a Child, Youth and Family Studies Major. She can be reached at emmalindsey@dailynebraskan.com

title: COLUMN: Consumerism in America
author: Jocelynn Messersmith
body: I love shopping. If I could describe my perfect weekend, one of the activities would definitely include shopping sprees and try-on hauls. As someone who always takes off work on Black Friday, I have started to realize how my shopping habits, like many others, have started to affect my everyday life and the lives of those around me. Like most Americans, I am a consumer.  The idea of consumerism in America skyrocketed just after WWII when American soldiers returned home to a different place from which they left. Wartime production helped pull America's economy out of the depression, where the country started to see a rise in spending power. Since jobs were plentiful and wages were higher, Americans were eager to spend their money. A consumer was praised as a patriotic citizen for contributing to the ultimate success of the American way of life. And the rest is history.  Consumerism has completely changed the way people shop, which is negatively affecting the environment and causing trendy products to have lower quality. Overconsumption also leaves individuals unsatisfied and overall promotes unhappiness.  A system of consumerism can have devastating effects on the environment. While this can be traced back to the beginning of factory systems, buying mass amounts of goods leads to more pollution, waste and carbon emissions.  Consumerism is one of the leading sources of carbon emissions, which is driving carbon-heavy processes like manufacturing and transportation. At least 45% of GHG, greenhouse gas, emissions are caused by the production of goods.  Environmental pollution has also risen with consumerism, as many manufacturing processes create toxic byproducts that can easily escape into waterways. The clothing industry alone is responsible for an estimated 20% of water pollution around the world.  Consumerism can easily motivate people to buy more products than they actually need, causing them to get rid of items in good condition, leading to a large amount of material waste. Textile production generates millions of tons of waste each year, which causes perfectly good pieces of clothing to end up in landfills. The same thing can be said for electronics, which lead to toxic waste.    The rise of consumerism has also led to a decrease in the quality of products. Since companies are trying to compete against one another, many choose to lower their prices, which means that they also have to lower the quality of the products they are selling.  Those looking for cheap options may look at Shein or Temu, which will throw coupons and sales in your face. While they seem like a great place to shop for less, the quality is often made of worse material, making the purchase feel like a mistake. These places can have rare gems that are actually pretty good quality, but overall, the cheap price tag comes with cheap material.  People who are over-consumers can often find themselves unsatisfied or unhappy because they are taking time away from things that nurture happiness, such as relationships. These people have a higher tendency to compulsively spend and are at higher risk of mental health issues such as depression and anxiety.  Although consumerism has a negative effect on the environment and on personal mental health, market-driven consumption can benefit the economy. The consumption of goods boosts the country’s GDP, making it an effective way to steer towards economic growth. The rise of consumerism also means more jobs are available because there is more demand for products.  While consuming new items can be fun and good for the economy, it is important to remember the bigger effects that consumerism has on the environment and on the actual quality of goods. It is always important to prioritize what is good for our health and the environment rather than a new outfit.  Jocelynn Messersmith is a sophomore journalism and broadcasting double major. You can reach her at jocelynnmessersmith@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Democrats should shut the government down
author: Jackson Hatcher
body: In an email sent out to students, faculty and staff yesterday, NU leadership warned of the possible effects of a potential government shutdown. If Senate Republicans are unable to secure at least seven Democratic votes for a continuing resolution by the end of today, September 30th, the business of the government will shut down. Federal museums will shutter, research grant payments may be paused, and hundreds of thousands of federal employees will be furloughed and those that aren’t won’t receive their pay.  A government shutdown occurs when Congress is unable to pass budget appropriations bills. Congress must pass 12 of these bills each fiscal year, corresponding to particular agencies based on the subcommittee. Agencies aren’t allowed to spend funds not appropriated by Congress, so without these bills, agencies must stop all non-essential services.  As Congress has become increasingly gridlocked in recent decades, legislators have increasingly relied on continuing resolutions, which are agreements to continue funding the government under the previous budget.  The one caveat is that CR’s must receive 60 Senate votes to pass, a number neither party has reached since 2010. The need to fund the government has therefore been used by minority parties in the past to extract concessions from the majority.  The most recent government shutdown lasted 35 days between 2018 and 2019 during Trump’s first term. The GOP, in the minority at the time, wished to appropriate $5 billion for the construction of a US-Mexico border wall, a non-starter for Democrats.  This year’s squabble over a shutdown is a lot harder to summarize, unless you’re in the President’s circle. If you ask Donald Trump, Democrats are demanding a trillion dollars for things like “free healthcare for undocumented immigrants” and “transgender operations for everybody”. These claims are based on very little.  Democratic leadership, for its part, has framed this fight to be in opposition to the Republican spending bill passed earlier this year, which cut billions of dollars in healthcare spending, among other things. In a statement earlier this month, House Minority Leader Jeffries and Senate Majority Leader Schumer said, “We are ready to work toward a bipartisan spending agreement that improves the lives of American families and addresses the Republican healthcare crisis.” To me, it is a vast understatement of the issues Democrats are up against in this fight.  The impunity with which the White House has acted since Trump took office this January has been remarkable. The executive branch has ignored court orders; seized powers that are constitutionally not afforded to it; shattered precedents at a breakneck pace; attacked law firms, universities and media companies; and mired Washington in some of the most brazen corruption I have ever seen.  Our Government is based on the bedrock idea of checks and balances, but the bodies that are meant to rein in the executive have largely encouraged this lawless behavior. The Supreme Court has misinterpreted the Constitution to afford Trump everything he wants.  The Republican controlled Congress is all too willing to allow this lawlessness as well, either because they’re too spineless to break from their party leader or because they agree with Trump’s authoritarian vision: pushing through the draconian and unpopular Big Beautiful Bill.  Through all of this, Democrats have been hiding in their offices, occasionally leaving to write a “strongly worded letter” or offer token opposition at the State of the Union. In a word, they have been feckless. Schumer would argue this is because they have no power, no leverage. Today, that is not the case.  Schumer has remained steadfast that a shutdown can be avoided with negotiations – a patently ridiculous assumption. Trump has no interest in negotiating as that would require ceding the power he’s taken for himself. He won’t see reason unless he’s made to see reason.  Republican leadership has claimed that a government shutdown will be owned by Democrats. But the fact of the matter is that Republicans control all branches of government. As the majority party, it is their responsibility to put forward a resolution that can get enough votes to pass. If they can’t get the required votes, they are the ones who are failing to be bipartisan.  This is not to say that a government shutdown has no downsides. I don’t want hungry people to miss out on their SNAP, WIC and medicaid benefits. I don’t want to see research grants paused, nor do I want to see federal employees furloughed or, if Trump’s threats hold water, fired.  What good is continuing to fund a government that can ignore congressionally appropriated funds, illegally fire workers, slash billions in benefits and levy taxes without congressional approval? This isn’t a government worth keeping open.  Trump, his administration, the GOP and the Supreme Court either can’t or refuse to see reason, so the solution is pretty clear to me: Democrats must drag them to reason by shutting the government down.  Jackson Hatcher is a senior majoring in biological sciences with a minor in political science.  You can reach him at jacksonhatcher@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Falling for fall break
author: Jocelynn Messersmith
body: Fall break is creeping up as the weather cools and the leaves change colors. Although the semester is starting to intensify, students will get just a few days off to relax and hopefully stay away from bookwork. While fall break is only a longer weekend, there are still plenty of activities to keep our minds off our classes.  UNL will have its fall break on Monday, Oct. 20, and Tuesday, Oct. 21. This means that students get four whole days to sit back and enjoy being away from campus.  Fall break is the perfect time to step away from school and enjoy the changing of seasons. Whether it’s detoxing from the internet or staying in town, there are so many things to do over our short break.  The best way to spend fall break is to go camping. Last year I went camping for the first time and it was the best way to spend my break. I was able to detox from a screen and just enjoy nature while the weather was still nice.  A pro to camping in the fall is that the weather isn’t too cold at night and isn’t too hot in the morning. This means that I could spend the whole day outside and still feel comfortable. I have also experienced fewer bugs camping in the fall than in other months. In the summer, there are so many mosquitoes that being outside can often be miserable, but in the fall, I don’t have that issue.  Camping is also a great way to deeply connect with friends. It gives everyone a chance to explore nature and just chat together because there isn’t the stress of the outside world. Even if someone isn’t interested in spending time outside in a tent, there are other ways to camp. People can always stay in RVs or cabins or even spend time glamping.  Another amazing way to spend fall break is at a pumpkin patch or haunted house. This is such a fun way to get in the festive mood and still enjoy nature. Many places near Lincoln have great fall attractions.  Vala’s pumpkin patch is the cutest fall retreat and offers so many attractions that are perfect for a day trip. The pumpkin field and apple cider scream fall vibes and it also has incredible photo opportunities.  Roca Berry Farm doubles as a pumpkin patch and a haunted house experience. I have been going to Roca ever since I was a little kid and it is so much fun spending time with friends on all the day attractions and then going through all the haunted attractions at night. I love Roca because I get out what I put in. If I allow myself to scream and have fun with friends, then the night becomes so memorable. It is the perfect place for that fall aesthetic and a great way to celebrate the horror of Halloween.  Eagle Hollow Haunts is another great way to spend fall break in a spooky way. This is a great night activity as there are many haunted attractions to go to. Eagle also offers people a great chance to unwind with friends by a fire.  If students want to stay in Lincoln over break, I recommend spending time at coffee shops with a book in hand to fully have a Gilmore Girls fall, or to go out and have a cute picnic at a park. The weather in Lincoln is supposed to be pretty nice, which will be perfect for a picnic or a walk in the park.  While fall break can also be the perfect time to catch up on school work, it is even better to give our minds a break from projects and assignments and enjoy the world outside of campus.  Don’t waste the days we have away from school focusing on class. Fall break is a chance to prioritize ourselves and have fun away from campus before locking in for the rest of the semester. It doesn't have to be the craziest weekend ever, but go out and enjoy the weather before it’s too late.  Jocelynn Messersmith is a sophomore journalism and broadcasting double major. You can reach her at jocelynnmessersmith@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Growing apart is healthy
author: Hannah Nazarenus
body: From childhood to adulthood we are often taught to value our friends and treasure the relationship for as long as possible. The thought of losing friends can be painful, sometimes even shameful, but it can be the healthiest thing for personal growth. While losing friends can be a difficult experience, sometimes it's a necessary and healthy part of life.  To grow as a person it may mean leaving behind friendships that no longer align with who you want to become. Think about how much you've changed over the years; your values, interests and goals aren’t the same as they once were. The same can be said about friendships. It's natural for them to no longer fit the way they once did. Staying in such friendships may slow your progress and path to self-discovery. By embracing change you create space for new opportunities, self-discovery and relationships that reflect who you are becoming.  Not all friendships have a strong foundation. They can drain you emotionally, creating stress and sometimes affecting your self-worth. When friendships aren’t mutually beneficial it can lead to emotional exhaustion. When you surround yourself with toxic friendships and constant conflict, competition and lack of support from them can negatively affect your self-esteem and drain you mentally. Letting go isn’t about being harsh, it’s about protecting your peace and prioritizing yourself.  When you move on from old friendships it can create space for more meaningful friendships. As people grow and change, so do values, interests, priorities and goals. Because of this, relationships that once felt strong no longer fit who you are becoming.  Instead of holding onto relationships simply because of stability, letting them naturally fade can open new opportunities to meet new people who truly align with who you are. With new connections comes deeper understanding, growth and a stronger support system. Embracing changes in relationships doesn't mean that you are forgetting the past, but rather making room for friends that bring out the best in you.  Some people may believe that the history and stability of long-term friendships can keep them strong. In some cases long-term friendships can be a source of support, but sometimes holding onto a friendship because of a sense of obligation from shared memories can do more harm than good. If a relationship no longer brings you joy, support and growth, it may be time to let it go. You don't forget the past, you recognize that people change and that's ok.  Drifting apart from friends can be tough, but looking at it as a sign of growth can help ease the pain. Instead of seeing it as an ending, view it as a natural part of life. One that leads us to more authentic relationships. Friendship change isn't always easy, but it is an essential part of personal growth and can open the door to friendships that genuinely support the person you are becoming.

title: COLUMN: Justice Brett Kavanaugh thinks racial profiling is constitutional
author: Jackson Hatcher
body: Your average Constitution-loving American would probably think that federal agents should not be able to detain someone based on their race or the language they’re speaking. Based on a recent Supreme Court opinion, Justice Brett Kavanaugh would disagree with that idea.  On July 11, in response to the class action lawsuit Noem v. Vasquez, a Los Angeles federal judge issued a preliminary injunction barring federal agents from conducting immigration stops without reasonable cause.  The injunction clarifies that agents cannot solely rely on four factors: apparent race or ethnicity, speaking Spanish or having an accent, being present at a particular location and the type of work one does.  The Trump administration subsequently filed an emergency request to the Supreme Court, seeking to lift the injunction.    On Sept. 8, the Supreme Court issued their decision in the case. The Court voted 6-3 to lift the injunction, allowing immigration officials to stop individuals they suspect of being undocumented immigrants based on factors like race and occupation.  Kavanaugh penned a concurring opinion, in which he claimed, “Under this Court’s precedents… those circumstances taken together can constitute at least reasonable suspicion of illegal presence in the United States.”  This decision empowers federal agents to profile individuals based on their race, occupation and spoken language. It throws gas on the fire that is Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s brutal, inhumane and draconian immigration enforcement. It not only furthers the brutalization of undocumented persons, but it also erodes the rights of U.S. citizens.  In recent months, ICE has conducted workplace raids at places they suspect undocumented immigrants congregate, such as California Home Depots, Omaha meatpacking plants  and predominantly latino Chicago residential neighborhoods. But, being present at one of these locations is no real indication of one’s immigration status.  In January, three U.S. citizens, a family from Puerto Rico, were detained by ICE at a Milwaukee supermarket, under suspicion they were undocumented. What influenced this suspicion? They were speaking Spanish.  In that regard, they are not much different than 66 million other Americans who speak a language other than English at home. Spanish is the second most spoken language in the United States, a fact that SCOTUS is willing to ignore if it means one can “reasonably” detain someone speaking Spanish.  There remain many unresolved questions regarding this point. Would someone speaking a non-English European language like Dutch or French constitute reasonable suspicion that they are an illegal immigrant? What about speaking English with a Canadian or Australian accent? Something tells me that wouldn’t cross the minds of most ICE agents.  It’s no secret that ICE has been detaining people based solely on apparent race, with little regard for the fact that one’s immigration status can’t be inferred from the color of their skin. It’s hardly worth clarifying, but an undocumented immigrant could be white, and a legal U.S. citizen could be Black or brown.  I’m reminded of a string of incidents from this January, where at least 15 indigenous Navajo people were swept up in immigration raids in Arizona and New Mexico. When asked to provide proof of citizenship, ICE wouldn’t accept their Tribal IDs. They were swept up because they looked a certain way in a certain place.  It begs the question, what does a U.S. citizen look like? Apparently not like a Native American.  Judging by a recent military-style raid of an apartment building in Chicago’s South Shore, a U.S. citizen doesn’t look Black, either. Every resident of the building, including children, were detained and handcuffed for hours, regardless of immigration status. According to a bystander, a majority of those detained were Black citizens.  It is important to note that people of color make up 42% of this country. Would an ICE agent ever look at a white person and doubt their citizenship status? Again, that would be hard to imagine.  In his concurring opinion, Kavanaugh states “for stops of those individuals who are legally in the country, the questioning in those circumstances is typically brief, and those individuals may promptly go free after making clear to the immigration officers that they are U.S. citizens.”  These are the words of a man who has never experienced an unlawful detainment. For the record, U.S. citizens have been detained unlawfully, and these detainments have often been lengthy. Beyond the inconvenience of being unlawfully detained, it is also humiliating. It’s humiliating to be treated like a criminal by your government simply for looking the wrong way, sounding the wrong way or working the wrong job.  Kavanaugh’s concurring opinion in Noem v. Vasquez shows a complete and utter failure by the Supreme Court to uphold the constitutional protections against unreasonable search and seizure.  In essence, granting a green light to racially profile individuals in the United States, robbing them of their rights and dignity. In 50 years, the decision will be seen as a stain on the Court and the Nation, as reviled as Plessy v. Ferguson or Dred Scott v. Sandford.  Jackson Hatcher is a senior majoring in biological sciences with a minor in political science. You can reach him at jacksonhatcher@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Mental health deserves more than a month of attention
author: Sydney Greenspan
body: We post and share about depression and anxiety every October. We see the Instagram stories of quotes about mental health and continue with the day. But why does the conversation stop when the month ends?  Each year, social media becomes filled with graphics, inspirational quotes and hashtags about depression. For a few weeks, everyone seems to care. People post reminders to “check on your friends,” share hotline numbers and talk about ending the stigma.  Then November arrives, and the conversation fades. The posts stop, the hashtags disappear and the silence takes over again.  Depression doesn’t work on a schedule, and neither should our awareness of it.  For millions of people, depression is not an occasional topic of conversation. It’s something people suffer with every day.  I’ve seen this in my own life. I’ve had days where simple tasks feel heavy and where reaching out for support feels like a burden. During those times, seeing a friend post a quote in October felt nice, but it was the real check-ins that really made a difference to me.  May is Mental Health Awareness Month, and October is National Depression and Mental Health Screening Month. Oct. 10 marks World Mental Health Day, which is a time dedicated to educating and advocating for a better understanding.  While these dates do serve an important purpose, they should not be the only time we care. Conversations and awareness about depression and mental health need to continue every day, not just when the calendar tells us to.  Keeping the dialogue about mental health year-round helps reduce the stigma and normalize the conversation.  When mental health becomes something we talk about openly and consistently, it helps those who are struggling feel less alone and more supported.  For someone living with depression, hearing others talk honestly about depression can be beneficial. Hearing others share their experience feels validating.  A consistent conversation also reinforces that mental health deserves the same attention as physical health.  Just as we wouldn’t wait for a certain month to take care of our bodies, we shouldn’t wait for October or May to take care of our and each other's minds.  Continuous education also plays a big role.  When we regularly talk about symptoms, coping strategies and healing, we help people understand what depression actually looks like. It’s not always visible, and it doesn’t always look like sadness.  Hearing someone share their personal story creates a sense of empathy and understanding that no infographic or quote can replicate.  And while awareness months have good intentions, they can sometimes feel performative. Posting a quote about “checking on your friends” means little if you never actually reach out.  Real awareness means taking action: checking in on people, advocating for better access to therapy and psychiatric care and noticing when someone around you might be struggling.  In my opinion, sending one sincere message that checks in with someone or lets them know you are there for them is worth far more than a thousand reposted infographics.  The most meaningful form of awareness doesn’t come from sharing. It comes from showing up.  With that being said, awareness months still hold value. They bring visibility, funding and attention to mental health that can lead to real progress.  However, that should be the beginning, not the end. Real progress happens when awareness turns into consistent actions, when we take what we see in October and apply it to every month that follows.  Mental health awareness is not a trend. It’s a commitment to compassion, understanding and openness. As October comes to an end, our attention shouldn’t. These conversations need to happen regularly, because healing doesn’t happen on a schedule and empathy shouldn’t either.  Someone is always there to listen, even if we don’t realize it. Please reach out. Help is always available.  You can reach out to https://caps.unl.edu/ for on-campus free support and the Suicide and Crisis hotline phone number at 988.  Sydney Greenspan is a junior majoring in Communication Studies with minors in Political Science and Psychology. You can reach her at sydneygreenspan@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: My Mid-Season Heisman Favorites
author: Michael Tatten
body: The mid-season point of the college football regular season is upon us, and it is time to take a look ahead at who the top contenders are for the Heisman trophy.  The Heisman trophy is the most prestigious individual award a player can win in the Football Bowl Subdivision.  Here are the top contenders for the award and who I think can really be the one to take the hardware home, starting with number five:  Jeremiah Smith is a Wide Receiver at Ohio State, and he is the only non-quarterback in contention for the Heisman. Smith burst onto the scene last season as one of the best receivers in FBS as a rookie. He helped carry the Buckeyes' wide receiver room to a National Championship win last year.  Smith’s sophomore campaign hasn't been as dynamic as fans expected, and his Heisman campaign is cooling down. In order for Smith to be able to take the trophy home, he will have to really pick up the pace, replicating some of his statistics from his freshman season.  The only non-quarterback who is going to be a contender for this award at this point in the season is Smith.  Marcel Reed is the starting quarterback for Texas A&M and a potential dark horse to win the Heisman. The last Heisman to come out of College Station was also a dark horse who took the SEC by storm. That man was Johnny Manziel.  Texas A&M has key wins over Notre Dame and Florida. They have big games against LSU, Missouri and Texas to finish out the year.  If Reed can continue to put up stats and lead his team to key-note wins, then he has to be really considered for the award.  Fernando Mendoza has been one of the biggest surprises in all of FBS as he is leading Indiana to one of the program's best seasons yet.  Mendoza is the third favorite to win the Heisman trophy, and his case has only gotten stronger after leading Indiana to a win over Oregon this past week.  Mendoza arguably has the best statistics out of any quarterback in college football, and Indiana has no ranked teams left on their schedule at this point, so if Mendoza were to continue putting up great stats and winning, he could absolutely be hoisting the trophy at the end of the year.  Ty Simpson is the starting quarterback for Alabama and has the second-best odds to win the Heisman trophy right now.  Alabama always plays a gauntlet of a schedule, being in the SEC. Alabama recently beat Georgia and has some difficult games left on the schedule against LSU and Oklahoma.  Ty Simpson isn't posting the best stats in FBS, but he is leading one of the top contenders for the National Championship. If Simpson can continue producing stats and wins, he will be a top contender for the trophy.  My top contender to take home the Heisman this year is Miami quarterback, Carson Beck. Beck is leading the Hurricanes in his first season with the team after transferring from Georgia last season.  Miami has beaten Notre Dame, Florida and Florida State this season. The Hurricanes' toughest opponents are behind them, and the team has a chance to go undefeated in the regular season.  If Beck were to lead the Hurricanes to an undefeated record, an ACC championship and put up top quarterback stats, then he would be the quarterback to win the Heisman.  Michael Tatten is a sophomore sports media and communications and broadcasting major. You can reach him at michaeltatten@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: My top 5 actors to be the next Batman
author: Michael Tatten
body: Batman is one of the most iconic characters in comic history. Over the years, Batman has been brought to the big screen in many different variations. Every time the Dark Knight is brought to the big screen, the actors always give a different spin on the character.  James Gunn, the head of the DC Universe, has rebooted the entire universe and is looking for actors to portray his heroes. Batman is one of the most important characters in the DCU, and the decision of who is playing Batman may be the most anticipated thing in the entirety of the DCU.  Here are my top five choices to play Batman in the DCU, starting with number five.  Jensen Ackles may not be the most blockbuster star on this list, but he has undeniable qualities that would make him a great Batman. One of those qualities is Ackles' voice. Ackles had voiced Batman in various animated projects and would bring a deep and gritty voice to the character. Ackles's demeanor is also a great fit for the Dark Knight. In the hit show, “The Boys,” Ackles portrays a dark and gritty anti-hero that had many fans wanting him to be the next Caped Crusader. Ackles would bring grit and experience to the table but may lack the star power to land the role.  Brandon Sklenar is also not a Hollywood A-lister, but there have been a lot of rumors that he could be next in line to don the cape. He has openly stated that it would be a dream for him to play the role. Gunn said that he wants the actor who plays Batman to be around the same age as the new face of the DCU, David Cornsweat, who plays Superman. With Sklenar being 35, he fits the bill of age with Corenswet being 32. A major reason for the Batman rumors has been Sklenar's rigorous training. Sklenar's trainer posted a picture with a very in-shape Sklenar claiming he was training him for his biggest role yet. Could this mean that Sklenar will be cast as the Batman of the DCU?  Christian Bale reprising his role as the Dark Knight is more than likely not going to happen since the DCU is looking to cast a younger actor. But if Gunn wanted to capitalize on nostalgia, there is no better way to do it than with Bale. Bale played Batman in Christopher Nolan’s Batman trilogy, a trilogy highly regarded as the best adaptation of Batman. The Dark Knight trilogy set the precedent for modern superhero storytelling. If Bale were to return as the Dark Knight, the DCU could expect the masses returning to the theatre to see it happen.  Jake Gyllenhaal is one of the most well-known actors in Hollywood and has long been rumored for various superhero roles. Gyllenhaal’s versatility has landed him major roles that show why he would be a good Batman. In movies like Prisoners and Brothers, Gyllenhaal has shown his ability to show off his intensity and his wide range of emotional depth. His persona would make for a great Bruce Wayne. If Gunn were to go with Gyllenhaal as his Batman, you could expect one of the best superhero acting performances of this decade.  Robert Pattinson is atop my list to be the next DCU Batman because he is currently still playing Batman. “The Batman: Part II” is set to release in 2027 in a universe that is not connected to the DCU, even though Batman is a DC character. James Gunn should just make Robert Pattinson the Batman of the DCU. This decision would tie all the DC projects together and make it simpler to comprehend. The fact is that Robert Pattinson’s performance in “The Batman” was fantastic and a completely different adaptation of Batman than we have seen in live action before. Pattinson should be the DCU’s next Batman because “if it ain't broke, don't fix it.”  Michael Tatten is a sophomore sports media and communications and broadcasting major. You can reach him at michaeltatten@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: My Top Contenders for Super Bowl LX
author: By Michael Tatten
body: This week, the reigning Super Bowl champions, the Philadelphia Eagles, are taking on the Dallas Cowboys to kick off the NFL’s 106th season.  After every offseason, which includes NFL Free Agency and the NFL Draft, everybody debates which teams have a real shot at contention for Super Bowl LX.  These are my top contenders to hoist the Lombardi trophy this season:  Philadelphia Eagles: Repeating as champions is one of the hardest things to do in sports. The Eagles’ infrastructure is one of the best in the league, led by general manager Howie Roseman. Roseman continues to draft and sign valuable players to help keep the team in contention. The Eagles have stars Jalen Hurts, Saquon Barkley, AJ Brown and Devonta Smith on the offensive side of the ball. If these players can replicate their production from this past season, the NFC will run through Philadelphia.  Buffalo Bills: After winning the M.V.P. award, Bills quarterback Josh Allen has one thing on his mind: The Lombardi trophy. The Bills added some new talent, along with developing younger players. Buffalo consistently puts out a top 10 defense in the league and with a weaker AFC, this may finally be the Bills’ year to take the final leap.  Baltimore Ravens: With a top-five quarterback in the NFL, the Ravens should consistently be contenders for the Super Bowl. Unfortunately for them, they can't seem to get past the divisional round of the playoffs. Many people question whether they really are contenders if they can't beat the other AFC juggernauts. However, after a great draft and signing some big-time players, the Ravens are poised to compete in the AFC championship for a trip to the Super Bowl.  Green Bay Packers: This offseason, the Packers have been making a lot of noise. Just recently, the Packers traded for superstar edge rusher Micah Parsons, previously of the Dallas Cowboys. Their defense is set to be one of the best in the NFC and with quarterback Jordan Love entering his prime, he is viewed as a potential M.V.P. candidate. Green Bay may have another great quarterback set to lead them to the big game.  Los Angeles Rams: In the playoffs last season, the Rams were arguably the Eagles’ biggest test in their path to the Super Bowl. The Rams’ calling card is their defense. It is one of the best units in the NFC. Rams Head Coach Sean McVay is regarded as one of the best in the NFL. The Rams are only three years out from their LVI Super Bowl win. They are looking to go for one last run with quarterback Matthew Stafford under center. As long as the Rams stay healthy, they will be a team to watch for in the playoffs.  Detroit Lions: Replicating a 15-2 season is going to be difficult for Detroit, given that they play a gauntlet of a schedule and lost both of their highly coveted offensive and defensive coordinators. Regression is expected this year for Detroit, but with the offensive talent on their roster, the return of superstar pass rusher Aiden Hutchinson and head coach Dan Campbell leading the way, the Lions will continue to fight their way to winning their first Super Bowl.  Kansas City Chiefs: Last season, the Chiefs failed to three-peat and got embarrassed by Philadelphia in the Super Bowl. This offseason, they made additions to their offensive line, which was a major problem last year. The Chiefs are not the most talented team in the NFL, but the advantage of having Andy Reid and Patrick Mahomes makes them dangerous.  Denver Broncos: Every year, there is a team that takes the next step towards contention and this year the Broncos will make that leap. Head Coach Sean Payton has been raving about his team this offseason. Quarterback Bo Nix is looking to build off of his very successful rookie campaign and lead Denver back to the playoffs. The Broncos are built in the trenches. They have a top-five offensive line unit, along with a top-five defensive unit. Denver is in a prime position to join the upper echelon of the AFC.  Tampa Bay Buccaneers: The Buccaneers are in a weak division: the NFC South. They have won the division the past four seasons and are looking to make that a fifth. Tampa Bay’s offense is one of the best units in the NFL, headlined by Baker Mayfield, Bucky Irving and Mike Evans. Their offensive line is deemed as one of the better lines in football. About four years ago, Tom Brady led Tampa Bay to a Super Bowl. Baker Mayfield will now have the opportunity to do so in Tampa Bay.  My Pre-Season Super Bowl LX Prediction: Buffalo Bills beat the Philadelphia Eagles.  Michael Tatten is a sophomore sports media and communications and broadcasting major. You can reach him at michaeltatten@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: NBA’s top contenders
author: Michael Tatten
body: The NBA season is officially underway, and the league feels wide open.  Across the association, we have teams that are tanking for draft picks, middle of the pack teams on the verge of the playoffs, fringe contenders with a lot to prove and then the real contenders for the Larry O’Brien trophy.  When determining which teams will be contenders, you have to consider the star power of the team, the depth of each team’s rotation, coaching and the overall infrastructure, and track record of each team.  Throughout the season, teams will reveal if they are real contenders or just hopeless pretenders, but right now, these are the teams that should be considered as beginning-of-the-season contenders:  Atlanta Hawks: The Hawks added pieces this offseason to make them fringe contenders with the addition of players like Kristaps Porzingis, Nickiel Alexander-Walker and Luke Kennard. Atlanta has a star in Trae Young, but if Jalen Johnson can emerge as an all-star caliber player, Atlanta can prove itself as a contender in the East.  Cleveland Cavaliers: The Cavaliers decided to practically run back their team last year and did so because they had the best record in the East last season. Cleveland is the favorite to come out of the conference and their defensive prowess is a big reason why.  Milwaukee Bucks: Milwaukee added all-star caliber center Myles Turner in the off-season to help anchor the defense. The Bucks parted ways with Damian Lillard this past offseason, but they still have Giannis Antetokounmpo… for now. Giannis makes this team a fringe contender by himself.  New York Knicks: The Knicks are the other favorite in the East. The team will now have more time to mesh after all of the trades they have made over the past couple of seasons. Under new coach Mike Brown, the Knicks will look to return to the Eastern Conference Finals in back-to-back years.  Orlando Magic: The Magic added an all-star caliber player and sharpshooter, Desmond Bane, this offseason. Shooting is what has held back the Magic in seasons prior, but with the addition of Bane and other plus shooters on the roster, the Magic are looking to change that narrative. The growth of young stars Paolo Banchero and Franz Wagner will determine how far this team can go.  Denver Nuggets: Denver made a lot of additions to their roster this season, giving them real depth that they hadn't had before. Nikola Jokic is the best player in basketball and this is potentially the best team that he has had in his career. Denver is one of the true threats in the entire association.  Golden State Warriors: Golden State has been the most winning franchise over the past decade, and the reason behind that is because of the infrastructure that Stephen Curry, Draymond Green and Steve Kerr have built. The Warriors play a brand of basketball that is beautiful to watch and they hope to get one more championship for their franchise.  Houston Rockets: The Houston Rockets lost their point guard, Fred VanVleet, before the season and have a real hole at the spot. But with the addition of Kevin Durant to an already young, star-studded roster, the Rockets will look to be a threat in the West.  Los Angeles Clippers: The Clippers have had a lot of bad luck with injuries over the past few seasons, but their roster is deep and talented top to bottom. The team is headlined by Kawhi Leonard and James Harden, who will both be critical for the Clippers' success this year. The Clippers have a real opportunity to take advantage of playoff matchups and win the West.  Minnesota Timberwolves: Minnesota has been one of the best defensive teams over the past few seasons. They will need some younger players on the roster to fill some spots they lost, but with Anthony Edwards' career taking off, the Wolves will be in constant contention for years to come.  Oklahoma City Thunder: The Thunder are coming off a dominant season that capped off with winning the championship. Superstar Shai Gilgeous-Alexander posted one of the best individual seasons for a player in history. OKC has so much depth and is the best team in basketball with a real chance to establish a dynasty.  The teams to keep an eye on that could be potential contenders are the Boston Celtics if Jayson Tatum comes back from injury, the Dallas Mavericks when Kyrie Irving comes back and the San Antonio Spurs if Victor Wembanyama can take an MVP-level leap.  My top five contenders to win the championship this season, in this order, are the Thunder, Nuggets, Cavaliers, Timberwolves and Knicks.  Michael Tatten is a sophomore sports media and communications and broadcasting major. You can reach him at michaeltatten@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Pete Hegseth wants to restore a ‘warrior ethos’: What exactly does that mean?
author: Jackson Hatcher
body: In the introduction to his 2024 book, “The War on Warriors,” Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth said of the US military, “Twenty years ago, the military was focused on lethality, competency and color blindness. Today, our brass are following the rest of our country off the cliff of cultural chaos and weakness.”  Hegseth has carried that worldview into his new role. Since his confirmation in January, Hegseth has consistently railed against “woke” policies, making it clear that his mission has been to restore a “warrior ethos” to the military, a nebulous and undefinable term. It begs the question, what exactly does Hegseth mean when he says he wants to restore the warrior ethos?  Hegseth joined the Army National Guard in 2001 following the 9/11 terrorist attacks. He served honorably in Iraq and Afghanistan and was stationed at Guantanamo Bay. For his service, he earned two Bronze Stars and a Combat Infantryman Badge.  In 2021, he was barred from serving at President Joe Biden’s inauguration after a fellow guard member sent an email to his unit’s leadership drawing attention to a chest tattoo reading “Deus Vult,” a term commonly used by white supremacists.  In his book, Hegseth characterized this incident as the army labeling him an extremist. Despite this, he would remain in his unit for several more years before resigning. This is the incident that prompted him to write “The War on Warriors.”  Hegseth was confirmed on January 24th under much controversy over his alleged alcoholism and his views on women in the military. He was confirmed on a 50-50 vote, the closest vote of any cabinet member. Since then, he has begun to rework the Pentagon in his image.  Much of what he has done has been very superficial, renaming things to be more in line with President Trump’s anti-woke and anti-DEI policies. Most notably, he urged the President to rename his department to the Department of War.  He also renamed the USNS Harvey Milk to the Oscar V. Peterson, saying “people want to be proud of the ship they’re sailing in.” This move stripped honors away from Harvey Milk, a Navy veteran as well as the first openly gay politician in California.  He also changed the newly named Fort Liberty in North Carolina and Fort Moore in Georgia back to their original names from before the Biden administration – Fort Bragg and Benning, respectively. If you were somehow unaware, Braxton Bragg and Henry Benning were both Generals of an enemy nation – insurrectionists to the republic, who were partly responsible for the deaths of 360,000 American service members.  In a speech to the military’s top brass delivered on September 30th, Hegseth said, “People make honest mistakes, and our mistakes should not define an entire career.” The worst example of a mistake made by a military official, Hegseth thinks, that can be swept under the rug is the 1890 massacre of Wounded Knee.  The massacre is notorious, seen as one of the darkest, most unjustifiable stains on American history. Upwards of 250 innocent Lakota Sioux men, women, and children were gunned down by US soldiers. Twenty soldiers who took part in the massacre were posthumously stripped of their Medals of Honor by Hegseth’s predecessor, Lloyd Austin.  This month, Hegseth announced the reversal of that decision, restoring their stripped metals, calling those who committed the massacre “brave.”  His speech also touched on new standards at the Pentagon. Chief among them being returning to, in his words, “the highest male standard only.” Stating that overweight men, as well as women who don’t live up to whatever Hegseth determines is the highest male standard, are not welcome in the military. He has also attacked transgender people, implementing Trump’s proposed ban on transgender individuals serving in the military.  He has also implemented harsher grooming standards, stating in his speech, “no more beardos.” The military has always had strict grooming standards, but there have been exemptions in the past. For example, Sikh men, who are primarily Punjabi Indian, do not shave for religious reasons. There have also been medical exemptions for soldiers who suffer from conditions like Pseudofolliculitis Barbae, a condition where shaved hairs curve backward into the skin, causing irritation. This condition primarily affects Black men.  It’s clear that all of this isn’t about creating a military dedicated to “lethality, competency and color blindness.” To me, it is plain and simple what Hegseth means when he says he wants to restore a warrior ethos to the Military. It means desecrating the legacy of gay soldiers. It means honoring traitors to the country. It means rewarding massacres of women and children. It means a military where women, transgender people, and minorities aren’t welcome. That’s no military we should ever be proud of.  Jackson Hatcher is a senior majoring in biological sciences with a minor in political science.  You can reach him at jacksonhatcher@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Rejection by thousands: Lessons from Dan Osborn’s campaign
author: Bret Fulton
body: Election night is always full of excitement or shocking devastation and this past cycle certainly did not disappoint. However, working on Dan Osborn’s independent U.S. Senate campaign amplified these feelings of uncertainty knowing that my future and the future of our state was determined by hundreds of thousands of votes. Osborn’s loss taught me valuable lessons that I will continue to carry with me for the rest of my life.  I started working on Osborn’s campaign in June 2024. At that point, only one poll showed him tied with incumbent Republican Sen. Deb Fischer and national media had yet to pick up on the race.  What I originally assumed would be another losing campaign quickly transformed into an operation that had a real chance of challenging Nebraska’s political establishment. Instead of losing by over 20 points in a statewide general election like democrats in 2018, Osborn would lose by only seven. His race forced national republicans to buy millions of dollars worth of advertisements to defend Fischer’s seat.  Politics was a central part of my life growing up. Some of my earliest memories are going into the voting booth with my dad as he casted his ballot in the 2008 Presidential Election. I still remember seeing Obama’s face all over the news in my early childhood and the passion he brought to politics.  This early exposure made me politically active all throughout high school and college. When I was given the opportunity to intern for an, at the time, obscure U.S. Senate candidate there was nothing I could say other than yes. Knocking on doors, sending thousands of annoying election texts and working out of a bare office space with other students taught me the humble beginnings of a fierce campaign.  Working so hard for something I believed to be rejected by 63,000 votes was a hard pill to swallow, however, this grew my faith in our election process. Osborn’s concession speech before a line of cameras and news reporters quelled the anxieties of myself and his supporters. He reaffirmed to me that concession is the foundation of a healthy democratic system.  Running for any office is like a months-, sometimes years-, long job interview where your boss is the millions of voters who will ultimately make the hiring decision. While losing crushed the hopes of thousands of Nebraskans, I am still just as resolved in the promise of an independent challenge to a long held Republican seat that I felt was not doing enough to help out everyday people.  Many who woke up disappointed the morning after election day questioned where we go from here. Some have taken the time to make unfounded claims about election fraud or cling to false hope in recounts. However, I saw firsthand the power that knocking on doors and offering a resonating message can have. Every mass movement for an issue or a candidate has these simple origins.  Campaigning for Osborn exposed me to the hard work that comes with living in a system like ours. Any massive change takes a lot of work, resources and convincing, especially running as an independent. This campaign showed me that offering a message that everyday voters connect with is an extremely powerful tool.  This campaign exposed the value of a losing campaign. When Sen. Fischer should have won an easy re-election by double digits, she instead only won by seven. In a race that attracted national headlines and siphoned millions of dollars away from republicans in more competitive senate races, it is safe to say this campaign still made its mark in sending a message to absent politicians.  Bret Fulton is a sophomore political science major. You can reach him at bretfulton@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: The cost of staying quiet
author: Dawson Iasillo
body: In an era when shouting often drowns out substance, many who oppose the Trump administration have stepped back, opting for caution over confrontation. It’s understandable. Protests can feel risky, debates can turn hostile and the internet rarely forgives mistakes.  But staying silent doesn’t make the danger go away; it deepens it. Real change has never come from quiet agreement. Throughout history, progress has always come from courage, visibility and persistence.  In the recent months of the second term of the Trump administration, I’ve seen firsthand how people have started retreating into their shells, growing quieter as tensions rise. Covering political events as a journalist, I’ve been turned down for interviews more often than ever before. When I ask people to share their perspectives, the answer I hear most frequently is some version of, “I’m too scared.” Too scared to speak publicly. Too scared to protest. Too scared to be labeled, attacked or doxxed online.  As a female journalist working in a time of turmoil, I know the risks. I’ve received hateful comments, threats and personal attacks just for doing my job. There are moments when I’m nervous, when I hesitate before publishing a story or walking into a protest. But I do it anyway, because the stakes are too high not to.  These fears are valid, but they can’t be the end of the story. Fear doesn’t disappear when we avoid it; it just grows stronger. The hard truth is, it’s time to be scared, because democracy doesn’t survive on silence; it survives on participation. Authoritarianism is fueled by silence and complacency.  There is no longer room for excuses. Every time people in opposition stay quiet to avoid discomfort, the forces of authoritarianism grow louder and bolder. We cannot keep retreating while democracy crumbles in real time. If the people who claim to value equality, freedom and justice are too afraid to stand up for them, then those ideals will be erased by those who aren’t afraid to destroy them.  The reality is, what people are doing now is not enough. There are too many people watching from the sidelines. No change will happen until we unite for change, even through the bouts of anxiety it might bring.  History books will not be written about those who posted something on their story or stayed at home during a protest. They will not speak about those who complained behind closed doors but were too afraid to speak in public. They will not speak about those who sat back, watched and shook their head.  Who will you be in the history books?  Protesting can be scary. Speaking out can be nerve wracking. But what is even scarier is democracy crumbling, families being ripped apart and America as we know it dying.  Saying that liberals are an embarrassment right now may sound harsh, but what’s truly shameful is the silence. History will not remember our fear. It will remember our failure to act.  So speak out. Protest. Write. Vote. Shout from the rooftops if you have to. Because if we don’t, someone else will, and their version of America won’t include us.  Dawson Iasillo is a political science and journalism major. You can reach her at dawsoniasillo@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: The mind of a woman in America
author: Dawson Iasillo
body: Little girls sit around the TV for months waiting to watch someone like them be elected as the President of the United States. Elderly women sit patiently waiting to see all of their hard work toward equality pay off. People are excited. People are hopeful. For the first time ever it feels like a woman is the only option.  On election night, state by state gets called. Passion diminishes as each vote is given to former president, Donald Trump. Soon, being a woman in America feels hopeless. The unsettling feeling of a power-hungry man being in control of our future sinks in. Reality feels gloomy and dark. Patriarchy won again, despite all of the efforts and strides we have made.  The line has been drawn: being a woman is a higher crime than a convicted felon who is a man.  Women now have an invisible string tying them to one another in solidarity. They bond over the grief and uncertainty of what is to come in their futures that lie in someone else’s hands.  This election could have shown little girls that they can grow up to be anything they want to be. Instead, this election demonstrated that no matter how hard a woman works, a lazy man can always beat them out. It showed boys that they can still be the leader of America after sexually abusing women, committing fraud and lying their way through life.  Leaders of countries, especially America, influence people. In the past week alone, women have seen men degrading and belittling them to no end. Men chant, “Your body, my choice” and remind women that the glass ceiling is nothing that can ever be broken.  For years, Trump made it acceptable to talk about women in this sense. The misogynistic quotes from Trump seem to be a never-ending cycle as they inspire men to be just like their president.
