It is nothing short of exhausting watching this man continue to spew hatred while being held at such low standards with no accountability.  I am a woman in politics. I work hard for my future. Every day, I choose to use this passion of mine to strive for greatness and to be the change in the world, even if it is on a small scale. I am more than aware of the threats made toward women by the Trump administration and Project 25. It is an understatement to say how horrifying it is to come to the realization that all the progress we have made in women’s rights may be thrown out the window. From my standpoint, it shatters my heart. I question what I am even working hard for if it will all be for nothing in the end.  I see how hard Kamala Harris and how little Donald Trump have worked in their lifetimes. With Harris’ resume, there is no doubt that she was one of the most qualified candidates to run for the presidency. Yet, her unbelievable campaign, her policy plans and her successes so far still were not enough to prove to America that a woman can be in charge.  I want my hard work to pay off, the same way Harris did. Seeing the disappointment in the country is such a disheartening feeling to witness.  Despite all of the pain that I and millions of other American women felt this week, I am joyous. I am happy to be on the right side of history. I do not understand how someone could support a human being with the character of Trump, but I am grateful that I do not understand. I am thankful that my heart is big enough to choose human rights over the price of eggs. I am pleased with my anger after the election results because that is living proof that I am full of empathy and passion. I love politics a lot, but there is nothing I love more than being a woman, regardless of how much it hurts sometimes.  I know all too well that I am not alone in these feelings of uncertainty and fear. I also know women are not the only ones settling into their distress. However, as Harris said, “It is time to roll up your sleeves.” Women cannot throw in the towel and give up after how much work their grandmothers put into women’s rights. The glass ceiling is dying to be broken, so be the woman to break the ceiling. On the good days and the bad days, it is always empowering and such an honor to be a woman.  Dawson Iasillo is a sophomore political science and journalism major. Reach her @dawsoniasillo@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Top 5 Picks to Host the 2026 Oscars
author: Michael Tatten
body: The 2025 Oscars aired last week, marking the 97th Academy Awards ceremony. The Oscars have awarded excellence and achievements in the film industry since 1929. It is a highly esteemed awards show. This year’s show drew 19.7 million viewers, setting a new high out of the last five years.  Every year the Oscars are judged on how successful the show was based on factors like how long the show ran or if the winners were more deserving than others. However, the ultimate test of a successful Oscars award season is largely based on the host of the night.  A good host is essential for a successful show. The host must engage the audience, make jokes, transition between awards, present comedic bits, keep the show moving and handle any unexpected moments all within a three-hour time frame.  There has been talk about who the 2026 Oscars host could be, and while there are plenty of viable options, five candidates stand out to me.  A realistic option to host the 2026 Oscars is comedian Conan O’Brien, who hosted the 2025 awards. It is widely believed and reviewed that O’Brien had a terrific Oscars hosting debut. O’Brien threw in some edgy jokes that paralleled current headlines in the news, set a great pace for the show in between awards and kept the people entertained. O’Brien’s past entertainment show hosting experiences made him a qualified pick for the 2025 Oscars. With him nailing his performance, the Academy would certainly be happy to have him back to host next year’s Oscars. Realistic Rating: 10/10  Coming off a very successful outing as the first solo female host of the Golden Globes, Nikki Glaser would be a red-hot selection to host the 2026 Oscars. Glaser is an actress, stand-up comedian and television host who gained mass popularity after her bit at the Tom Brady Roast. Glaser herself stated that the Tom Brady Roast “changed my life forever.” Glaser’s stardom is only beginning, and she will be looking to keep that momentum going. If the Academy chooses Glaser as the 2026 host, it would be a wild show with unhinged jokes, making it one of the more entertaining Oscars in recent times. Realistic Rating: 8/10  Widely regarded as one of the funniest people on the planet, Adam Sandler would absolutely deliver an entertaining three hours of television. Sandler can relate to all generations, which would bring in more viewers for the Academy. Sandler is starring in “Happy Gilmore 2,” a film that will be released in July 2025. This film will look to connect generations and be a highly relevant and comedic film. The real question is if Sandler would do it. Sandler has never won an Oscar, so perhaps he wants to find his Oscar success as the 2026 host. Realistic Rating: 6/10  Maybe a more unrealistic option to host the 2026 award show, but my personal choice is Pete Davidson and Shane Gillis. Davidson and Gillis are both stand-up comedians who have great comedic chemistry and would make for hilarious hosts. Gillis has appeared on Davidson’s show, “Bupkis”, they were both in Eminem’s music video for his song, “Houdini”, and both have multiple appearances on the show, “Saturday Night Live”. If this duo were to host the 2026 Oscars, it would make for, in my opinion, the best Oscars ever. Realistic Rating: 4/10  Potentially another co-host option for the Academy to consider would be Tina Fey and Amy Poehler. Fey and Poehler are both actresses and comedians. The duo have been friends for more than30 years. This comedic duo found great success as the hosts of the Weekend Update on “Saturday Night Live” with their amazing chemistry and quippy writing abilities for jokes, skits and characters on SNL. Fey and Poehler have hosted the Golden Globes four times, and every show was deemed a hilarious success. The duo has also made numerous films, including the hits like “Mean Girls” and "Baby Mama.” They both have a decorated background hosting the Golden Globes and “Saturday Night Live”, which would make them prime candidates to host the 2026 Oscars. Realistic Rating: 6/10  Critics may not appreciate these picks as much as I would. All of these hosts would make some either edgy, awkward or out-of-pocket jokes, and perhaps the Academy wants to go with a more conservative, traditional host. The Oscars have done ceremonies with no hosts as well, so that is potentially a route that they want to take. However, the Oscars with no hosts were rated as the worst Oscars of all time, and part of the reason they are trending back to relevancy is due to the fact that there is a charismatic host at the helm.  The Oscars are heading back in the right direction and the Academy has many candidates to choose from that will give them a successful 2026 Oscars award show.

title: COLUMN: When it comes to ‘big coffee,’ who reigns supreme?
author: Emma Lindsey
body: In Lincoln, there are options abound for a coffee drinker. Whether you prefer to pick up a cup of joe from a local dive or a large chain, there are options for everyone. As a self-identified coffee connoisseur, I have tried coffee from all over the United States.  My first job was as a barista, which proved dangerous, as I now struggle to stomach terrible coffee. Perhaps more discerning is my taste for espresso. As a coffee drinker, I want to be able to taste the espresso intermingled with milk and flavorings. This brings me to the pursuit of finding the best coffee among the four powerhouses of ‘big coffee’ chains in town.  I tried coffee from Starbucks, Scooters, 7 Brew and Dunkin’. From each establishment, I ordered a small hot skim milk caramel latte. I’ll also be ordering around the same time of day and in similar-esq locations.  I will rate each on taste, speed and quality of service and price. Speed is included because this is often why most folks choose to purchase from a chain. For each element, I will rate it on a 1-5 scale. With this, let’s start with the powerhouse that is Starbucks.  Starbucks is a household name. They are seemingly everywhere and loved by thousands of people.  I ordered from Starbucks around 2 p.m. on Monday. There was no line and service was quick: I spent only a minute and forty seconds there. While it was a quick interaction, it was far from a warm one. The employee was monotone and didn’t engage in anything other than the necessities. The flavoring tasted a bit too fake or light and the flavor of the espresso seemed to hide behind the taste of the milk. I prefer a more robust flavor in the espresso and a richer flavoring to the caramel. The hot and small drink was 12-oz, which I paid $5.74 for.  Quality of service: 2, Speed of service: 5, Taste: 2, Price/Value: 3. Overall score: 2.4.  Dunkin', another well-known coffee chain, is also far-reaching. Known as a cheaper option, folks often turn to Dunkin’ for their caffeine fix.  I visited Dunkin’ on Tuesday at 11:30 a.m. Again, there was no line present, and I spent two minutes and eight seconds there. The employees there seemed focused on doing the job and moving on to the next customer. They weren’t overly warm, but not unkind or monotone in their approach. Though the coffee was at a reasonable temperature, the taste was off. Upon first sip, I sensed some kind of dish soap taste. I took two more sips of the coffee before ultimately throwing it away. I couldn’t taste anything other than the taste of soap. The coffee wasn’t drinkable. I paid $4.80 for the 10-oz cup.  Quality of service: 2.5, Speed of service: 3, Taste: 1, Price/Value: 1. Overall score: 1.9.  Scooter’s is a popular option here in Nebraska. Known for their sweet coffee and their famous “go ahead and scoot around” line, Scooter’s is well-loved.  I visited Scooter’s on Wednesday at around 2 p.m. Once more, there was no line, and I spent about one minute and 48 seconds. The employees at Scooter’s proved once more to be kind and helpful. They cracked a few jokes, asked me how I was and offered a drink stopper. They didn’t keep me too long, but they were conversational. The coffee was similar to the Starbucks latte I tried earlier in the week, but was far more robust in flavor. The caramel and espresso tasted richer. I paid $6.18 for my 12-oz cup.  Quality of service: 4, Speed of service: 5, Taste: 4, Price/Value: 1. Overall score: 3.5.  7 Brew was my last visit. Upon my first attempt, a friend was working, and I came back midday Saturday. I spent a little over eight minutes in line, but only one minute and a half until my order was taken. There were around eight other cars in front of me. I paid $4.76 for a 12-oz cup. The taste of the latte is what I expect from 7 Brew, rich in flavor and caramel, but not overpowering. The service was kind and conversational, asking me about my day and confirming my order. The employee wished me well before I drove away to enjoy my cup.  Quality of service: 5, Speed of service: 3.5, Taste: 5, Price/Value: 5. Overall score: 4.6.  I argue 7 Brew is the best out of these four large coffee chains. Their quality and speed of service are consistent, the coffee is delicious and it is reasonably priced! However, I know there are some incredible local coffee dives in town. Any suggestions?    Emma Lindsey is a Child, Youth and Family Studies major. You can reach her at emmalindsey@dailynebraskan.com

title: COLUMN: Winter is the best season
author: Hannah Nazarenus
body: There's a certain magic in the way the air turns crisp and the first snowflakes begin to fall. However, winter is a season that often gets a bad reputation. Some say it's too cold and the sun sets too early, but few embrace it as more than a season, but a feeling. From fun traditions to the beauty of a landscape covered in a fresh dusting of snow, winter is by far the most beautiful and underrated season of the year.  Winter is a season full of blankets, cozying up by a fireplace, comfort TV shows and a warm drink. There's something so comforting about being warm inside while the snow falls and the world becomes frozen in time. There’s a sense of tranquility walking through the trees covered with snow, icicles hanging from their branches. Parks, cities and forests become magical with the snow muffling the noise of daily life.  Along with the serenity of winter, the activities are simply unmatched. With skiing, sledding, snowball fights, ice skating and more, there is something for everyone to enjoy. Some of my favorite memories I’ve made are being launched in the air off a sled, or rolling down a hill while learning to ski. There is something so special about coming inside from playing out in the cold. Laying out my wet shoes with a cold nose as I warm up beside the fire is an ideal afternoon.  While the beauty and activities of winter are fun, my favorite part is the connection winter brings. The home-cooked food, nostalgic desserts and Black Friday deals get the holiday spirit started. Being able to go home for Thanksgiving break and see family and friends is an unbeatable feeling. Sitting beside a decorated tree while exchanging gifts with loved ones are what bring the magic of Christmas alive. Then there's the anticipation for the New Year, a celebration of fresh starts and goal-making. It reminds us that winter isn't just an end, but also a beginning.  Winter celebrations bring people together, as they are drawn to the season of giving. Houses shine with lights and towns host festival events creating a sense of community. In a season that is often cold, these celebrations are like pockets of warmth.  While some may complain about the icy mornings and early sunsets, I am personally looking forward to the slow, cozy mornings. It invites us to slow down, connect with each other and find the beauty in the stillness. Winter is a reminder that even on the coldest days we can find solace in the warmth of our homes, family and communities.  Hannah Nazarenus is a junior journalism and ADPR double major. Reach her at hannahnazarenus@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: Your mental health is more important than a college degree
author: Emma Lindsey
body: Between college classes, jobs and personal commitments, most college students might find themselves without the time necessary for their mental wellness. While these various endeavors may be important and valuable to one’s life, I will be the first to tell you that your mental health is the one thing that you can’t forgo for long.  To put my understanding into perspective, I am currently a senior at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. I’ll also be turning 30 in March. While not always true, I am often the oldest undergraduate student in my classrooms. The reality is that when I was what most people would consider ‘college-aged,’ I was working meaningless jobs and was uninterested in ever returning to college.  See, much like my peers, I went to college immediately after high school. Despite having the sneaking suspicion that it was the right thing at the wrong time, I registered for my first semester. I went to classes, joined study groups and attempted to feel at home in a place that I just wasn’t ready for.  This became more evident as I began to fail my classes. Subjects I was often adept at fell into barely passing, while classes I struggled with only slipped into a failing grade. I stopped going to classes, didn’t ask for help and was swallowed by shame. I figured I just wasn’t cut out for college.  However, after being in the workforce for years, I suffered a mental breakdown. The mental illness I had ignored and had left unmedicated finally grew unmanageable. It refused to be ignored any longer and my life came crashing down.  While this time in my life was frightening, filled with difficult healing and required that I seek help from my community, I did make it out to the other side. From this, I have learned that nothing is worth the disintegration of your mental health.  You, or the people in your life, might think that dropping out of college is the worst thing that can happen. Perhaps failing a class or, even worse, being put on suspension in college is the scariest thing that could happen. Maybe you’re reading this right now and thinking that you can just keep toughing it out, that you don’t need help or that it might be weak to seek it.  I don’t want to scare you, but there are worse things than failing a class, being put on suspension or dropping out of college. I know because I have been there. I tried to tough it out, to struggle through it and to make people proud by continuing college. I worked myself to exhaustion, trying to keep my illness-ridden brain focused and on task, if only to prove I could ‘pull myself up by my bootstraps.’  I dropped out of college with less than a 1.0 cumulative GPA, but what was far worse was the deterioration of my mental health.  However, there is light at the end of this tunnel. It took years of work, of sacrifice and not just asking for help, but taking it. When I took my mental health seriously and made time for myself, I was able to pursue college again. I was able to flourish and do more than just go to classes, something I never saw as a possibility during my first attempt.  None of this would have been possible without taking a step back to care for myself. I shudder to consider what could have happened if I continued to ignore or shy away from what my body and brain were telling me I needed.  So, if your brain is telling you that it has had enough, there are resources on campus that you can turn to. You don’t have to drop out of college or fall into shame – but you should seek help. Perhaps that includes therapy, medication or lightening your class load. Maybe you’re in the same position I was in, and dropping out is the best solution for you at this point.  No matter where you are in your journey, you should know that it’s okay to choose yourself. It’s okay to put your mental health first. It’s okay to stand boldly and do what is best for your needs and choose the path and timeline that work best for you.  If no one else is, I am proud of you for making the decisions you need to protect your mental health and make space for your needs. You are worth more than a college degree, a job or an extra commitment. Those things can wait, but your wellness can’t.  Emma Lindsey is a senior Child, Youth and Family Studies major. You can reach her at emmalindsey@dailynebraskan.com

title: OPINION: The Upside of a Messy Conference Realignment
author: Jalen-Thomas Kroger
body: The landscape of college football remained relatively stable with not much changing in the way of conferences for most of its lifetime.  Five major conferences had majority control over the sport, being labeled as the Power Five conferences. They are the Big Ten, the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC), the Pac-12, the Big 12 and the Southeastern Conference (SEC).    In the past couple of years, many schools switched from their long-established conferences in favor of moving to new territory. The reason teams jump ship to new competition is for one reason: the almighty dollar.  Teams get compensated by television networks to broadcast their games. Most of these television games are organized by conferences, or conferences have their own television networks.  When these conferences’ leases are finished with their networks, schools can find new conferences that will pay them just as much, or even more, to play for them on their television stage.  In August, the Pac-12 conference, the only Power Five conference yet to negotiate a new TV deal, was left with two teams remaining in their conference, with the other 10 teams moving to compete in other conferences.    Money talks for those willing to listen, and many other teams in collegiate sports were open to trade in legacy and history for new contracts.  In the past two years, 27 teams have transferred conferences, completely shaking up the landscape.  One of the main complaints of the new realignment is the dissolution of long-established rivalries from within the conferences, but this is not a bad thing.  The death of tradition and history, especially tradition built on mutual hate, pride and trash-talking, leads to rebirth in new situations.  New teams in new conferences allow new rivalries to be built, even though they take time to develop. Rivalries don’t spawn out of nowhere, so developing them will take time, but that’s what’s special about them.  Most rivalries started before many modern college football fans were even born, but now we have the opportunity to watch new ones develop.  College football is an evolving sport, despite its age, so things like conference realignment are bound to happen.  Not all conferences started with the teams they had before the recent realignment shakeup, there was plenty of realignment beforehand.  Although the unprecedented recent realignment moved many teams and shifted conferences geographically, this is just what happens in this sport. Teams were bound to move, and it just so happened that it was all very recently.  The many critics of the recent realignment act like this is the end of the sport, but this new realignment will work out, like it has with every realignment prior to the past two years.  Even if conference realignment is a mess right now, that does not mean that it will remain this way in the coming years. Teams and fans will eventually get used to their new in-conference opponents and learn to accept them as a competitor.  While it’s strange to see UCLA, USC, Oregon and Washington in the Big Ten, fans should be rejoicing at the sight of new competition in a conference that was only dominated in recent years by Ohio State and Michigan.  Even though conference realignment will work out, that doesn’t negate the mess it currently is. Many despise the new additions to their conference and the teams that left their old conference. However, schools aren’t realigning for fans. Fans should focus on the fact that new realignment provides opportunities to college football, even if this progression in the game has its growing pains.  The best thing to do as a college football fan is to enjoy what the game is bringing in ways of new development.  It’s time to enjoy realignment rather than try to poke holes in its fundamentality, because this is a new chapter for college football that should be observed instead of complained about.  Jalen-Thomas Kroger is a sophomore sports media and communications, journalism and broadcasting triple major. Reach him at jalenkroger@dailynebraskan.com.

title: COLUMN: The cure to male loneliness
author: Jalen-Thomas Kroger
body: In July 2023, pictures of the same painting of a crying man watching people play pickleball filled Twitter, now known as X.  The picture originates from an opinion article written by Michelle Cottle and published in The New York Times about the “cure” for male loneliness.  The article, titled “Is the Cure to Male Loneliness Out on the Pickleball Court,” details how the rise of male loneliness can be fought with hobbies.  Male loneliness is a serious problem here in America, but it’s often overlooked.  A 2023 State of American Men report found that two-thirds of surveyed men between ages 18 and 23 say, “no one really knows me.” Not only this, but since 1990, the share of men who lack a single close friend quintupled to 15%.  So what can be done about male loneliness? Is there a cure, and is it actually pickleball? No.  Cottle’s article is a double-edged sword when it comes to male loneliness because, while it brings attention to the issue, it’s tone-deaf. Men’s general mental health has always been neglected, but it’s not because of a lack of pickleball.  Opening up about mental health is challenging, but it seems to be even harder for men. Whether it’s because of toxic environments or the standards and expectations ingrained in our society, men often have a harder time opening up. Without opening up about their feelings, men struggle to build relationships with their friends and end up becoming part of the statistics mentioned earlier.  Part of the reason men don’t open up can be seen in the response to Cottle’s article, which turned into a joke.  The article lays out good points about how group hobbies can be very beneficial to lonely men, but few readers paid attention to that. This opinion piece was meant to be serious, but with a questionable title and outlandish art, the story was turned into a huge joke.  Few people took the substance of the piece seriously, rather poking fun at how dumb the notion of pickleball curing male loneliness is.  Men can’t open up about their feelings when the response could easily be met with jokes made in poor taste. The mental health struggles of men can’t even be taken seriously enough by men before it gets mocked.  It’s easy to blame the people making the jokes, but can you really blame them for making fun of this article? Pickleball curing male loneliness is a preposterous idea, and publishing it with full certainty makes it very vulnerable to criticism.  An article like this makes a mockery of the epidemic-like rise of male loneliness in America and does the opposite of what it was intended for. Attention is brought to the subject, but it comes with the side effect of making that exact subject susceptible to the things that take attention away from it.  So, what is the cure for male loneliness? It depends. Like the article says, it can be through hobbies with other men that bring them closer together, but for others the cure is totally different.  Above all, the cure for male loneliness is making it easier for lonely men to open up about how they feel. This can be through therapy, support groups or other men.  Opening up can provide solace and relatability for men, creating a tighter bond within their individual relationships.  There is no cure for male loneliness, but we can take steps to make it less of an issue in America, and it starts with talking about the issue.  Jalen-Thomas Kroger is a sophomore sports media and communications, journalism and broadcasting triple major. Reach him at jalenkroger@dailynebraskan.com.

title: EDITORIAL: Censorship of Indiana Daily Student is inexcusable
author: The Daily Nebraskan’s Editorial Board
body: One thing most Americans can agree on is that censorship of the media does not belong in this country. However, the University of Indiana’s Media School is in the midst of committing a blatant act of censorship against the Indiana Daily Student, the school’s student publication.  On Oct. 14, IDS co-editors-in-chief Mia Hilkowitz and Andrew Miller said they were sent an email from IU Media School Dean David Tolchinsky. In the email, Tolchinsky explained to Hilkowitz and Miller that the IDS would be forced to shift from print to digital platforms that week to combat the paper’s growing deficit.  This email came just hours after former IU Student Media Director Jim Rodenbush was called into an urgent meeting with Tolchinsky and promptly fired. According to his letter of termination, Rodenbush was let go for his “lack of leadership and ability to work in alignment with the University's direction for the Student Media Plan.”  The university’s “direction” was censorship.  In recent months, the IDS and university leadership have been at odds over what the paper publishes. Since the IDS was forced to move from a weekly publication to seven themed special editions per semester in the spring of 2025 as a budget-cutting measure, university leadership pushed for the paper to keep news stories out of the print editions.  After the release of the IDS’ Sept. 10 edition, Media School Associate Dean Galen Clavio called Rodenbush into a meeting, where he asked Rodenbush why the publication still had news stories in print.  In other words, Clavio was asking why a newspaper was printing the news.  Later that month, ahead of the IDS’ next publication, Clavio continued to push the newspaper to take its general news coverage out of the edition. Rodenbush pushed back, saying that restricting a paper’s freedom to publish what it desires is the “definition of censorship.” On Oct. 7, Rodenbush relayed to his students that the university expected the next edition to focus solely on the theme of homecoming.  On Oct. 13, Hilkowitz and Miller emailed Tolchinsky, Clavio and other university leadership, pleading with them to take back their decision. Hilkowitz and Miller argued the directive infringed on their right to free speech, and suddenly cutting the print edition would interfere with advertiser relations.  If the decision to cut print was solely fiscal, then why would university leadership make such a sudden move that could grow the paper’s deficit even more? It’s because the IU Media School would rather double down than realize the error of its ways.  Tolchinsky’s attempt to paint his attempt at censorship as a business decision is inexcusable.  The IDS’ budget deficit is something that needed to be addressed, but after agreeing to take on the publications’ deficit in the 2021-22 fiscal year for three years, the media school only met with the IDS once over the two years. During that time, the deficit neared $500,000.  The silver lining to the situation is that the IDS handled it gracefully. Although they couldn’t get it to newsstands, the IDS published their Oct. 16 edition online with the front headline reading “CENSORED” in bold red font, accompanied by a subhead reading “This is not about print, this is about a breach of editorial independence.”  The edition had the publication’s general news coverage, but that coverage would not have reached the Indiana student body if the IDS hadn’t taken matters into its own hands. The ad spaces were blacked out and replaced with text showing how much the paper was losing in potential advertising revenue, more evidence that this wasn’t a fiscal decision.  In the face of complete and inexcusable censorship at the hands of their own university, the IDS is showing exactly why journalistic independence is needed in our country. As an independent student media organization, The Daily Nebraskan stands in solidarity with the IDS and with journalists facing censorship nationwide.

title: EDITORIAL: Chancellor Rodney Bennett needs to face DEI concerns
author: The Daily Nebraskan’s Editorial Board
body: As the only BIG 10 school without an Office of Diversity and Inclusion, The Daily Nebraskan believes that Chancellor Rodney D. Bennett needs to show up and address DEI concerns for students.  Bennett began his role as chancellor at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln in July 2023 after previously serving as the president of the University of Southern Mississippi.  Prior to being elected, Bennett openly talked about his plans to face DEI problems at UNL. At a forum on June 6, 2023, he responded to diversity concerns that Executive Associate Athletic Director for Strategic Initiatives, Lawrence Chatters, had about his daughter starting at UNL.  “I will always use the position of chancellor to move the needle forward,” Bennett responded. “As you and others have talked about today, I’ll never sit silent, sit on my hands and not speak up.”  A year after his term started, however, he did just that. After previously acknowledging how much better UNL is “when we have multiple voices around the table,” Bennett decided to shut down ODI on Aug. 20, 2024. This decision also eliminated the position of Vice Chancellor for Diversity and Inclusion.  In a message to students, Bennett said ODI is “no longer right for our institution.”  The message detailed his new decentralized approach that still valued DEI, just in a new way. He emphasized how interactions between people among different backgrounds remain important, yet his following actions told a different story.  While this closure shocked students, Bennett stayed silent. Since the closure, Bennett has sent four messages to students, with only one briefly mentioning these changes.  In this message, Bennett said services are not reduced, but instead dispersed among Vice Chancellors. Bennett assigned larger responsibilities to Vice Chancellors to make up for the closure of ODI.  Bennett gave this small reassurance behind his computer screen, but has yet to address students in person.  The Association of Students for the University of Nebraska and UNL’s NAACP chapter hosted a Q&A session with Bennett for students to get answers to DEI-related questions. However, Bennett himself wasn’t in attendance.  Despite scheduling around Bennett’s events and reaching out on many occasions, Bennett didn’t show up to the town hall. Instead, students took the time to express their frustration about ODI’s closure, while their questions remained unanswered.  Bennett closing ODI and not answering students’ questions face-to-face speaks to where his priorities lie. It’s obvious that there’s a disconnect between Bennett’s words and his actions.  Not attending a Q&A to address student concerns after previously stating how much he cares about diversity on campus is a slap in the face to countless students at UNL. Answering questions from students recently deprived of resources and a sense of community should be the bare minimum from Bennett.  As we enter this next semester, The Daily Nebraskan hopes to see change from Bennett moving forward. Not only acknowledging students’ concerns, but also showing up to planned events would be a great place to start for students to feel like they belong at UNL under Bennett’s leadership.  Students can share their opinions on Bennett’s actions as chancellor by submitting a letter to the editor here.

title: EDITORIAL: Cutting student journalism cuts campus transparency
author: The Daily Nebraskan Editorial Board
body: This story was updated at 11:30 a.m. on Wednesday, March 5, to reflect that a Stanford's Board of Trustees investigation found no evidence to conclude that former Stanford President Marc Tessier-Lavigne personally engaged in research misconduct. Dr. Tessier-Lavigne's resignation letter cited "the good of the University" as his reason for stepping down.  The Daily Nebraskan Editorial Board urges universities everywhere to protect student journalism funding and recognize its vital role on campuses.  University administrators and student governments nationwide are slashing funding for college newspapers, threatening both the quality of coverage and survival of these often century-old media outlets. These cuts don’t just hurt student journalists, they also weaken oversight and deprive campus communities of information they deserve.  On Feb. 10, the University of Kansas Student Senate proposed an 80% funding cut for The University Daily Kansan from $3.64 to 75 cents.  "My whole philosophy for this is if you cut four-fifths of my funding, students are going to get one-fifth of the coverage. It’s that simple,” Courtney Lane, editor-in-chief of The UDK, said.  Recent budget cuts are the latest instance in a long line of attacks against student journalism across the country.  Luckily for The UDK, their Student Senate finance council voted overwhelmingly to reject that bill.  Other newspapers haven’t been as lucky.  The Daily Trojan, a historic student newspaper at the University of Southern California, saw all of its funding cut late last year, eliminating pay for staffers and limiting its print schedule to three days a week.  It was the sole remaining college paper on the West Coast that printed every weekday.  “This decision was made without consulting The Daily Trojan’s student leadership in any capacity. Student Life told us, despite our objections, that their decision was final,” The Daily Trojan Spring 2025 Managing Team said in a letter from the editors.  The Daily Collegian, the 137-year-old newspaper at Penn State University, learned in March 2023 that, starting last August, the paper would lose all funding from PSU’s general fund.  The Collegian’s Board of Directors sent a letter of appeal to Penn State’s President to request holding the newspaper's cut to 15%. They never heard back after an initial acknowledgement that the office received the message.  When PSU initially announced the plan for university-wide budget cuts, it said no unit would receive cuts of more than 4% each year leading up to 2025, according to The Daily Collegian.  Rider University in New Jersey cut funding for its student newspaper, the Rider News, last August, severely limiting its print capabilities.  “It is a shame that our newsstands, where students, faculty and staff alike would normally grab our latest issue, will be empty at times,” Rider News editors said in the article.  Even in Nebraska, student newspapers are taking a hit. The University of Nebraska Omaha cut funding to its newspaper, The Gateway, in April 2023, bringing the senior staff salary budget from $30,000 to $0.  The Gateway was the only organization at UNO that used student fees to pay student salaries.  These aren’t the only cases of student newspaper funding cuts, and they most certainly won’t be the last. As universities across the country continue to struggle with difficult budget decisions, student newspapers are on the chopping block.  Administrators and student governments may view student newspapers as disposable luxuries, but that couldn’t be further from the truth. College media serves as both the training ground for the journalists of tomorrow and the watchdog that holds universities accountable today.  "Student journalists are the journalists of the future. If we want to continue to hold our government and our society accountable in the coming years, we really need to be investing in the people who are going to be doing that coverage,” Lane said.  Student journalists have long investigated and exposed wrongdoings within their universities. Take, for instance, The Stanford Daily, which investigated claims in 2022 that the university’s president published research papers containing manipulated data. A Stanford Board of Trustees investigation later found evidence of manipulation in certain papers by members of Dr. Tessier-Lavigne's lab, but concluded he did not have knowledge of the misconduct and was in no position to identify it.  Former Stanford President Marc Tessier-Lavigne resigned on Aug. 31, 2023, citing “the good of the University” as his reason for stepping down.  Theo Baker, the head journalist for the investigation, was honored with a George Polk Award for his work.  At the University of Florida, The Independent Florida Alligator conducted an extensive investigation revealing former UF President Ben Sasse’s financial scandal, in which he tripled his office's spending to $17.3 million from the previous president.  It’s not just administration that college newspapers keep an eye on, it’s all programs, even athletics. In July 2023, The Daily Northwestern exposed hazing and sexual assault among the University of Northwestern football team, leading to firing of their head coach.  Without student journalism, these stories would’ve likely gone untold.  When universities cut funding for the voice of the student body, they’re silencing that voice, crippling our ability to hold the people in power in check and ensuring that crucial campus stories go uncovered, with no one to tell the story.  "We cover the things that no one else will—mold in dorms, student government decisions, university policies that impact students. If we disappear, so does that coverage,” Lane said.  Universities must restore and protect funding for student journalism before they create a generation of campuses where truth is optional.

title: EDITORIAL: Don’t let Trump kill the PRESS Act
author: The Daily Nebraskan’s Editorial Board
body: President-elect Donald J. Trump recently pushed for congressional Republicans to block the passage of a federal shield bill intended to protect journalists.  Earlier this year, Republicans and Democrats in the House of Representatives unanimously passed the Protect Reporters from Exploitative State Spying, or ‘PRESS’ Act.  This bipartisan measure is designed to limit the government’s ability to compel journalists to reveal their sources and restrict federal law enforcement’s surveillance of the press.  The bill, originally slated for potential passage in the Senate later this month, has now hit a firm roadblock following Trump’s intervention.  On his Truth Social platform, Trump declared, “REPUBLICANS MUST KILL THIS BILL!," signaling opposition to the measure, all but ensuring the bill will not pass the Senate floor.  The Daily Nebraskan supports the PRESS Act and condemns the President-elect's attempts to undermine protections for journalists and whistleblowers who work to hold the powerful accountable.  Our publication finds the President-elect’s actions troubling for our staff and the audience we represent. Our student-run newsroom acts independently from the university, allowing our reporters the same press freedoms shared by newspapers across the country.  In the same way that The DN holds UNL’s administration accountable for transgender healthcare without administrative oversight, national publications should retain the same freedom in dealing with the federal government.  A federal shield law for journalists must be passed.  Journalists serve as a watchdog for democracy — uncovering corruption, exposing abuse of power and informing the public. These journalistic pillars depend on the trust that sources and leaks have in their confidentiality with reporters.  Exposing wrongdoings, corruption and abuse of power relies on brave officials and public figures who are willing to bring those issues to light. These sources, with their livelihoods on the line, are hesitant even with shield laws in place.  Federal oversight threatens to create a chilling effect, silencing investigative journalism and eroding public trust. The PRESS Act is not an irrational demand, but rather an extension of the freedoms enshrined in the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution.  Americans deserve the truth about their elected officials and the government they serve in. Anything less would be unacceptable in our democracy.  For democracy to survive and flourish, the press must remain free to expose the truth, uncover corruption and protect the public interest. The PRESS Act deserves to be passed, and Trump’s efforts to dismantle press protection must not prevail.  There’s no good reason for Trump to oppose the act other than his desire to investigate the press and disregard First Amendment protections.  The President-elect has repeatedly called journalists the “enemy of the people” and a “threat to democracy.” Trump recently vowed to enact vengeance on news outlets that anger him, pledging to toss reporters in jail and hinder major television networks.  In his first term as president, Trump tripled the number of leak investigations, culminating in the seizure of phone records of New York Times reporters in 2017. During the Biden administration, Attorney General Merrick Garland put in place a temporary policy that banned the use of subpoenas, warrants or court orders to seize reporters’ communication records.  Without a federal shield law in place, Trump or another future president’s administration could reverse that regulation.  It speaks volumes that a heavily divided U.S. House unanimously passed the PRESS Act. This clearly shows the heavy support for media independence and journalist confidentiality among all areas of congress, save for the incoming commander-in-chief.  The PRESS Act would protect all journalists, including conservative, independent and liberal media outlets. This is not a partisan issue.  The Daily Nebraskan calls on Congress to pass the PRESS Act and uphold journalistic freedoms among attacks on its very foundation.

title: Editorial: How we’re fighting for COVID transparency from the university
author: Staff
body: On Aug. 27, the University of Nebraska-Lincoln published a COVID-19 dashboard to track positive test results in the campus community. The Daily Nebraskan was glad to see this effort, and we hope it continues to be a valuable resource throughout the semester.  But it’s not enough.  The current situation demands a level of transparency and accountability that, thus far, the university has failed to provide. The effects of this are shown in the questions we receive daily from anxious students through our Curious Cornhuskers initiative.  Students want to know why the university did not publish the case tracker sooner.  Why weren’t students tested for COVID-19 before they moved back into residence halls? What consequences do students in Greek life have for hosting parties?  How many cases is too many, and what point would the university switch to remote learning?  Students want answers — they deserve answers — and The Daily Nebraskan staff is trying its best to provide for them. We created an FAQ page on our website, which we will continually update with answers to your questions and the information you need to know about COVID-19 on campus.  Unfortunately, finding these answers is not always a straightforward process. Few university staff members are able to speak with our reporters, and the administration sometimes doesn’t have an answer at all.  This is a difficult, unprecedented and constantly evolving situation, and we would like to be understanding of that. We know from spending time in our own office that each day presents a new challenge. In the first three weeks of school, 50% of our in-office staff has had to take leave due to symptoms of illness or exposure to someone who tested positive.  As student leaders, we are frustrated with the little guidance the university has provided in dealing with this challenge. Furthermore, we have concerns about how these statistics are echoed in the university community. As journalists, we’d really like to know.  Overall, we’re disappointed with the university’s handling of the return to campus.  We don’t understand why an entire class is not allowed to know that an unnamed peer tested positive. We’re confused by the lack of mask policy enforcement in common spaces and the idea that we are all responsible for reporting those who don’t comply.  We have concerns about the university’s use of “strongly encouraged” when detailing policies on campus. We’re not sure why the Cornhusker Commitment is not mandatory. We don’t think the ratio of 25,000 people to 1 testing site is rational.  The Daily Nebraskan will continue to fight for transparency and answers from the university. In the meantime, you can expect to be hearing from us a lot more — specifically, from our new COVID team.  Under the leadership of former assistant culture editor David Berman and former assistant news editor Zach Wendling, The Daily Nebraskan has dedicated a set staff solely for COVID-19 coverage.  This team will answer all of your COVID-19 questions, whether you submit them through Curious Cornhuskers, DM us on Facebook or go on a Twitter rant that we happen to catch wind of. They will also publish data-driven stories, as well as feature stories about the student perspective of current life on campus.  We want this team to be your go-to source for information, direction and, hopefully, assurance.  So, here’s what we need from you.  If you have a question, submit it at this link. If you have a thought, submit a letter to the editor. To make sure you’re all caught up, subscribe to our newsletter. If you want to join our team, apply here.  We hope to have a successful and healthy semester on campus with you. But even if we have to go back to working from our bedrooms, we will be on your screen, in your pocket and, in spirit, by your side.

title: Editorial: Maintaining our mission to tell the stories of all UNL students
author: Karissa Schmidt and Ally Sargus
body: The world we live in has changed and continues to change drastically in light of the COVID-19 pandemic. Most components of our everyday lives have been shifted or put on hold for the time being. For The Daily Nebraskan, this meant a change in plans for our final magazine of the school year. We know that news continues regardless of how you receive it, so we’ve decided to solely publish the stories online instead of printing copies to distribute throughout campus.  Why? The answer is simple: There’s no one here to physically read it, and we want to do our part to mitigate the spread of the coronavirus.  Despite the change in format, we want to reassure you that this publication is just as important as any other. Even in this unprecedented time, we will continue to shed light on issues that affect the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and campuses nationwide.  In this edition of The DN, we emphasize the importance of diversity.  Over the last couple of years, diversity has been at the forefront of conversations at UNL. In 2018, a student who was a self-proclaimed white supremacist sparked outrage and fear on campus. The incident caused the university to take action with the "Hate Will Never Win" campaign in an effort to restore peace.  This year, students spoke out against the lack of diversity efforts in faculty and student enrollment at UNL. They argued that the few faculty members representing diverse communities makes the transition into college more difficult for students in those communities.  Diversity is crucial to college campuses, and we try to reflect that in our day-to-day news coverage. But we also recognize there are groups on campus who often don’t receive the same level of coverage as others.  We aim to cover several communities, but we understand this collection of stories reflects just a portion of the students on campus.  We highlight individuals on campus who have made an impact on students and colleagues, such as Anna Shavers, the associate dean for diversity and inclusion in the Nebraska College of Law, and Kevin Reese, the OASIS program coordinator.  Through stories about the South of Downtown Art Hub and the band Mental Disturbance, the churches available to students and dining halls with cultural selections, we touch on how students can explore their identities on and off campus.  With Nebraska Athletics as an influential force in Lincoln, we knew it was important to include the stories of athletes in the LGBTQ community and teammates who openly practice their religions.  We even include a timeline of prominent additions to UNL that feature diversity from the university’s creation in 1869 to the present year.  In no way are these stories a complete representation of the diversity on UNL’s campuses, and we encourage students to reach out so that we can continue to diversify our own coverage.  The Daily Nebraskan aims to share the stories of all students on campus and their individual college experiences. Every Husker has their own story that deserves to be told, and it is our mission to tell it.  Sincerely,  Karissa Schmidt and Ally Sargus  Editor-in-chief and managing editor

title: EDITORIAL: Pillen must apologize for his xenophobic and dishonest ignorance
author: The Daily Nebraskan's Editorial Board
body: The Daily Nebraskan condemns Gov. Jim Pillen’s recent xenophobic remarks about Yanqi Xu. We urge him to apologize to Xu and recognize how his harmful rhetoric reflects on the potential next generation of Nebraskans.  On Sept. 11, 2023, Pillen responded to a radio host’s question about a report by Yanqi Xu, a 6-year U.S. resident from Guangzhou, China:  “Number one, I didn’t read it and I won’t,” he said. “Number two, all you gotta do is look at the author. Author’s from communist China. What more do you need to know?”  On Oct. 20, Pillen had the opportunity to apologize.  “My comments were my comments,” he said when asked to comment by the Nebraska Examiner.  Pillen is correct: Yanqi Xu did grow up in China. However, his suggestion that her place of birth has anything to do with her reporting is, in our view, disrespectful, repulsive and intolerable. Even if Xu lacked her exceptional pedigree, she and her reporting would still be worth the governor’s respect. In dismissing her as simply “from communist China,” Pillen, knowingly or not, signals to Nebraskans that he will engage with xenophobia when it benefits him.  Emily Taylor, social chair of the Asian Student Union at UNL and whose mother is a Filipina immigrant, told The Daily Nebraskan that the governor’s words make her feel unwelcome.  “When it’s our governor that is saying these things, it really makes me not feel safe, it doesn’t really make me feel supported and it doesn’t make me feel good about the well-being and safety of my family and friends who are also Asian,” Taylor, a senior child, youth and family studies major, said.  “And then I feel like the Nebraska Legislature wonders, well, ‘Why do young people keep leaving Nebraska?’ and, well, it’s because we don’t feel safe and supported,” Taylor continued.  As a successful businessman, Pillen should have responded to the facts of Xu’s article, which reported how high nitrate levels on some of his family’s hog farms could have dangerous downstream effects. Yet, four days after Xu’s story was published, our governor attacked her credibility instead of responding to her reporting.  In doing so, he chose to promote prejudice toward the Chinese — who are already suffering from discrimination, xenophobia and violence stoked by the COVID-19 pandemic and geopolitical tensions, according to the Asian American Journalists Association. Pillen should be aware that his purposeful xenophobia fuels further prejudice.  Above all else, Pillen violates a basic human principle: nobody should be judged by where they were born.  The DN rejects Pillen’s divisiveness and his purposeful ignorance. As the sole independent student publication of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, we value integrity, we value diversity and we value honesty.  As an organization of nearly 100 young professionals deciding where to spend the rest of our lives, we rebuke the governor’s words because those words reflect an agenda that alienates us.  The governor’s apology would start to heal the polarization caused by his remarks and underline that xenophobia is unacceptable. The governor’s apology would indicate that he understands that his power to spread hate can also spread community. The governor’s apology would prove that he values integrity, diversity and honesty, too.  The governor must understand that students are listening. Students who agree with these values and that the governor should apologize can write him a letter in support of Xu, or write the DN a letter to the editor.

title: EDITORIAL: Proposed cuts to UNL exacerbate brain drain
author: The Daily Nebraskan’s Editorial Board
body: Brain drain – a topic of discussion spurring up in universities across the country.  This term sits in the minds of those in higher education, defined as an emigration of a state’s most skilled and educated workforce to outside states.  After years of declining and plateauing enrollment numbers, keeping Nebraskan students in the state is becoming increasingly important.  When universities dial back funding and cut programs that house hundreds of eager students who want to stay in the state, they don’t just lose students. They lose the next generation of Nebraskans.  If these cuts go through, the University of Nebraska-Lincoln will see over $100 million in budget reductions, cutting down faculty and eliminating programs before our eyes.  With six programs proposed to be cut, this begs the question: Does the federal and state legislatures truly care about halting brain drain?  However, there is no reason to blame NU president Jeffrey Gold or the university as a whole. Gold got the short end of the stick and was expected to repair a university facing state and federal cuts.  Even though the university is trying its best to accommodate programs and strategically make cuts that impact the least amount of students, concerns and anger should be redirected to state and federal legislation that trickled down, affecting students at UNL.  Cuts, such as the Trump administration’s “Big, Beautiful Bill,” directly impact the university and its students through research and funding cuts. It must be noted that many of those in charge of these cuts, nationally and state-wide, have been out of college for years, sometimes even decades. Why should those who’ve spent decades outside higher education get to cut programs benefitting hundreds of students at UNL and thousands nationwide?  Although 635 students are enrolled in the programs proposed to be eliminated, the proposed cuts will reduce the state-aided budget by 1% university-wide, saving a total of $4.61 million. Mark Button, interim executive vice chancellor, said that the 1% cut is estimated to save the same amount of money as cutting two mid-sized programs.  This reduction will mean that every college will see the negative impact of budget cuts, even those that do not contain programs on the chopping block.  In addition, the university has budgeted for roughly 38 professors to retire voluntarily, while another 77 will be eliminated, according to Button. 71 of the 77 professors to be let go are tenured or on tenure-track.  By eliminating some of the university’s longest-standing professors, we eliminate some of our greatest resources and strain the remaining faculty by increasing their workload to make up for the losses.  Budget cuts harm not only the university, but Nebraska as a whole. In the face of brain drain, eliminating programs that are the only of their kind in the state and reducing the quality of education that Nebraska’s only public university system provides seems to be a large step in the wrong direction. As the state’s largest employer, the university makes $10 for every $1, clearly showing higher education in the capital city is our state’s money-maker.  If those making budget-related decisions at the federal and state levels are comfortable with offloading budgeting issues to universities, one can’t help but wonder if they really value education.

title: EDITORIAL: Student Press Freedom Day, importance of student-run newspapers
author: The Daily Nebraskan’s Editorial Board
body: The Daily Nebraskan is the University of Nebraska-Lincoln’s only independent, student-run publication. To us, that’s more than just a description of what we do.  Our editorial choices don’t require approval from a moderator, faculty member or university president. We’re incredibly fortunate to have the freedom that we do, serving as an informed voice of the student body while also bringing light to university issues.  On Student Press Freedom Day, The Daily Nebraskan’s editorial board wants to acknowledge and stand with our fellow student journalists who aren’t as fortunate to have the same level of journalistic freedom. Censorship of the student press, from colleges and universities to high schools, is unacceptable and all student-run publications deserve the same level of editorial freedom that we enjoy.  Even within state borders, that editorial freedom is far from guaranteed.  Although there have been efforts for student press freedom in Nebraska, censorship continues to flourish, especially in Nebraska high schools. Westside High School, who had earned the reputation of producing independent content, began to enforce prior review in 2020 by appointing an administrator to look over every article before it can publish.  On Feb. 12, 2021, Westside High School’s administration censored a student editorial about censorship. Jerred Zegelis, one of the advisors, resigned the same day. After holding the story for a week, the administration approved the editorial to be published, but the students claimed that the damage had already been done.  In January 2021, Sen. Adam Morfield sponsored a bill — LB88 — that would extend free press protections to student journalists and their advisors in public high schools, colleges and universities. Some schools, such as Omaha Public Schools, were not in support of the bill. In March 2021, Nebraska lawmakers advanced the bill but in April 2021, the bill failed to pass after a filibuster.  The Daily Nebraskan is completely independent from the university. We are grateful to receive student fees that we use for facilities, publishing infrastructure and printing. We do not receive any oversight from administration or faculty; all of our daily work is produced by students, for students. Our independent paper, and those like us around the country, is a testament to the power of student press freedom.  Through this freedom, we have been able to use our platform to voice students’ concerns with the university.  When students first returned to campus during the pandemic, we called on the university to be more transparent with COVID-19 protocols. We questioned the lack of safety guidelines for students, the absence of re-entry testing and more. Eventually, the university updated protocols, and our staff continued to investigate the questions students brought to us. One year later, we again pointed out the university’s inability to protect its students after a student was allegedly sexually assaulted. All of which we would not have been able to do if we were working within the constraints of our university system.  While we have been fortunate enough to have press freedom at our publication, other student papers have not. Student Press Freedom Day is Feb. 24, and in recognizing this day we stand with our fellow student journalists to bring awareness to the importance of student press freedom.  Just this past month, The Battalion, which is the student newspaper for Texas A&M University, was told to cease printing with only 24 hours notice. Their university officials have since said the paper can continue printing through the end of the semester after which the paper will go purely digital.  A Student Press Coalition survey from 2018 asked student journalists at Council for Christian Colleges & Universities if they had felt pressure from “university personnel to change, edit or remove an article” after publication. Of the student editors that responded, 76% said yes. Schools should not interfere with journalism. The truth needs to be told, no matter what school officials believe or want to be told.  The theme this year for Student Press Freedom Day is “Unmute Yourself!” The Daily Nebraskan has been unmuted since our founding, but other student journalists still need help to be uncensored. That is why we are using our voice to support the voices of those who can’t write without being censored yet.  Take the time today to find out a little more about your college or high school’s publication. If your state — like Nebraska — doesn’t legally protect student press independence, you can submit a student journalist press freedom restoration act to your legislators. Here is a template for a bill.  We can’t take student journalism for granted, as the situation at Texas A&M shows very clearly. Student newspapers are important staples of their communities that provide a unique opportunity to hold people accountable, and we need to make sure they can keep doing that for years to come.  https://studentpressfreedom.org/

title: Editorial: Thank you, Warren Buffett
author: Editorial Board
body: Dear readers,  We are speechless.  And as a group of student journalists, we can tell you that doesn’t happen often.  Today, we learned Warren Buffett generously donated $100,000 to The Daily Nebraskan Editorial Support Fund, which helps pay editorial wages.  When we started our #SaveStudentNewsrooms campaign back in April, we set a goal to raise money to continue to train the next generation of professional journalists at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.  We're now one step closer to that goal.  We don’t think each donor realizes how much each donation means to the newsroom. Whether it’s $1 or $100,000, each donation is a declaration that the work we do matters.  As any journalist can attest, it hasn’t been the easiest couple of years for the industry. College publications aren’t immune to the struggles that newsrooms across the country have been facing.  Like many newsrooms, we haven’t made a profit in years. Our editors work more than 50 hours a week for less than $3 an hour.  But we love what we do, and we wouldn't trade those hours in for anything.  This donation, and every donation we have received so far, means more than you could possibly know. By donating, you ensure future editors and reporters will have the same opportunities we do.  Your donations have renergized an entire newsroom and rededicated us to our mission as the independent voice of UNL.  From our home in the basement of the Nebraska Union, we thank you.  Please continue to support and save student newsrooms. Visit savestudentnewsrooms.com for more information about the movement. To donate to The Daily Nebraskan, click here.

title: Editorial: The Daily Nebraskan is independent — let's keep it that way
author: Editorial Board
body: Student newspapers must perpetually grapple with a world in flux. Not only do reporters and editors graduate, but papers must face declining advertising revenue, the rise of digital media and the constant ebb and flow of the news cycle.  The Daily Nebraskan is no different. Like most news outlets, we’ve witnessed our revenue decline sharply and consistently in recent years. In 2017, we made the substantial leap from publishing a newspaper to a monthly magazine, The DN. We’ve also explored reaching our readers through our new culture, news and sports podcasts.  In spite of these changes, The Daily Nebraskan has stood firm in our independence from UNL’s direction, our pursuit of truth and our commitment to bringing the day’s news to the student body.  Even while working long hours and for less than minimum wage, we as editors refuse to budge on our core values. We’ve held these principles for over a century and have no intention of ever deviating from them.  Unfortunately for many college campuses across the United States, this journalistic integrity has come under threat. Papers directly affiliated with their universities have faced pressure to avoid reporting on sensitive stories, and at times have suffered stiff consequences for pursuing the truth. Just last year, two editors of Liberty University’s The Champion were fired for allegedly not presenting a positive enough image of the college. The University of North Alabama’s The Flor-Ala’s adviser was removed by the university in a move that was condemned as “retaliation for Constitutionally protected student speech” by the College Media Association.  Although we oftentimes take our journalistic liberty for granted at UNL, we’ve nonetheless remained vigilant over the years to maintain our independence.  In light of this, The Daily Nebraskan joins with other student newspapers across the country today in support of the Student Press Law Center’s Student Press Freedom Day.  We hope you join us in the effort to protect the student press in all its forms.  This year, The Daily Nebraskan has reported on the lasting legacy of Cornhusker Marching Band member Tyler Butterfield, the bond between a Husker football player and his fiancee, UNL’s transition to a new student advocate for sexual assault survivors and changes at the University Health Center. As always, we’ve kept ASUN accountable to you through our coverage of their weekly meetings.  Although we strive every day to bring you the highest-quality news possible, our efforts are for naught without you, the reader.  In this era of change, we humbly ask for your continued support. Tweet your support for SPLC’s campaign using #StudentPressFreedom. For more information on the campaign, please visit SPLC’s website. If you wish to donate directly to The Daily Nebraskan, click here.  The Daily Nebraskan has been the only independent voice of the student body for over a century. So long as there’s UNL news to report, with your help we hope to continue our mission well into the next hundred years.

title: Editorial: The Daily Nebraskan is not diverse; here’s how we’re fixing it
author: Drake Keeler
body: Media organizations across the country had a reckoning on race this summer.  Following the deaths of George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor and many others, the summer of 2020 was filled with protests. Americans were forced to examine the prevalence of racism in our everyday lives. For newsrooms, this meant re-examining how we cover Black communities, along with other underrepresented groups.  The Daily Nebraskan is no exception to newsrooms that need to take this necessary step. In April, before racial injustice was at the forefront of national news, we published an online magazine covering diversity on the University of Nebraska-Lincoln’s campus.  While it was a step in the right direction, there’s still more work to do. In June, we published an editorial communicating our support of the Black community and responding to criticism of our protest coverage.  Now, we’re taking another step. Once again, we won’t be putting out a physical magazine. Instead, we’ll publish an online project focused on Black Lives Matter and Black stories on campus, both now and historically. I, Drake Keeler, will be leading this project, which will feature multiple sections.  The first part of the project is this one right here, talking about our own newsroom diversity. The second will focus on the evolution of the Black Lives Matter movement, history of anti-Black racism at UNL and stories of Black trailblazers. Lastly, we will look at the current movements happening on campus and aim to capture what the Black experience is like for UNL students now.  But diversity and racism aren’t things to only cover in a special magazine or project. We should constantly be covering and addressing these things in our newsroom.  The reason we’re doing this now is not because it’s a hot topic that would attract readers. The point of this project is to put a spotlight on Black stories that haven’t been told enough or at all. This is meant to set in place a precedent to tell the stories of all people for years to come.  Before we do that, however, we must look at our own failures. As you look at the first edition of our annual newsroom diversity report, you’ll see that I’m the only Black person on The Daily Nebraskan’s staff. Yes, this means that almost none of the contributors to this project will be Black. While I made the choice to lead this project, and it was never something forced on me, it’s also clear that there weren’t a whole lot of diverse options.  I joined The Daily Nebraskan my freshman year in October of 2018. In the two years since, the lack of diversity — racial and otherwise — has been glaring. Reporting our diversity statistics annually will help us and the UNL community hold The Daily Nebraskan accountable.  Journalism as an industry has a diversity problem, and Nebraska is included in this. As Nebraska media outlets, we can send feel-good messages about how we support diversity, or we can put the work in to make structural change.  Along with telling the stories of all students on campus, The Daily Nebraskan has a responsibility to prepare young journalists for their future careers. We aren’t meeting this standard to the fullest if we aren’t creating an environment where all aspiring journalists and writers can come in and feel accepted for years to come.  That’s why, as part of this project, we will be launching The Daily Nebraskan Diversity and Inclusion Board. This board will include voices from both inside and outside The Daily Nebraskan, and it will have the purpose of fostering more inclusive coverage and a more diverse newsroom.  Making concerted efforts to be inclusive will create a larger pool of qualified, diverse journalists that can help make the Nebraska media market better. Of course, other publications across the state also need to do their part to make that work.  As the founder of the board, I will take on the privilege of becoming its first internal chair. On Wednesday, Oct. 7, applications will open to fill the board with an external chair and other members.  Having an external chair and board members from outside of The Daily Nebraskan will be crucial to the success of the board. While internal members will not be afraid to give criticism, we can’t always analyze our own work as objectively as those outside of our organization. I’m looking forward to building this team and working to make change with Nebraska students who are just as passionate about diversity and inclusion.  When complete, this board will focus on improving The Daily Nebraskan’s recruitment practices, making sure its coverage is inclusive and hearing from community voices.  Expanding on that last point, we’re looking to get UNL’s underrepresented communities involved in the creation of this project, even if you aren’t a part of The Daily Nebraskan. If you have any story ideas, questions, comments or concerns, you can make a submission to our Curious Cornhuskers initiative or email me at drakekeeler@dailynebraskan.com. In the near future, we’ll be creating even more opportunities for community feedback.  I’d like to reiterate that this is not just a semester project by a student newspaper. This is the start of a structural effort to make long-term change for the better in the media landscape.  Here’s to a more inclusive future,  Drake Keeler  drakekeeler@dailynebraskan.com

title: Editorial: The Daily Nebraskan's commitment to balancing ethics and morals
author: Editorial Board
body: Dear readers,  In the past week, cities across the country have been home to hundreds of Black Lives Matter protests. These protests follow the May 25 death of George Floyd — a Minneapolis man who died after ex-officer Derek Chauvin knelt on his neck for nearly nine minutes.  Also in the last week, The Daily Nebraskan has sent editors, reporters and photographers to protests in Lincoln and Omaha. We’ve observed the scene, collected quotes and taken photographs in hopes of telling a fair and complete account of these events.  In this time, we’ve received concerns from our readers about the language in some of our headlines and captions. Specifically, concerns about us downplaying the severity of the situation or that our writing implied a bias toward a specific side.  As a news organization, The Daily Nebraskan cannot take sides. We must remain neutral, even in the most divisive of times. Taking a stance would jeopardize our ability to provide our readers with the full picture.  Our job is to report facts and observations. We can only hope to accurately inform our readers; what our readers choose to do with or think of that information is not up to us.  In reporting these facts, we must be clear and literal, and we are very careful about the language we choose.  For example, we cannot refer to the deaths of Floyd or James Scurlock as murders because the law has not decided Chauvin or Jake Gardner are murderers. If the defendant has not been prosecuted, the law says the defendant is innocent.  So, we too have to say the defendant is innocent. We cannot call the individual a murderer, nor can we call the individual’s act a murder.  What we can say is that we stand with the Black community — our readers, our peers, our educators and our staffers — in the fight against systemic racism.  This April, The Daily Nebraskan published a series of articles about diversity with one goal: Tell the stories of all University of Nebraska-Lincoln students.  We recognize that, while the university has taken steps in increasing diversity and inclusion on campus, there is considerate work to be done. We also recognize that we have a responsibility to use our platform to give a voice to those who are most often overlooked.  So, this project was just the beginning. We want to continue to educate our readers and ourselves by sharing the stories of Black and other minority communities.  But reporting outward isn’t enough. To stop systemic racism, we must look inward. We acknowledge that we have work to do in the diversity of both our coverage and our newsroom. We are actively working to expand the reach of our coverage to include all identities on campus and recruit a more diverse staff for our publication.  Going forward, we want to be known as both an ally and as an ethical source. Our job is twofold: report fairly and provide a voice for our community. We encourage students to take part in that coverage by joining our staff, submitting questions or writing letters to the editor.  The Daily Nebraskan wants to hold both ourselves and our leaders accountable, and we invite you to help us do that.

title: EDITORIAL: UNL must take swift, definitive action to prevent more sexual violence
author: The Daily Nebraskan Editorial Board
body: Dear readers,  In light of the alleged sexual assault at Phi Gamma Delta fraternity, The Daily Nebraskan’s Editorial Board started crafting an editorial in response. Before we could publish it, another fraternity faced sexual assault allegations.  That leads us to ask — how many more sexual assaults need to occur before the university takes action?  By now, most everyone thinks they know the story. Reports of an alleged sexual assault at FIJI surfaced on Tuesday, Aug. 24, and by that night the fraternity was subject to campus-wide protests. Those protests continued for four consecutive days, and organizers plan to continue protesting until the university takes decisive action.  Here’s the problem. UNL’s track record of managing sexual assault on campus makes it impossible to believe that decisive action will take place. There’s more of a possibility the situation will be mismanaged, swept under the rug and repeated.  That cannot happen again.  To university administrators, we have a simple message: You have consistently failed at keeping your students safe. You have failed the community.  The events of last week are the latest in a long, long list of colossal administrative failures at combating sexual violence on campus.  In the past, the closest the university got to a sexual misconduct training — besides the one implemented in the spring — was in fall 2015 when students were strongly recommended to complete an online course. Less than 40% of students completed the training.  Between 1988 and 2001, there were speakers, conferences, a candlelit vigil and one other unrequired training put on by university groups at the time, according to Daily Nebraskan archives. There was no mention of required training for students on sexual misconduct before 2015.  Several alumni and past students — ranging from the past decade to the 1980s — have told The Daily Nebraskan they were never required to take sexual misconduct training.  While there is a fraternity-specific sexual assault prevention program called Husker Man, that program is run entirely through the Interfraternity Council and is not affiliated with the university.  The most recent training implemented in the spring was asynchronous, hidden behind a screen and filled with jokes that were insensitive to survivors of sexual assault or harrassment.
