It gives young adults a break from the uncertainty and pressure of everything else. Nostalgia has become a kind of emotional reset, a way to pause, breathe and escape the constant pressure to always be “on.”  Gen Z came of age during a pandemic, watched the economy wobble, dealt with rising student debt and was told the planet is dying. Young adults show higher levels of stress and mental health concerns than any of the previous generations in their 20s. It's no wonder that many are retreating to a time that felt safe before grades, bills, job applications and the pressure of having it all together.  The real kicker is that everyone, from social media to sitcoms says that college and early 20s are supposed to be the peak of life with carefree and unforgettable years. When they aren’t exactly that it can be easy to feel like a failure.  This narrative doesn't just cause stress, it fuels a self fulfilling spiral. When people say this is the best it's ever going to get, it can be easy to start grasping for any version of joy that feels right.  It's not that Gen Z doesn't want to be present, it's that they don't know how to feel okay in a present that doesn't match what was promised. Psychologists say nostalgia can function as emotional regulation. For college students dealing with identity shifts, academic pressure and post-grad uncertainty, looking back on childhood or high school memories can help create a sense of stability.  Nostalgia isn't inherently bad, and often it is just fun. The issue is when it's treated as a substitute for actually living life now; all the flaws, messiness and uncertainty of it all. The same goes for the myth that someone's 20s should be peak happiness, when in reality they’re a decade of confusion, learning and growth.  People turn to the past when the present feels too heavy. Growing up isn't about having it all figured out, it's about learning to sit with the uncertainty and still move forward anyway. Because these years don’t have to be perfect to be worth remembering later.
category: NOSTALGIA IS A CRUTCH FOR GEN Z

title: OPINION: 2000s fashion trends are coming back and bringing the culture with them
author: Rose Woelm
body: The 2000s were full of skinny jeans, trucker hats, layered tank tops and body shaming. The late 1990s and early 2000s popularized a thinner frame and coined the look "heroin chic."  The fun fashion trends were paired with an obsessive diet culture. This culture normalized body shaming and critique on full display from media outlets that freely commented on female celebrities' bodies. Now, the 2000s are coming back, and the culture is coming with it.  Fashion typically follows a 20-year cycle where trends from the past come back into the fold. With the rise of microtrends on platforms like TikTok and Instagram, fashion trend cycles are getting shorter, but overarching themes still shine through.  2000s staples like low-rise jeans have been online more and more over the past couple of months. The style is associated with a skinnier figure, one that fits into brands like Brandy Melville, a one-size-fits-all brand commonly called online “one size fits small.” When fashion trends resurface, cultural ones are sometimes close behind.  The 2000s created a harmful diet culture obsessed with skinnier frames, promoting dangerous fitness and nutrition trends in the name of achieving the perfect body for skinny jeans and low-rise shorts. However, the current body trends might not be much better. The body positive movement and fat acceptance movement have roots in advocacy for inclusion in public policy, tracing back to the 1960s. However, pockets of these movements have been co-opted on social media to advocate for remaining in unhealthy cycles rather than self-love and acceptance.  After the 2000s and 2010s, the movement known as body positivity exploded on social media, promoting body acceptance and intuitive eating. The movement advocated for more inclusive sizing at clothing retailers, preaching self-acceptance and self-love.  Another movement known as the fat acceptance movement online grew out of the body positive community. They advocated for self-love and argued that health at every size could be possible. Both movements have been around for decades, but were originally much more involved in policy reform issues.  Now, critics of the online factions of the movements say they’ve gone too far in the opposite direction, citing the growing obesity rate in the United States, with two in five adults in the U.S. being obese.  The response online to these movements and slight overcorrection has been a reversion to toxic mindsets. TikTok communities like “SkinnyTok” are eerily similar to the early days of pro-eating disorder blogs. They glamorize sayings like “nothing tastes as good as skinny feels” and have popularized terms like “big back.”  The culture around fashion and diet is constantly shifting. It wasn’t long ago that the brand Victoria’s Secret faced public backlash for glamorizing thinner bodies through their marketing and advertising, sizing and their iconic fashion shows. However, when Victoria’s Secret came back with a new approach to their shows, people online were asking for the old production to come back with comments critiquing the appearance and the models.  The 2000s gave us iconic brands and trends that still influence many people’s style today. It also gave us platforms like pro-eating disorder blogs and dangerous diet culture trends. Fashion trends are bound to come back, and some of them should. I love a good low-rise flare jean, but we can do without the food and body shaming or unattainable beauty standards.  Rose Woelm is a philosophy and journalism double major. Reach her at rosewoelm@dailynebraskan.com

title: OPINION: Allyship doesn’t count when it’s selective
author: Benjamin Korinek
body: Sometimes friendships feel more like a role than a relationship. You’re the funny one, the one who hypes everyone up or the one who always knows how to make a room lighter. It feels good at first to be liked, but then you realize they love the version of you that entertains them, not necessarily the person you are.  It’s easy to say you support the community, but it’s harder when it means calling out a homophobic joke or standing up to your friend’s ignorance. The “gay best friend” trope has normalized the idea that queer people exist to make straight people’s lives brighter. Pop culture has glamorized it for years, turning gay men into side characters instead of full people. Acceptance often depends on how convenient or comfortable your gayness is for someone else.  Many people love to say they support the LGBTQ+ community, until it costs them something. They’ll fan over Chappell Roan, Troye Sivan, and Doechii, post rainbow emojis during June and tell you how much you mean to them. But when their boyfriend drops a slur, they go silent. Yes, we’re funny, but liking a gay friend for comedic relief while ignoring real prejudice isn’t support. It’s treating queer people like entertainment instead of individuals.  There’s an unspoken rule that if you’re gay and want to be accepted, you have to be loud, stylish and entertaining. It’s often harder for introverted individuals to make friends in general, but when you’re gay, there’s an added layer of fear to put yourself out there.  It also highlights privilege within the community. I realize as a gay man, it’s often easier for me to make friends or be “accepted” than it is for many trans, nonbinary or gender-nonconforming people. Society prefers queerness neat, male and familiar. The kinds of people they can laugh with, not the kind they have to listen to.  Movies and TV shows have been recycling the “gay best friend” character for decades at this point. Although it feels a bit like representation, it doesn’t give queer men a storyline beyond comedic relief. Bowen Yang’s a great example of how to be comedic and expressive at the same time. He’s one of the funniest people on “Saturday Night Live,” but layered too. The same is said for David Rose from “Schitt’s Creek,” who gave watchers something different. His story was about love, not trauma.  Both Yang and Rose prove that queerness doesn’t have to exist for someone’s amusement. Viewers love jokes, but don’t care when queer people have to fight for rights to healthcare, marriage or acceptance.  Some people might argue that having any gay friends or media characters at all is progress. Visibility matters, but why is it so controversial to want to be treated with the same respect as everyone else? Representation means little when it’s based on stereotypes or surface-level tolerance. Being seen isn’t the same as being valued, and visibility without depth isn’t representation. You can’t say that the LGBTQ+ community is treated equally when our rights are actively being taken away.  The gay best friend trope may seem harmless, but it’s a reminder that our acceptance comes with conditions. People want the fun part of queerness, the humor, confidence and emotional support, without the responsibility of standing up for us when it matters. We deserve better than to be someone’s temporary accessory or proof of open-mindedness. True friendship is about respect, reciprocity and seeing someone as a person; it exists beyond convenience or aesthetics.  Benjamin Korinek is a sophomore journalism major. You can reach him at benjaminkorinek@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Break up with Valentine’s Day cliches
author: Jocelynn Messersmith
body: Red hearts on cupid’s bow and a box of chocolates sweeter than sugar. The beginning of February marks the countdown to Valentine’s Day. Love is in the air and there is no better day than one spent with someone who is near and dear to our hearts. But, is Valentine’s day all joy and love or have people started to get sick of this cliche holiday?  Valentine’s Day dates back to ancient Roman times. While no one has pinpointed the exact beginning of the holiday, some people believe that Valentine’s Day commemorates the anniversary of Roman priest Valentine’s death around 270 A.D. Others claim that the Christian Church placed St. Valentine’s feast to christianize the pagan celebration of Lupercalia which was typically a bloody festival with animal sacrifices.  In modern times, Valentine’s Day marks a day of love signaled by hearts, doves and roses, but the overcommercialization of this holiday has left consumers cringing in grocery stores.  Valentine’s Day can easily become a cliche if we get stuck in the same routine of a fancy dinner followed by a box of chocolates and roses. This holiday deserves an improvement by using creative ways to ask someone to be a valentine and switching up date night.  Some people prefer to take a short and simple approach to Valentine’s Day. Asking someone to be a valentine especially while in a relationship can seem cheesy. A lot of people opt to send a message over text or in person with the question. To break away from this cliche, there are unique and memorable ways to ask someone.  Valentine’s Day should be a personalized holiday. To ask someone it is important to start by picking one of their favorite things. For example, if they enjoy coffee then a simple way to ask them to be a valentine is giving them a drink with the question on the cup. This demonstrates knowledge of the other person’s interests making it a special way to ask them out. This works for all kinds of hobbies and likes. If they enjoy reading, a personalized bookmark on a page is a simple way to show love.  Deciding how to spend Valentine’s Day is the most important aspect of the holiday. Many people decide to keep it simple and go out to a fancy restaurant for dinner. As someone who has done this before, trust me when I say it is the worst mistake to make.  While dinner seems nice, the high traffic the holiday brings makes dining out not worth it. Even with a reservation couples can end up waiting hours to be seated. Not to mention that many restaurants only serve a prix fixe menu meaning there are less options of what to eat typically at a higher price.  Instead of falling into this cliche, find different ways to make this night special. Make a romantic dinner at home or plan an entirely different activity. There are many ideas that can be personalized and romantic like a dinner date.  Typically on Valentine’s Day, couples like to exchange gifts. Most of the time this consists of chocolates, roses and cards. While these are all nice ideas, they are all cliche gifts that aren’t personalized or meaningful.  An easy way to elevate gift giving is by customizing different gifts. Instead of chocolates choose their favorite candy or snack and instead of roses opt for their favorite flower or item. A handwritten note is a great way to show commitment and love. It doesn’t have to be an expensive gift, it just has to be thoughtful to whoever is receiving it.  It’s okay to think that Valentine’s Day is another cheesy holiday and an excuse to spend money. Nonetheless, by taking a different approach to the holiday and demonstrating a deep understanding to a significant other it can make the holiday seem less tacky.  Valentine’s Day can be more than just another couples cliche. This holiday is a chance to show commitment to someone else and demonstrate how well we understand each other on a deep level. Going above and beyond on Valentine’s Day says that love is special and unique to everyone. So, before asking someone with roses and chocolates, think about how that person can feel heard as an individual instead. XOXO.  Jocelynn Messersmith is a freshman journalism and broadcasting double major. You can reach her at jocelynnmessersmith@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Checks, balances and breakdowns
author: Dawson Iassilo
body: When one political party controls all three branches of government, checks and balances are thrown out the window. Partisan loyalty often blurs the lines between branches and allows abuses of power to go unchecked. Many leaders blindly follow their party instead of being loyal to their country.  Checks and balances were formed to self-police the government. They ensure that no party gains too much power and veers the U.S. away from a democracy.  Checks and balances often fail when one party rules all three branches of government. Partisan loyalty undermines democratic norms and powers, and a single party's concentration makes it impossible for the opposing party to be represented.  In recent years, policies and loyalty to the country have taken a backseat to party affiliations. When all three branches put their party above all else, no single branch of government can keep another in line.  When Congress leans in the same direction as the president, they are less likely to challenge the president on wrongdoings. President Donald Trump’s two impeachments were a prime example of this. While Democrats had control of the House of Representatives, Republicans had control of the Senate and ultimately had the final say. Both impeachment trials were essentially a slap on the wrist to the president because these members of Congress held party loyalty over the Constitution.  There is nothing holding leaders accountable except for the risk of losing reelection. However, many voters put their party above the Constitution and the good of the country. Therefore voters continue to vote for the party they align with regardless of their policies, accountability and duties while serving.  The judicial branch is a huge component of the checks and balances system. The judicial branch was created as a nonpartisan branch to act as a mediator in case Congress and the executive branch ended up in control by the same party.  Trump nominated three out of nine of the Supreme Court Justices in his first term This resulted in six of the nine leaning heavily right and in favor of the Republican Party. Every constitutional decision for the foreseeable future will fall in line with Trump. Trump has found defect in this key component of checks and balances and made the court incredibly partial.  With the three branches of government controlled by one party, it leads to the risk of democratic morals being undermined. The entire idea of checks and balances is to ensure every branch is kept in line to follow the democratic process. In Trump’s first term, there was a significant loss of democratic processes because of the control Republicans had.  Some may see unified party control as a positive as it allows more overall government activity, including bills passed. While that may be a beneficial thing for half the country who supports the party in control, the other half of the country is unrepresented in any branch of government which undermines democracy.  In theory, checks and balances are a great tool for ensuring that democracy stays strong and that one branch of government doesn’t reign over another. However, when a party has the upper hand in each branch of government, there is no one to make sure the others in power are held accountable. Checks and balances have their loopholes and Republicans have definitely found them.  Dawson Iasillo is a sophomore political science and journalism major. Reach her at dawsoniasillo@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Democrats, start being an opposition party
author: Bret Fulton
body: The first couple of weeks in President DonaldTrump’s administration has put a strain on the morale of Democrats across the country. With institutions and the rule of law under attack, Democrats need to start taking solid action. It is time for Democrats to start being the opposition party.  Republicans gained their federal trifecta (obtaining control of the White House, the House of Representatives and Senate) for the first time since 2016 this past election cycle. President Trump has yet to use this trifecta though, as he has instead governed almost entirely through far reaching, and oftentimes illegal, executive orders. Republicans have allowed the Trump administration to purge federal agencies and freeze funds already allocated by Congress while offering no oversight on executive orders that are blatantly unconstitutional.    After Trump’s executive order freezing all public spending was signed, it became clear that Democrats were in disarray as their response was an emergency caucus meeting planned for the next day.  If Democrats want to win again, they need to create a winning strategy that will sweep them into power come the 2026 and 2028 elections. Some possibilities include coalescing around a leader and creating a solid policy agenda instead of just holding a Zoom meeting.  The Democrat’s policy agenda should be one that is easy to understand and resonates with the public. They must focus on lowering the cost of living through policies that prevent price gouging and ban large corporations from buying single family homes who in turn raise costs.  Democrats should adopt an anti-corruption agenda by promising to hold Tesla CEO, Elon Musk, and Trump accountable for illegally gaining access to the personal information of millions of Americans at the Treasury Department.  Unelected billionaires should not hold the reigns of power in the United States. While they have disproportionately held influence in the American government for decades, recent activities by Musk and the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) are unprecedented. The executive branch should follow the will of the millions of Americans who put them in charge, not the orders of the world's wealthiest man.  The Democrat's playbook for DOGE illegally freezing funds and purging federal agencies of career civil servants has largely consisted of only holding angry press conferences expressing their disapproval. Even some Republicans have begun to question the influence Musk has over our government. Therefore, Democrats should build coalitions in Congress to push anti-corruption legislation and hold those who don’t go along politically accountable.  Now more than ever, Democrats need to exist outside of Trump. They should articulate to the American people how they would use the same power Republicans are currently enjoying. Only then can they start convincing people to elect Republicans out of office and give that power to Democrats.  Some may argue that there is little Democrats can do while out of power in Washington D.C. However, this ignores the influence that state governments have to fight back against federal overreach. Furthermore, stating Democrats have little institutional power is not enough of a reason to resign all control to Republicans. With Trump’s approval rating dwindling, Democrats need to offer a platform that attracts those estranged Trump voters into their coalition.    Democrats need to use the next couple of years to reorganize and search for an identity. The majority of Americans know that things are bad. Rather than complaining and reiterating this point, it is important to explain how things would be different under Democratic control.  Bret Fulton is a sophomore political science major. You can reach him at bretfulton@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Don’t blame “Sephora Kids”
author: Bret Fulton
body: Some of the most innocent victims of social media beauty influencers are young kids. For those who don’t know, there have been trending videos all over various social media platforms of young kids rummaging through beauty store isles like Sephora and Ulta, typically in search of the latest products that have been trending.  The “Sephora kids” aren't just a short-lived internet meme but the beginning of a harmful trend. The kids being targeted by beauty influencers have no need to purchase a large amount of skincare products due to their young skin. However, beauty influencers on TikTok have tapped into a young consumer base that is waiting to seize the opportunity to buy the products regardless.  While introducing good skin hygiene habits for young kids can be beneficial, only appropriate products should be used. However, many dermatologists have reported an increase in cases in which anti-aging products such as retinol and vitamin C serums have caused adverse reactions.  This is not only harmful to the parent’s wallet funding their child's obsession with skincare, but it is also having harmful consequences on their skin. Parents should provide appropriate products and guidance for their child’s age that actually help build good habits rather than allowing them to fall victim to a harmful social media influence.  The role of the parent of a young child is to make decisions that are in that child’s best interest. Making the decision to purchase a product that will increase skin sensitivity — or in extreme cases, burn their child's skin — is irresponsible at best, and neglectful at worst.  Kids will only continue to be the target of consumerism. The resulting attitudes from this increase will negatively impact childhood development by introducing the insecurity of aging. Not only that, it drives kids to examine overall beauty standards, potentially internalizing harmful rhetorics around the body.  Many people have argued the opposite by saying that increased interest in skincare can build good hygiene habits for later in life and parents shouldn’t be criticized for spending their own money to make their kids happy.  The potential to build good hygiene habits later in life can only be true if young kids are using safe products. Using harmful products has the potential to push kids away from pursuing a routine in the first place. Parents should analyze the safety of their young child’s products before purchasing. While this is a personal parental decision, they do not have the right to harm their child with dangerous products.  We need to point blame at social media and parents for creating these “Sephora kids.” The feasibility of age restrictions in beauty stores following the “Sephora kid” trend should also be examined as it could possibly prevent kids from harming themselves with skincare products they do not need.  Bret Fulton is a freshman political science major. You can reach him at bretfulton@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Ending birthright citizenship is taking an eraser to the Constitution
author: Rose Woelm
body: The Constitution is starting to feel like a terms and conditions page: everyone is checking the box, but nobody is reading it.  President Donald Trump has introduced multiple executive orders during his presidency that have raised judges’ eyebrows, leading them to issue national injunctions against the administration for its seemingly unconstitutional orders. One of these orders, signed on day one of Trump’s second presidency, tried to put an end to birthright citizenship as we know it.  The order would end birthright citizenship for those born in the United States to parents who are undocumented or here on temporary visas. This would change the language and enforcement of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution. Currently, the amendment states that “All persons born or naturalized in the United States, and subject to the jurisdiction thereof” are citizens.  This means that even if someone is born to parents who are not legal citizens, the child is still a U.S. citizen with caveats for those who do not fall under the country’s jurisdiction (e.g., children of diplomatic representatives or those living under tribal sovereignty). The order to change this has been blocked by three district courts through national injunctions.  National junctions have been issued more often in recent decades. Some argue that they slow the progress of presidential administrations and that they create a politicized judicial system. While they can contribute to the intermingling of politics and judicial processes, arguing that they make things too slow is an underwhelming argument. They aren’t supposed to make things easier. Injunctions stop administrations in their tracks to prevent something illegal or unconstitutional, according to the judge’s discretion, from going into effect.  Despite the blocks, the Supreme Court of the United States has agreed to hear oral arguments from the administration on May 15, 2025. This is rare for the courts, as they typically only hear oral arguments between October and April.  The administration is expected to narrow the scope of the order, hoping for the policy to take effect in at least some, if not most, parts of the country while the court challenges unfold. If SCOTUS overrides the national injunctions and allows the enforcement of the Fourteenth Amendment to be changed, it could mean setting a legal precedent that presidents can change and dictate legal interpretation.  Changing the enforcement of an amendment would set a terrible precedent for this and any future administration’s endeavors. If the interpretation of this amendment can be changed, it would not take much to establish good reasoning as to why other amendments should be corrected. While logical fallacies like the slippery slope argument are always a copout, it is worth noting that this could provide the foundation for fundamental legal change in the country.  This change could happen without much public discourse. If SCOTUS rules that these injunctions only apply to the plaintiffs in individual cases, and the policy can take some level of effect, it could lay the foundation for judges to be stripped of their injunction power in the future.  National junctions aim to protect everyone who may be affected by a case, not just the people directly involved. Without these injunctions, people would have to sue individually for their right to birthright citizenship and make it to the higher courts. A group could sue together, or a state could sue on behalf of its residents, but the ruling would only apply to the residents or people involved in the case directly. However, to win a case, it has to be heard.  SCOTUS is petitioned for about 8,000 cases a year but only hears 80. It is far easier and faster for the president to swipe his pen than it is for all these cases to make it through the court system.  While the courts would be working through the overload of cases, the president could be making new changes to amendments and legal interpretations daily, theoretically. Yes, the orders might be scrutinized and people might sue, but again, the sentiment remains: it is much easier for a president to put pen to paper than it is for a citizen to work their way through the tedious and strenuous court system.  If a president can change the enforcement of Constitutional amendments like this one without going through typical legal channels, then executive orders become much more powerful.  Birthright citizenship is a test case. Regardless of your opinion on birthright citizenship, you should pray that SCOTUS doesn’t rule in the administration’s favor. This case will set a precedent for national injunctions and protections in place for Americans, and it might not be a good one.  Rose Woelm is a philosophy and journalism double major. Reach her at rosewoelm@dailynebraskan.com

title: OPINION: Give video games a chance
author: Elise St Clair
body: I was stuck in Lincoln over spring break, so I started playing video games on my boyfriend’s Xbox to pass the time. I had played Gran Turismo, Skylanders and Minecraft on the PlayStation as a kid, but after a multi-year hiatus, I found joy in video games again.  It wasn’t because the games had changed, but rather, I discovered games that meshed with my interests.  Whether you have a computer, gaming console or a mobile device, game developers create something for everyone. You can start gaming even if you don’t have a console designed specifically for video games.  Despite what you choose to play on, there is a never-ending supply of games to experience.  Video games are designed for a variety of audiences, so no matter what niche interests you might have, you will be able to find a game that aligns with your interests.  If you’re creative and enjoy the freedom to build, create and explore, a sandbox-style game might be a good fit. If you are looking for a challenge, a more exhilarating option is a survival game. If relaxation is the goal, a comfort-style game can be a great way to decompress.  Even if video games aren’t a major hobby, playing them could be a good break from work and school. Everyone needs an outlet to break up the monotony of everyday life and relax. While not all games are relaxing, video games have been proven effective in relieving stress.  Prioritizing mental health is important, especially for college students. Even on campus, some residence halls offer Nintendo Switches in specific study lounges for students to use. In University Suites, students can rent out controllers from the front desk in exchange for their NCard.  What really pushed me into my rejuvenated interest in video games was that many of the people close to me play them. I downloaded Clash Royale on my phone and played religiously for weeks because my best friend wanted me to play with her. I play multiplayer games with my boyfriend on his Xbox because they are a great way for us to spend time together and grow closer. My RA plans Mario Kart game nights as bonding activities. Video games truly allow you to connect with the people you love.  Like many people, I had a skewed view of video games due to my brother and my friends playing first-person shooter games. I pigeonholed myself into believing video games weren’t for me because I didn’t like those kinds of games. I much prefer puzzle games and games with storylines, but I didn’t know what I liked until I started playing video games again.Even though it seemed daunting, I’m glad I ventured out of my comfort zone because I have since found games that I really enjoy, and I have come to understand their value.  You don’t have to be an avid gamer to enjoy video games. I urge you to give video games a chance and try out a type of game you have never played before. Between arcade, sport, survival, role-playing games and more, there is no shortage of options at your disposal. You just might find joy in the occasional game like I did.  Elise St Clair is a freshman journalism and broadcasting double major. Reach her at elisestclair@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION:  Grading Trump’s first 100 days
author: Dawson Iasillo
body: The first 100 days of a presidency are often seen as a critical test of leadership, vision and competence. However, for Donald Trump, they revealed a presidency defined by chaos, broken promises and national division. To say these first 100 days have been exhausting, eventful and downright depressing is an understatement.  Trump's first 100 days in office were marked by legislative failures and chaotic executive actions. He demonstrated a troubling lack of effective leadership and undermined key democratic norms.  Trump’s approval rating has since declined from Jan. 20. He is now seeing disapproval from more than half of the country at 55%. Older Americans, white Americans and those with lower levels of education are more likely to back Trump, whereas younger, highly educated and nonwhite voters are more likely to disapprove of his job.  Plenty of Trump’s supporters have expressed their interest in Trump for economic purposes. However, his supporters are feeling the heaviness of the broken economy that Trump created.  The stock market has been shaken up quite a bit since Trump’s notorious tariff threats. Depending on the day, tariffs might be in place or they might not. Many are fearful of investing in anything and are quickly pulling away. It has been a roller coaster for the stock market.  For the days that tariffs are in place, they are driving up the prices of everything. After his 90-day tariff pause, Americans are preparing for the worst. A whopping 90% of Americans predict that tariffs will cause goods to get even more expensive than they already are.  Overall, Trump has had few policies for the economy and those he has endured haven’t been positive. Economists around the globe have criticized the president. Besides, electing a person who has filed for bankruptcy six times might not be the person to elect based on the economy.  Perhaps the most frightening (though there are several close seconds) could be Trump’s urge to pull out of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). While the U.S. has not backed out of the organization yet, Trump has expressed his interest in leaving the alliance. NATO protects the U.S. in more ways than one and it is absolutely necessary to be a part of.  Amongst this, Trump has explained how the U.S. needs to be self-sufficient, but this is simply unrealistic. Trump has forced America to back out of the World Health Organization, the United Nations Human Rights Council, the World Trade Organization and several others. This hurts nobody but the American people. With this, there are no regulations, boundaries or standards that will hold America to a high standard.    As many promises that Trump has broken, one that he has been sure to uphold is his immigration policies. Trump has deported several Americans without due process and simply based on assumptions. Trump’s immigration policies are more than depressing.  One of the deportations that is most notable is the four-year-old child with stage four cancer who was sent out of the country with no access to the cancer medication needed.  With that being said, Trump’s domestic policies align very heavily with Project 2025, which he has denied on several occasions.  In the healthcare field, he has rolled back parts of the Affordable Care Act, cut limits on drug pricings, removed the concept of gender affirming care and ended federal funding that went toward the right to a women’s choice.  It may be that the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) is the elephant in the room. DOGE has cut over 270,000 jobs across the nation. The national parks are in severe jeopardy from DOGE cuts and several funding cuts have been made to the National Park Service. Other services such as Social Security, healthcare grants, National Institutes of Health (NIH) funding and several more have seen the wrath of DOGE. Despite all of this, DOGE is not actually saving the government any money.  Several other random orders that have been put into place include dismantling the Department of Education, bans on climate change actions, making English the official language and more.  Many appreciate Trump’s forcefulness. However, records show that this behavior does not go over well in other countries or domestically. Trump has accomplished a lot in his first 100 days, including gaining the title of being the president with the lowest approval rating in more than 80 years.  Trump's first 100 days have fallen far short of the promises he made to the American people. Instead of ushering in a new era of effective governance, he has continued the division from his first term. If these early days are any indication, the challenges ahead may not come just from the forces opposing him, but from his own inability to lead. Our country has a long four years ahead of us.  Dawson Iasillo is a sophomore political science and journalism double major. Reach her at dawsoniasillo@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: ‘How I Met Your Mother’ deserved a better ending
author: Jocelynn Messersmith
body: When I was nine years old my parents would lay in their bedroom and play reruns of the sitcom, “How I Met Your Mother.” I would sit in and watch segments of the mature show laughing at jokes I didn’t even understand, but were clearly funny to adults.  “How I Met Your Mother” is a sitcom that ran for nine years offering viewers nine seasons filled with laughter and heartbreak as a father named Ted, shares with his kids the story of how he met their mom through a series of flashbacks recounting the journey with his four best friends.  In my free time, which was all the time, I would run to the living room and binge episodes on Netflix starting from the pilot. I must have watched the whole series, all nine seasons, over 20 times. This is not an exaggeration as I can still to this day quote every episode almost word for word. Although this sitcom tops any other TV show I have seen, I refuse to accept the ending.  The show came to an end after each character had significant development. Barney and Robin spent the whole last season on their wedding just to get a divorce the next episode. This isn’t the only bombshell dropped in the last episode as we find out that Barney had a child many years after the divorce. Although I wished the upset ended there, the writers also surprised us with the fact that the mother is dead and Ted ends up with Robin.  How I Met Your Mother is the greatest television series of all time but deserved a much better ending than the writers provided us with.  I strongly believe that Barney and Robin were meant to be together. The entire last season revolves around their wedding as we see them travel to their venue in the last episode of season eight. They both spent parts of the season freaking out over the wedding, but in the end realized that their love for each other was a much stronger emotion than their fears of settling.  The two characters also share various amounts of similarities that demonstrate a strong compatibility. They both have a Canadian background, commitment issues, play big pranks, are independent and grew a lot throughout the series. They always had each other’s backs and had so much chemistry during the show.  On the opposite side, Ted and Robin had a very forced relationship that made it awkward to watch. Other than the fact that he said, “I think I’m in love with you” on the first date, the two worked better as friends. Their friendship was evident in their inside joke based on saluting to words like “major” and “private.”  They consulted each other on relationships, lived together when they were purely platonic and Ted was Robin’s honorary Best Man. Ted overstepped many times by kissing Robin moments after she broke up with her ex boyfriend and trying to teach Barney how to be in a relationship with Robin. Most importantly, Ted and Robin didn’t have the same feelings about kids as he wanted two kids and she didn’t want any. This is a clear sign that they weren’t meant for each other.  Barney’s ending was one of the worst parts of the finale as he goes straight back to his old life after getting a divorce from Robin. He made a lot of progress throughout the show so it was disappointing to see that the writers threw away the character development. Barney ends up having a baby with a random stranger and this supposedly changes his life.  I would have liked to see him have more development as a father to show that he has truly changed, but we only get the one scene with the baby in the hospital. How are we to know that he didn’t ditch the family at some point? In season four Barney had already been intimate with 200 women meaning that by the end of the show it would have been close to 400. To only have one child after nine years seems completely random and forced.  Some people strongly believe that Ted and Robin were clearly meant to end up together as they always had a bond. Ted cheered her up when she was alone on Christmas and would do practically anything to make Robin happy. The fact is that Robin never demonstrated this kind of love for Ted as she struggled to tell him that she loved him. I admit that the couple was good in season one and two, but beyond that they were completely different and wanted opposite things in life.  “How I Met Your Mother” will still always be my favorite show despite the disappointing ending. As a fanbase let’s accept our own ending where Barney and Robin end up together living happily ever after. The death of the mother is upsetting but could be considered a good element to the conclusion of the story that I can stand behind. With these small changes the finale could have been legen-wait for it-DARY.  Jocelynn Messersmith is a journalism and broadcasting double major. You can reach her at jocelynnmessersmith@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Immigrants are not just numbers
author: Dawson Iasillo
body: Eleven million people came into this country for a better tomorrow. 11 million people took the leap of faith to go to an unknown country for themselves and their families. 11 million is the number of illegal immigrants that some Americans are worried about.  With President Donald Trump’s ongoing mass deportations, 11 million people now sit scared in a country that was supposed to bring them freedom and a new lust for life. After Trump’s inauguration, there have been over 2,500 arrests for his mass deportation plan.  Immigrants are more than just a number. Each immigrant has a family, a friend, a job, something they are looking forward to and a reason to be in America.  Roberto Oran is the middle child of an impoverished family in Mexico. After his mom became ill due to birth complications from Oran’s birth, they had to sell their house and land to be able to afford her medical expenses. He continued to go to a strict Catholic school while living with his grandmother and graduated from ninth grade.    No schooling was available after, leading him to pick up watercolor art. He realized there was not much of a future in Mexico with his aspiring art career and knew the great opportunities America offered.  His Mexican-American uncle who lived in the U.S. encouraged him to cross the border. Oran’s art started winning prizes and it inspired him to continue his education. He attended Chemeteka Community College and graduated with his associate's degree in 2016. Oran worked for an organization called Pineros y Campesinos Unidos del Noroeste which amplifies marginalized workers in art. Oran is one of many who found his success in the hands of America.  Heriberto Bolonas was only 6 years old when he and his family fled Mexico. After a long and tedious journey to America, they landed in Oregon. Bolonas worked hard and tested out of the English as a Second Language (ESL) program in fourth grade.  However, Bolonas got into trouble throughout middle school and even wound up in a gang. After recognizing where his path was headed, he left the gang to better himself.  During his senior year, Bolonas worked for the Bring Them Home campaign which advocated for 250 asylum seekers to come across the border. He quickly worked his way up to a leadership position at the campaign. From there he organized one of the most successful walkouts, the Forest Grove Walkout, which led to several ethnic bills being approved in Oregon. Bolonas paid his way through college and is currently studying history and minoring in law with hopes of returning back to teach at his former high school.  Francisco Bautista found his wife Laura in the same village where he grew up in Mexico. It had always been their dream to move to the U.S. one day and grow their weaving business. They also knew women had more rights than they did in their village of Teotitlán del Valle.  Together they arrived in the U.S. On their first night together they reflected on the snowfall out their window, excited that they would experience something as simple as the four seasons unfolding. They went on to have their own weaving business in the United States, like they had always dreamed of, and have two children, both of which are successful artists now. Francisco describes their journey to America as “destiny.”  No matter how extravagant or simple these people’s testimonies are, they have stories just like me and you. To outcast immigrants and support politicians who are consciously horrifying these individuals is inhumane. The numbers often disguise these personal stories, but they’re not to be overlooked amid these new laws.  Many argue that these immigrants are criminals and bad people. At the end of the day, they are just people. There is no reason to invalidate humanity because a person does not look or think the way someone else does. Immigrants are just as human as anyone who filled out the right forms or was born on American soil.  Each of these people has friends, coworkers, family members, and dreams they aspire to accomplish themselves. America is supposed to be the place where anything is possible for anyone, and it is nothing short of insufferable watching it limit its capabilities to cater to those the government favors.  Dawson Iasillo is a sophomore political science and journalism major. Reach her at dawsoniasillo@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: It’s okay to cry
author: Jocelynn Messersmith
body: After working a nine hour shift all I wanted to do was go home and eat my dinner. I had been dreaming of eating a rice bowl all day when suddenly I went to place an order and the restaurant was closed. Immediately I started bawling my eyes out. It seems silly to cry over something so small and embarrassing that I was crying over food. So, why do people cry and should we prevent this emotion?  There are several reasons why someone may cry. Gender and culture actually play a role in how often a person sheds a tear. Women cry an average of 5.3 times a month whereas men only cry an average of 1.3 times per month. This stark difference is due to testosterone levels that may inhibit crying while women have higher levels of the hormone prolactin that promotes crying. In countries with greater freedom of expression such as Chile or the U.S., men and women cry more.  But, is crying bad? As infants it is the most important communication tool to show they need help. As adults tears serve as a more therapeutic role.  Although crying is often seen as a negative emotion, being able to express it demonstrates strength and relieves stress. The soothing effects of crying help to reduce pain and overall better an individual.  Crying is a natural response to different emotions that can benefit our health. Keeping feelings inside can become difficult and negatively affect health.  Studies show that repressive coping can cause a less resilient immune system, higher chance of cardiovascular disease and increase mental health conditions such as stress, anxiety and depression. Emotional tears contain more stress hormones. These tears serve a therapeutic role known as a good cry. Emotional crying makes people feel better. It is a good part of the healing process.  Shedding tears can act as a self-soothing mechanism. Individuals are able to release pent up emotions which leads to a sense of relief and emotional balance. Researchers have found that crying activates the parasympathetic nervous system. This helps the body rest and digest.  Crying may support the body and the mind by releasing the stress hormone cortisol and the mood-regulating hormone oxytocin. Sometimes we have to let our emotions flow to calm down and reevaluate our situation.  While crying has numerous emotional benefits, tears can also help to reduce pain. They dampen our fight or flight responses, helping us catch our breath and be able to relax. Since our emotions and pain get wrapped together the action of crying helps to alleviate the physical pain. Sometimes we focus so much on our tears that we forget the injury all together.  The level of control we have over our pain management is called gate control theory. This is the idea that our mental state can influence our perception of pain.  Still people believe that crying is a sign of weakness. From a young age many men are taught that they shouldn’t cry or talk about their emotions. This idea is a major obstacle for future relationships and self-esteem. Everyone should be able to express their emotions even when it means tearing up because it is natural. There should be no shame in walking out of a room with puffy red eyes. It shows that someone is strong and cares deeply.  At the end of the day no one wants to cry, but we have to get over the idea that crying is for weak people. Showing an emotion like crying helps us love harder. Sometimes to feel better we have to let out a few tears and remember that it’s okay to cry.

title: OPINION: Learning to fail in college is an important lesson
author: Hannah Nazarenus
body: Many college students know the feeling of studying for an exam or project only to fall short. In that moment the failure can feel devastating. However, the life lessons from these setbacks can be some of the most profound lessons learned.  College is often seen as a time to learn and become successful, yet many students experience obstacles along the way.  From failing a class to not getting an internship, or even struggling with personal issues, failure can feel very overwhelming. Nevertheless, these experiences can help teach resilience, self-reflection and empathy which are essential life lessons that lead to long-term success.  Resilience is one of the most valuable life skills, as it empowers students to push forward even in the face of adversity.  Resilience is a skill developed through often uncomfortable hardship. Students must learn to persist and adapt, even when things don't go as planned.  This resilience is essential for students' future careers and personal lives helping them to adapt and overcome rather than giving up. Students who build resilience in college are better prepared to handle future challenges and are also more likely to have greater mental well-being.  Failure can also promote self-reflection which encourages students to reassess their approaches to different problems.  Self-reflection can allow students to look at what went wrong and how they could have done things differently. Through this self-reflection, students can better understand their strengths and weaknesses, which can help them gain valuable insights into what abilities they possess and which ones they still need to grow. This self-assessment can be a powerful tool that encourages lifelong learning and growth, which can help students make better-informed decisions in the future.  Additionally, failure can also create a sense of empathy and humility, two qualities that are very important in both personal and professional relationships.  By experiencing failure firsthand, students are able to develop a greater sense of compassion for others' struggles. This can help them build stronger connections and collaborate more effectively in teams.  This humility can also help students be open to feedback without being held back from improvement by their pride. Humility and empathy help lay the groundwork for strong personal relationships and effective leadership.  Some may argue that failure can discourage students, especially in environments where grades and success are often equated with their self-worth. For some students, challenges can impact their mental health and their future performance. While it's true that failure can frequently feel overwhelming, colleges should emphasize the importance of resilience and provide mental health resources for struggling students. Through these resources, students can grow positively from these experiences.  While failing is never ideal, college provides a valuable environment to learn from these setbacks. Learning to fail teaches qualities that are essential for future growth such as resilience and humility. In a world that demands perfection it can be difficult for students to take a step back and realize that these failures are not the end of the world, but rather steps towards a more successful future.  Hannah Nazarenus is a junior journalism and advertising and public relations double major. Reach her at hannahnazarenus@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Level up with video games
author: Jocelynn Messersmith
body: Growing up my siblings and I would crowd around the gaming consoles in our living room. We logged in according to birth order, meaning I was always the last player as the youngest. From New Super Mario Bros on the Nintendo Wii to Minecraft on the PlayStation 3, we have continually obsessed over video games. Even at night we would lay in our rooms playing on the Nintendo DS sneaking it under our pillows whenever our parents walked in.  Today, video games are a billion dollar industry with nearly two-thirds of American households playing games regularly. They originally got their start in research labs, but are now often at the forefront of computer technology.  Video games have many benefits as they strengthen friendships through shared experiences that create lasting memories and increase hand-eye coordination which improves cognitive skills. The supportive communities that are built from video games create a sense of security for many gamers.  Many people start playing certain video games due to their friends. Games are influential on relationships as 77% of boys play online video games with friends at least once a month. Shared experiences can be beneficial at helping people connect and work together to complete goals, similarly to how a sports team works.  About nine-tenths of teen video game players say they play with other people and 47% boast about friendships they have made specifically from playing video games. While it may seem silly, games help people learn to work with others and offer a chance to socialize without having to be in person.  Although I don’t live with my brother anymore, we always find time to play Fortnite together which keeps us close. It feels like I see him everyday because I am constantly interacting with him and staying updated on his life. Video games are a fun way to relax and  talk to those around you, strengthening friendships along the way.  Another positive aspect of video games is an increase in hand-eye coordination and other skills. Games require precise movements and fast reflexes helping the development of accurate hand-eye coordination.  Video games also help gamers with organization skills, whether it’s arranging chests, strategizing, memorization or all of the above. Defeating a boss or remembering a pattern takes a lot of practice.  A research study concluded that children who reported playing video games for three or more hours per day were faster and more accurate on both cognitive tasks than those who never played. These children who played games also had higher brain activity in regions of the brain associated with attention and memory than others.  Gaming communities also help build social connections around fans of a certain game, but more than that, these communities foster a safe place for players to connect and promote positive mental health.  The Stack Up Overwatch Program has specifically studied the benefits of the online gaming community in addressing the mental health crisis. Fans sometimes feel such a connection to other players of a game that they feel safe and vulnerable with those around them.  Communities can help fans feel safe, but in return fans help creators by actively engaging in their content. This helps developers get an understanding of what players want to see in a game which can decide updates and new features. An example of this would be the mob vote that Minecraft developers do each year at Minecon, an annual Minecraft convention where players and developers around the world gather. This live vote gives the creators an idea of what fans want to see added in their game.  There is a stigma that video games cause violence. People believe that violent games dealing with physical assault and other brutal aspects cause aggression in gamers, especially young teens. This is a common misconception because video games have proven to have no correlation with violent behaviors and aggression. Playing a fighting game will not make people more aggressive.  Video games are more than just a distraction for kids. They offer improvements to hand-eye coordination and give people an opportunity to build an online community. More than that, video games allow us to bond with our friends creating lasting memories over online experiences.  Jocelynn Messersmith is a freshman journalism and broadcasting double major. You can reach her at jocelynnmessersmith@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Mental health needs to be taken more seriously
author: Dawson Iasillo
body: October is widely recognized as mental health awareness month and serves to educate others about what mental health means.  Recent generations have started to recognize what it means to have mental health issues. However, there is still a lack of intensity when it comes to handling the mental health emergency. As of now, America is considered to be in a mental health crisis.  Mental health first became recognized in the 1990s. Before then, the words depression and anxiety seemed somewhat foreign. Now, many brush off the idea of mental health and are stubborn to the fact that mental health problems are on the rise.  1 in 5 adults in America suffer from mental health. Regardless of this outlandish number, the seriousness of mental health is thrown out. It seems to be an afterthought and overshadowed by everything else that life throws. This leaves millions of people suffering in what feels like a battle they are facing alone. Mental health is the culprit for many things in society, yet it is still taken with a grain of salt despite its weighing effects on overall well-being and quality of life.    Not only does mental health consume the entire livelihood of an individual, but it also affects physical health as well. When induced anxiety, stress or depression occur, physical conditions come into play. Negative mental health has been proven to be a contributor to serious conditions such as diabetes, a higher risk of strokes and heart disease.  Physical health is recognized as an urgent issue while mental health is overlooked. People fail to realize that physical and mental health go hand-in-hand. Without mental health being treated properly, it turns into a substantial physical health issue.  People who struggle with mental health often take to unhealthy coping mechanisms. Those who suffer from depression and anxiety may turn to substance abuse, which can cause lifelong health deterioration. Mental health must be well-maintained and taken seriously in order to ensure total health of the body.  Mental health is a big enough struggle in itself. Finding the right mental health outlet is an even harder mountain to climb. Many therapists are insanely expensive, and very few insurance companies see mental health as a medical issue.  Being accepted to be a therapist’s client is another uphill battle. In America, there is a significant shortage of therapists. In turn, therapists have a lack of funding causing this absence of help.  Medication for mental health problems also can be extremely difficult to obtain. Due to how long mental health problems take to diagnose, they often go untreated.  Mental health has an overall lack of acknowledgement. Many are not aware of the physical effects it can have on an individual. The understanding of mental health diagnosis and how it affects everything about the individual is difficult to comprehend if not aware of it.  The negative stigma around mental health has been around for decades, and it hasn’t died down. People often jump to conclusions and place stereotypes on those who struggle with mental health issues.  People are referred to as “crazy” simply because of the internal battles in their heads. Therefore, many push down those feelings and downplay their issues. Many choose not to look further into their mental health hardships because of judgment from others. The general public does not have a complete understanding of the commonality  of mental health.  With the recent talk of mental health issues, people often miscategorize normal emotions as mental health problems. There is a clear difference between sadness and debilitating depression but, with the new awareness of mental health in society, some describe depression as a feeling rather than an illness.  However, if emotions are not handled properly, it is easy for them to snowball into a mental health issue. Without mental health being taken seriously, those normal emotions that everyone feels turns into something it never had to.  The lack of mental health support continues to be a critical issue. Mental health issues seep into the cracks of all parts of society. Without it being taken seriously, and with mental health problems on the rise, the cracks will begin to widen if action isn’t taken.  Dawson Iasillo is a political science and journalism double major. Reach her at dawsoniasillo@dailynebraskan.com

title: OPINION: Music is the Key to Our Lives
author: Jocelynn Messersmith
body: Everyday students at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln wake up and start their morning routine by brushing their teeth, picking out an outfit and making their way to class. Whether they are walking or driving there seems to be one similarity: everyone listens to music.  Headphones and AirPods have infected our morning routines giving us a more exciting journey to class each day. From current pop stars such as Sabrina Carpenter or Taylor Swift to rap artists like Kendrick Lamar, college students start their days in such a similar but different way.  From ancient Greece where it was believed that music could develop the mind and soul to the Renaissance and Baroque period where music became sophisticated, music has been around for centuries and interpreted many different ways.  Music is tied to historical events such as the civil rights movement with songs such as “We Shall Overcome.” Today, music is filled with innovation and diversity.  While music is now viewed more as a form of entertainment, there are many aspects of music that people tend to overlook. Music is a plague, but instead of spreading disease it spreads many benefits that improve overall health. Music is much more than a simple song as it also holds memories.  Songs often remind people of the past and spark familiar memories when a recognizable rhythm plays. Studies show that music has a unique capacity to evoke both strong emotions and vivid autobiographical memories. This is an experience called music-evoked autobiographical memory and it is a common experience.  “In My Life” reminds me of my grandmother’s funeral and “Ophelia” reminds me of learning to drive for the first time. We correlate songs to important parts of our lives. Even with smaller events in our lives, songs can remind us of the past. For example, “Shape of You” by Ed Sheeran reminds me of sitting in my parents’ car with my sister blasting the music back and forth. It’s a simple silly thing, but these songs hold memories and parts of our pasts.  While listening to music is great for studying and strengthening relationships, music education has a vast amount of benefits alone. Even from a young age children can start gaining the benefits that music education holds. The process of learning and playing an instrument increases brain power and functionality which results in a boosted IQ and improved concentration. This accelerates brain development in kids and helps with sensory development. In the long term, music keeps our minds sharp and reduces the chance of developing Alzheimer’s and dementia.  People who study music often perform better in school. On average they achieve better grades and are 24% more likely to graduate high school. Making music helps students learn many skills including confidence, independence, perseverance, leadership and personal responsibility which sets them up for lifetime success.  Music is good for the mind as it reduces stress and improves well-being. Music is a powerful outlet that can regulate our emotions. While upbeat songs can make us more alert and focused, slower tempos can relax our muscles, quieting our minds and relieving stress from the day.  After a long stressful day it can be peaceful to lie down and put on a slow song to relax. Studies also show that listening to music can reduce cortisollevels, our hormone tied to stress.  Other than stress, music benefits our mental health. It evokes emotion as it connects to us which can improve our mood. After a long day it can be easy to let the emotions of hard work wash over us, but if we instead put on some music it can actually soothe our minds.  Parents sometimes worry that there is a harmful side to music. It is proven to evoke our emotions, but what happens when a person is feeling upset and listens to music that evokes their thoughts? When a person dwells on these feelings it can contribute to depression and anxiety which can be especially harmful to teens. It is important to understand the effects of music to make sure that we avoid these negative effects.  Music is much more than a simple song or melody. It allows the listener to follow a story and create lasting memories while also offering mental health benefits that improve well-being. Music cultivates bonds and offers educational benefits demonstrating its importance in our lives. As William Shakespeare once said, “If music be the food of love, play on.”  Jocelynn Messersmith is a freshman journalism and broadcasting double major. You can reach her at jocelynnmessersmith@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: My top five sport cities in America
author: Michael Tatten
body: Debates often happen in all aspects of life, but sports debates can be among the most heated. One of the most controversial sports debates is between entire cities. The debate centers on which of these cities deserves the title of the best sports city in America.  Fans will argue that the history of the city and championships means the most. Others argue that pride and passion take the cake. Some say the city's atmosphere on gamedays proves to be the most important aspect. All of these factors have a say in determining which cities are the best.  Here are my top five sports cities in America, starting with number five:  5. Las Vegas:  Las Vegas is in my top five sports cities, which may come as a shock to many, because not long ago Las Vegas wasn't even on the sports map. Las Vegas was a hub for casinos, concerts and prize fights, rather than being a hub for professional sports. Las Vegas is still home to all of those things that earned the city its nickname “Sin City,” but now Las Vegas is a hub for professional sports. Las Vegas is the home of the Raiders, Aces, Golden Knights, the UFC, NBA Summer League, boxing’s biggest events and will soon be home of the A’s. Las Vegas residents have embraced these new teams and have shown top-tier pride and passion for the city.  4. Philadelphia:  There are a few cities in America that embody their sports teams like Philadelphia does. Philadelphia fans are known as some of the harshest fans in sports. Philadelphia fans will tell you it's just passion for their city, while others will tell you it's classless fan behavior. However, there is no denying Philadelphia fans' loyalty to the city. The Eagles have had a lot of success recently, as they were last year's Super Bowl champions. The Phillies, Flyers and 76ers all have deep-rooted history in their respective leagues. These Philadelphia sports teams are all woven into the identity of the city of Philadelphia.  3. New York City:  There isn't much argument for this city’s spot on this list. New York City has so much history when it comes to sports. It is a city that has two professional teams in nearly every major league. A lot of the teams that play in the New York City area are in the upper echelon of the most valuable sports teams as well. The New York City fans are also iconic for their passion for their teams, whether that's in a good light or not. The Yankees and Knicks are two of the most iconic, not only teams but brands in the world. The Mets, Jets, Nets, Giants, Rangers and Islanders give the people of New York City multiple other choices for teams to root for. New York City’s deep-rooted history is reflected in its sports culture, with legendary teams and iconic rivalries that have defined generations of sport.  2. Los Angeles:  No city has more star power than Los Angeles. The Lakers and Clippers are headlined by some of the biggest stars in the NBA, backed by ownership groups who are willing to spend to win. This isn't just the basketball teams. The Dodgers may be the biggest example of spending to win. Their star-studded lineup keeps the Dodgers in constant contention. The Rams and Chargers both returned to LA within the last decade and are both competitive teams for the Super Bowl. A lot of the Los Angeles teams right now are contenders for their league's respective championship. There is a deep history of sports in LA, with many of its teams being multiple-time championship winners. LA is also the home to many of the biggest sporting events that occur and that will continue as LA is set to host the 2028 Olympics. Los Angeles is one of the best sports cities in America, but it doesn't lie atop the list.  1. Boston:  In the number one spot on this list, I have Boston. Boston is home to the Celtics, Red Sox, Bruins and New England Patriots. The Celtics are the most successful basketball team in the history of the NBA. They have the richest history in the league as well. The Red Sox are one of the most noticeable brands in the world. There is a history that runs deep with this city and its franchises. The Patriots have been the most winning team in football in the 21st century and have solidified their place as one of the best franchises in all of sports. The fans of Boston show a lot of passion and pride for their teams. The expectation for Boston sports teams is to be a consistent contender. The history and constant winning are why Boston is atop this list.  sports@dailynebraskan.com

title: OPINION: Nature deserves rights
author: Elise St Clair
body: Nature is often viewed as property for humans to treat however we see fit. It’s time to change this narrative.  The idea that nature deserves basic rights to not only exist, but thrive, is known as the Rights of Nature. The movement is grounded in the perspective that humans share the Earth with nature, and it has just as much of a right to flourish as we do. Considering everything humans gain from nature, the environment deserves our advocacy and legal protection in return.  While extending rights to natural entities appears absurd, this is a common practice. Corporations have been granted many of the same rights that individuals have for centuries. The Congressional Research Service reported in 2013 that corporations are protected by certain provisions of the First, Fourth, Fifth, Sixth and Eighth amendments, even though corporations are not people, nor are they mentioned in the U.S. Constitution.  Under these amendments, corporations have the right to free speech, protection against unreasonable searches and seizures, due process, protection against double jeopardy, the rights to counsel, jury trial, speedy trial, to confront accusers, to subpoena witnesses and protection against excessive fines.  If corporations can be considered people in legal circumstances, nature should too. Just as a human representative for a corporation can stand in a courtroom as a spokesperson of a company, natural entities like rivers and forests should be afforded the right to a legal guardian to defend their rights.  Some places around the world have successfully granted nature such rights already. In 2006, a borough of 7,000 people in Tamaqua, Pennsylvania granted personhood to an ecosystem through the Tamaqua Borough Sewage Sludge Ordinance.  This ordinance allows a person to act as a legal guardian of a damaged ecosystem for legal purposes and use any money they receive through the judicial process to restore the ecosystem in question. These rights are only extended on a case-by-case basis when they should be established federally.  Similarly, in 2013, New Zealand gave the Te Urewera National Park legal personhood. The New Zealand government relinquished its control over the park and established a board of people to act as guardians over the park. This board is responsible for protecting the interests of Te Urewera as an entity with intrinsic value, and all decisions made regarding the land must be in the best interest of the land’s ecological systems and inhabitants.  Despite its relevance to the planet and human livelihood, nature cannot defend itself. Still, our laws affect the environment and its ability to thrive. Humans share the Earth with all of the planet’s inhabitants, and it’s time we stop pretending that we are the only species that matters.  As the primary contributor to climate change, and the only species on Earth with the power and influence to reverse its effects, it is our responsibility to advocate on nature’s behalf. It is time we give nature the respect it deserves in return for its beauty and resources that we selfishly take for granted.  Because nature is not human, some might argue that we have no place personifying nature. But giving nature rights does not mean personifying nature, it simply means considering natural arguments in judicial proceedings alongside human arguments.  Extending stewardship to the environment means giving a voice to the pollinators, rivers, plants and animals that live alongside us, especially when that means representing nature’s interests in a court of law.  Typically, environmental legislation passes when an environmental issue hurts people. The Clean Air and Clean Water Acts, some of the most well-known and influential federal environmental laws, are prime examples of this trend, but human involvement should not be a factor. We should be able to pass environmental legislation for the sole benefit of nature and its right to flourish.  Nature deserves that right.  Elise St Clair is a freshman journalism and broadcasting double major. Reach her at elisestclair@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Nebraska faces “brain drain’ because it lacks opportunity
author: Bret Fulton
body: Nebraska had a chronic loss of talent over the previous decade. The coined term “brain drain” was born out of students fleeing the state due to the lack of support from universities and post-graduate opportunities. As state leaders continue to scratch their heads and wonder why this mass exodus is happening, many Nebraska students already know they need to go out of state to further their educational and career goals.  While UNL’s enrollment increased this academic year for the first time since 2017, the other two universities in the NU system, University of Nebraska Omaha and University of Nebraska at Kearney, saw an enrollment drop. Therefore, the recent trend at UNL is not reflective of the entire state. Statewide, the rate of fleeing residents holding a bachelor’s degree or more has increased significantly since 2017 and continues to this day.  UNL increased investment in campus resources and is likely the cause of the upward trend in enrollment, retention and degree completion. Investments in universities for the purpose of improving those three metrics cannot center on scholarships and grants alone. Instead, other Nebraska universities should replicate UNL’s investment in student support programs such as the Center for Academic Success and Transition (CAST), financial well-being ambassadors and the Military and Veteran Success Center just to name a few.  When students feel supported academically, financially and emotionally, they are more likely to continue their degree paths and stay at UNL for all four years. It is not by pure coincidence that increasing student support also increases the three major metrics to measure a university’s success.  State leaders should take UNL’s model and build on the already existing statewide one. Nebraska has various scholarship programs including the Nebraska Opportunity Grant which offers scholarship grants based on financial need.  Simply offering scholarship money can only go so far, though. Throwing money to scholarships at universities can be useful to get students’ feet in the door. However, if Nebraska continues to refuse to invest in student support programs, like career development and mental health resources, they can expect to see retention and completion rates continue to fall at some in-state universities.  If the state takes those steps, graduates of Nebraska high schools will be more likely to choose a Nebraska University. However, this still does not ensure students won’t leave the state upon degree completion. Many previous graduates of UNL explain that there is simply a lack of opportunity in the state.  Nebraska needs to concentrate on attracting new industry from around the country. That new opportunity cannot be concentrated in just Lincoln and Omaha. Distributing opportunity across the central and western portions of the state is important as well, which was the subject of the Rural Projects Act. This act matched funds to non-profit economic development organizations. The opportunities should not include just jobs and opportunities, but housing to hold those new workers too.    The Nebraska Legislature addressed this housing concern in 2023 and resulted in the allocation of  $40 million toward a rural housing construction initiative. However, in May of that same year, Gov. Jim Pillen line item vetoed the fund allocation. After his veto, he continued to question why people continue to leave the state.  Sending money to scholarship programs will not be the end all be all solution to prevent college educated adults from leaving. Many students may simply want to leave the state they grew up in. However, UNL’s investments prove that increasing opportunity and support can at least retain students for the time they are attending the university.
