Clearly, the state should build on UNL’s model of success for other state universities as well as post-graduate opportunities.  If state leaders want to keep students in Nebraska, they need to give them a reason to. Instead, students have faced a state that constantly turns its back on their needs.  Bret Fulton is a sophomore political science major. You can reach him at bretfulton@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Not all influencers are ethical
author: Hannah Nazarenus
body: Have you ever found yourself purchasing a product solely because your favorite influencer endorsed it? Sometimes this product may not live up to the hype, and consumers feel betrayed by the people they trust. Social media influencers shape consumer behavior through their perceived authenticity, and many times this influence can lead to the exploitation of their audiences.  The rise of social media platforms like Instagram and TikTok gave birth to a new form of marketing: influencer marketing. Influencers collaborate with brands to promote products and services, with their endorsements often feeling more personal and trustworthy. Because of this, consumers rely heavily on influencers’ recommendations.  Influencers’ authenticity and relatability make their endorsements highly persuasive, which directly impacts consumer purchasing decisions. They will often showcase their products in a casual everyday setting making their advertisements feel more like recommendations, instead of brands trying to sell an item.  A recent study found that 74% of people have purchased a product because an influencer recommended it. Consumers feel an emotional connection to influencers, which makes their endorsements feel personal.  The parasocial relationships created between the influencer and consumer can blur the line between genuine recommendations and paid advertisements. Consumers may believe that influencers are giving unbiased, unpaid reviews for products when they don't disclose that it is an advertisement. Because consumers are more likely to trust these influencers, companies can use this to their advantage and only have an influencer market for them. This lack of transparency in influencer marketing is unethical and could have major implications.  One of those being that influencers can more easily exploit their audiences by promoting products or services that may be ineffective or even harmful. By doing this they prioritize their personal gain over the well-being of their followers.  Some may promote unregulated supplements or financial schemes, all under the guise of helping their followers. Even ones who don't purposefully market bad products can still affect consumers.  Two studies show that children increased their intake of junk food when they were exposed to influencers marketing unhealthy food. Influencers have a direct impact on consumers of all ages on a daily basis, whether good or bad.  While there have been instances of exploitation, many influencers strive to maintain trust by promoting products they genuinely believe in and being transparent about sponsorships. They clearly label sponsored content and know that their platform is built on the relationship and trust they have with their audience. Still, it is always important for consumers to look at all influencers and advertisements, even ones they trust, with a skeptical eye.  As influencer marketing continues to grow, it is crucial for both influencers and consumers to be aware of the implications involved. Influencers should prioritize transparency and the well-being of their audiences, and consumers should approach endorsements with a critical eye. Influencer marketing isn't going away anytime soon, but realizing the influence it has on consumers' lives can help evolve it into a more trustworthy and beneficial part of our lives.  Hannah Nazarenus is a junior journalism and ADPR double major. Reach her at hannahnazarenus@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Palestine protests expose UNL’s free speech problem
author: Bret Fulton
body: The Justice for Palestine demonstration that took place at UNL’s Union Plaza on Wednesday, May 1, brought in students, faculty and community members. The Nebraska Union has been the site of countless demonstrations over the years, however, Wednesday’s events illustrate UNL’s restrictive free speech and protest policies.  Across the country, regulations by government entities are allowed to implement content neutral regulations concerning the time, manner and place of demonstrations. Considering the university environment, UNL is allowed to take these regulations further to respect the university's educational mission.  As a result, designated protest zones were enacted and maps are available to the public. The designated zone on the city campus does not extend past the fountain and, as a result, the space is restricting to protestors and should be reformed.  Possible reforms to the map could include expanding the designated protest zone past the fountain and into the Meier Commons. This would include the entire grass field behind the union fountain.  The Meier Commons is a very commonly used space for students and RSOs due to its placement and classification as a limited public forum. Expansion of the designated public forum will be less restrictive on the size and placement of student demonstrations and will also increase campus safety. Demonstrations will be less congested and enough space would be available to separate opposing counter protests to further maintain safety.  Questions arise of the university’s commitment to allow public demonstrations when the policies regarding designated public forums are so restrictive. It seems like an intentional policy choice that the largest public forum at UNL is on the lesser populated East Campus.  A tiny strip of concrete on UNL’s most populous campus has a major impact on the size and place of demonstrations. Protests organized by UNL students may also be too large to allow for any meaningful public involvement outside of the university. Therefore, expanding the zone will help UNL live up to its commitment on encouraging meaningful and safe public demonstrations.  The university has already made improvements on its free speech policies after being sanctioned by the American Association of University Professors. The sanction came after UNL fired a professor for making a lewd gesture to a student Turning Point USA recruiter. Administration responded by complying with guidelines to have adjunctive hearings prior to disciplinary action as well as implementing a controversial free speech policy.  While improvements to some may be deterioration to others, UNL has undoubtedly responded to faculty and student concerns in the past regarding speech. However, our campus cannot claim that free expression is good when a glaring restriction on free speech and student safety is still present.  The potential pushback from possibly expanding the dedicated public forum could be seen as infringing on students’ education and living standards in the nearby dorms.  However, academic buildings are far enough away so a demonstration will not seriously infringe on education and vital walkways will still be clear of obstruction. Furthermore, the East Campus zone extends right up to a dorm building with little to no objection.  Universities should adopt policies that best balance students’ and the community’s rights to speak with their purpose as a place of learning. Restricting demonstrations to a small concrete strip is a violation of students’ ability to freely express their views on campus.  Bret Fulton is a freshman political science major. You can reach him at bretfulton@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Pay Attention to Politics
author: Dawson Iasillo
body: There are many points in history where citizens followed politics blindly as they put their trust in the government. In some cases this trust wound up in genocide, a Communist country or even a pointless war.  In America, we are entitled to protest and oppose the government if we feel that things are not being run the way we want them to be. However, not paying attention to what is happening almost completely eliminates this right. Without awareness of what's going on, people cannot stand up for themselves and their country.  Paying attention to politics is crucial to be aware of decisions that affect our lives, our friends' lives and all other citizens’ lives. Staying informed empowers individuals to make educated decisions, hold leaders accountable and stand up for activism to make an equitable society.  Many forget that the horrific points in history did not just happen; there were steps taken to get to that point. The Holocaust did not just start with the execution of millions of people. It started with support from a susceptible audience. Plenty of people did not stay well informed, which ultimately led to fear mongering and control.  Adolf Hitler did not act alone. In fact, he was popular at his time. Hitler took advantage of those who chose not to get too involved in politics and catered his language and propaganda to them. We now have the knowledge to not let history repeat itself, yet many are adamant not to get into politics.  Watching from the sidelines is the same as being a bystander. Being educated in the world of current events allows individuals to trust their government to do the right things for citizens.  Some politicians should not be trusted and do not have their people’s best interests at heart. It is the democratic freedom to choose who is put into power, but with that holds the responsibility to make an educated decision.  With this, not taking the time to educate oneself ends up hurting others in the end. In the U.S. there is currently tons of oppression under President Donald Trump’s administration. Immigrants are scared, LGBTQ+ rights are on the lines and women’s access to their reproductive rights are being thrown around.  Somehow, plenty of people are still in the dark about what dangers this administration truly imposes. Politics has never been about how it affects just one person, but how it affects everyone around them. It should feel like a responsibility to become educated for the people who will continue to be left in the dark.  Many are not particularly aware of what is happening because the system may already be set up in their favor. Some are lucky and privileged enough to be able to say that the political systems in this country fit their narrative and rhetoric. Ignorance is a privilege.  In a weird way, not caring about politics almost shows a lack of empathy. Just because an individual may not be affected by policies doesn’t mean their neighbors, friends, loved ones or even total strangers won’t be.  Although something is not affecting someone yet does not mean they can’t speak out against it. If and when the political system ends up oppressing an individual who wasn’t well informed enough to speak out when it wasn’t for them, they shouldn’t be surprised when no one is there to speak out on their behalf.  Many are beginning to realize how important politics are. Plenty of Trump voters are now regretting their vote after Trump is executing what he promised to do all along. If these voters were well informed from the get-go, they would not be feeling this remorse and regret.  There is an argument to be had that it is hard in this day and age to be informed. While news media are biased and there are different narratives all over the place, a simple Google search and a fact-checking website can get any person the answer they’re looking for in a matter of minutes.  At this point, it is inexcusable to not be well aware of the things happening in our country. The power of social media and technology makes our world a whole lot smaller. There is not a lack of information, just a lack of people who search for that information.  Staying engaged in the political world acts as an advocate for everyone who is affected by politics; which is everyone. By remaining informed, we can influence policies that affect our daily lives and protect our rights. Ultimately, political awareness empowers us to be active participants in the democratic process. Change requires knowledge and there is power in knowledge.

title: OPINION: Protect the legitimacy of courts
author: Bret Fulton
body: Courts are among the most respected institutions in the American government. Today, however, the federal judiciary finds itself in a legitimacy crisis that may end up requiring major reforms. As the Trump administration and the public continue to question the authority of our judicial system, everyday Americans will pay the price.  On February 9, 2025, Vice President JD Vance made a post on X questioning the authority of courts when it comes to the executive branch’s “legitimate power.” What some consider a simple question, to others is considered an attack on the foundation that the judicial branch’s power rests on.  Even if the Trump administration were to ignore court decisions they don’t like, this won’t change the fact that those decisions are legally binding.  Decisions by federal courts remain legally binding regardless of whether or not the administration in power enforces it. Having an executive branch that ignores orders, as the Vice President suggested, is an attack on the founding principle of separation of powers. Furthermore, this sets up a dangerous precedent that future administrations of either party will continue to exercise and expand.  A history already exists of presidents ignoring court decisions. The infamous defiance of the Supreme Court by President Jackson where he stated that the Supreme Court should use its own military to enforce its decisions has been a bright stain on American history.  His refusal to enforce a Supreme Court decision respecting the Cheroke people’s right to sovereignty on their land eventually resulted in forced displacement and ethnic cleansing. Otherwise known as the trail of tears, this horrific period of American history has been labeled an attempted genocide by some scholars.  Our republican system requires that different powers are distributed among different actors, rather than being vested in a single executive. However, the excessive use of executive orders by both sides of the aisle, especially in the second Trump administration, undermines this core feature of American government. It is court decisions that make the final determination as to what law should be followed, not executive orders.    Officials in the executive branch and in congress should express their disagreement on the merits and legal groundings of court orders they don’t like, as checks and balances require it. However, that disagreement should exist within the confines of not attacking the foundational authority of the court itself and ensuring that appropriate enforcement actions are taken.  Recourse is built into the system if courts make decisions that the other two branches disagree with. In 2022, the Supreme Court limited the Environmental Protection Agency’s ability to regulate carbon as it was not considered a pollutant and congressional action was required.    Congress and the Biden administration passed a law classifying carbon as a pollutant and therefore restoring the EPA’s regulatory authority. This was a clear example of checks and balances in action. Of course, broader constitutional questions would require a constitutional amendment that is extremely difficult to accomplish.  Some may argue that the expansion of power within the executive branch and its ability to ignore court decisions is justified as it’s an elected branch of government. Furthermore, some may point to examples in history when courts made notoriously bad decisions that had long lasting, negative repercussions for generations.  However, if we allow a single person to make the final determination as to what the law is and execute it accordingly, we no longer have a republic, but a dictator. The simple fact that the president is elected doesn’t change this calculus. Courts have made terrible decisions in the past where enforcement has resulted in generational consequences. Proper recourse through other branches, or at least executing a narrow enforcement of the decision, serves more in the public’s interest than simply ignoring it.  If we want to continue living in a system where checks and balances are pushing against one another, we must empower courts and ensure that congress is actively exercising oversight on the other branches as well. If court orders continue to be ignored, the future of our republic looks grim.  Bret Fulton is a sophomore political science major. You can reach him at bretfulton@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Sabrina Carpenter isn’t too sexual, she’s powerful
author: Sydney Greenspan
body: If society still mistakes a woman’s confidence for oversexualization, then Sabrina Carpenter’s newest album, “Man’s Best Friend,” might just be the wake-up call we all need. Her music isn’t about seduction or objectification, it’s about power.  Sabrina Carpenter’s rise in pop culture is nothing new. She went from a Disney Channel actress to a pop star with a distinctive sound and image that has only continued to gain popularity.  Her latest album, “Man’s Best Friend,” has quickly shot to number one on the Billboard 200 Chart. Yet, it is being criticized for being “too sexual.”  This backlash says far more about society’s discomfort with confident, sexual women than it does about Carpenter herself. Her music calls out the double standards that still dictate who is ‘allowed’ to be sexual in the public eye.  Far from being oversexualized, “Man’s Best Friend” celebrates female empowerment while exposing the hypocrisy women continue to face.  When male artists sing about sex, no one bats an eye. Harry Styles’ “Watermelon Sugar” is famously known for being about sex and when he was asked about the meaning of it, people did not seem concerned. The Weeknd’s “Earned It,” which was featured in Fifty Shades of Grey, was celebrated with radio time and even went diamond.  However, women face a different reality.  When women sing and perform about sex, they are shamed, discredited and criticized. Madonna in the 1980s, Britney Spears in the 2000s and Beyoncé in the 2010s have all faced backlash for the same themes men are praised for.  Carpenter joins this lineage of women being punished for confidence and sexual expression, proving that society still treats female sexuality as controversial while excusing men who do the same.  What critics are overlooking is that Carpenter’s music is not about objectification, it’s about expression. With irony and humor, her lyrics flip the script on how women are usually framed in pop music.  She isn’t performing for the male gaze; she’s creating for herself and for the women who see their own strength reflected in her confidence.  Songs like “Feather,” from the album "emails i can’t send", shows her claiming control of her story and redefining what empowerment looks like. Carpenter is playful, sexual and bold on her own terms. For fans, her confidence feels like permission to take up space.  She is not the problem, society is. By celebrating femininity that is playful, powerful, sexual and self-directed, Carpenter helps shift pop culture toward a more authentic version of womanhood that refuses to shrink for patriarchal comfort. She represents a broader wave of women in pop reshaping feminism through culture, proving that self-expression doesn’t have to conform to outdated norms.  Of course, not everyone agrees.  The cover of "Man’s Best Friend" stirred up criticism online, with some calling it raunchy, excessive or even misogynistic. Yet, this outrage misses the point. Carpenter exaggerates the very things critics complain about, using humor and irony to reveal how fragile these particular values still are.  In fact, the criticism only strengthens her message: society is more uncomfortable with women owning their sexuality than with men flaunting theirs. Carpenter’s confidence, playfulness and boldness turn criticism into proof of the very power she is claiming.  Her music isn’t about being oversexualized; it’s about celebrating power. By challenging double standards, empowering women and broadening cultural representation, Carpenter proves that confidence and sexuality are not weaknesses but strengths.  Her success shows a simple truth and a sad reality: society still struggles to see a woman’s confidence as strength. Owning your power and sexuality should never be controversial, and Carpenter proves exactly how empowering that can be.  Sydney Greenspan is a junior majoring in Communication Studies with minors in Political Science and Psychology. You can reach her at sydneygreenspan@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Social media promotes hateful behavior
author: Hannah Nazarenus
body: When scrolling through social media there are often hateful comments and bullying posts. This isn't an unusual experience but rather the new norm.  Social media was created to bring people together, build bridges and create a voice for everyone. However, now the algorithms prioritize engagement which can lead to social media showing controversial or negative content because it creates more reactions. This normalizes hateful behavior and creates an echo chamber effect where toxic behavior is shown more often.  Social media algorithms are designed to prioritize content that draws attention and engagement, even if it’s negative.  Controversial content tends to get more likes, comments and shares which means it will likely end up at the top of feeds or for you pages. This allows inflammatory content to be seen by many people, conditioning viewers to see it as acceptable.  Especially when many platforms have weak guidelines against this behavior they allow it to go unchecked. While many community guidelines try to prohibit harassment and abusive behavior these rules are often not enforced or hard to prove.  With the sheer volume of hateful behavior, it is hard for platforms to keep up with the amount of reports. Frequently it takes a post being reported many times before the offensive content is addressed. This lack of accountability shows that hateful behavior is tolerated and often overlooked. When people realize that there is no punishment for their behavior it becomes even more normalized.  This lack of accountability paired with the anonymity of social media allows people to say things they wouldn’t in real life.  In face-to-face interactions, people are less likely to engage in harmful or offensive behavior. Without this in-person interaction, they lose empathy. People feel encouraged to lash out, bully and attack others without considering their impact. Being online gives users a shield to say things they wouldn't in person. The faceless interactions remove accountability and create a breeding ground for toxic behavior and words.  Some argue that social media doesn’t normalize harmful behavior but rather exposes how society really is. They may believe that social media has given a voice to marginalized communities allowing them to share their stories. While it is true that social media has helped many positive movements and can create positive change, it’s hard to deny that it can have the opposite effect. The algorithms reward engagement no matter whether it is good or bad.  Social media platforms must take accountability for the environment that they have created. To combat this hate, social media platforms need to reevaluate their algorithms and guidelines to encourage accountability for others. These steps would ensure hate is less visible on the platform and seen as less acceptable. Without these changes, the platforms designed to bring us together will continue to push us further apart.  Hannah Nazarenus is a junior journalism and ADPR double major. Reach her at hannahnazarenus@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Spending money on items you enjoy isn't a waste
author: Hannah Nazarenus
body: As college students, we have all been told at one time or another to not buy something because it's a waste of money that we should be saving. However, what if treating oneself to an item of clothing or splurging on a beloved hobby isn’t as wasteful as we have been told? Spending money on things students genuinely enjoy isn’t a waste, rather, it's an investment in their well-being and happiness.  Many college students are told to plan for the future and save the little money they have. With the cost of tuition, housing and any other large purchases for the future, we are constantly pressured to cut out any unnecessary spending. Having this mindset can overlook how valuable personal enjoyment and happiness can be to our lives. Sometimes spending money on what brings students joy can be just as important as saving for the future.  Spending money on enjoyable things can primarily help boost one’s mood and mental health.    College life can be stressful between classes, extracurriculars and jobs. Many of us are juggling a lot of responsibilities which can take a toll on our mental health. Spending money on something, whether it's a night out with friends or that new pair of shoes, can give students a much-needed mental break. While these purchases might not be seen as necessary, they help contribute to overall happiness and can improve one’s emotional well-being which is as important as anything else students spend their money on.  One of the best ways students can spend money is on experiences like concerts, trips or other events which help create memories that can last a lifetime.  These memories can bring about long-term satisfaction and happiness which makes them a valuable investment in students’ life experiences. When thinking back to some favorite memories they likely revolve around fun experiences, therefore spending money to create these moments is not wasteful, but enriching. They can help students connect with others and build relationships that can make their college years much more fulfilling.    Spending money on hobbies or passions, like art supplies, workout equipment or classes, can help students discover new talents and deepen their sense of self, all contributing positively to the future.  These aren't just frivolous expenses but, rather, investments in students’ future selves. Spending money on things students are passionate about can help cultivate their interests in ways that can open up new opportunities in the future. Purchasing things students enjoy can help them become more well-rounded and engaged in their own lives.  Some may argue that unnecessary spending could lead to financial stress later on and that it's better to focus on saving as much as possible now. While it is important to save some, it’s also necessary to find a balance between financial responsibility and spending money on enjoyment. Practicing mindful spending can be done without putting a strain on long-term savings. Moderation is key to ensuring that the money students spend aligns with both their values and happiness.  Spending money on enjoyable things isn’t a waste, it’s an investment in students’ happiness and well-being. While it’s important to be financially responsible, there’s also value in treating oneself with things that make life more pleasurable. Life is about more than just saving every penny, it’s also about creating joy with enriching items and experiences along the way. College is a time to create memories, discover passions and develop into the person students want to be. Sometimes that means spending a bit of money on things that make one genuinely happy.  Hannah Nazarenus is a junior journalism and advertising and public relations double major. Reach her at hannahnazarenus@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Spotify is scamming people
author: Jocelynn Messersmith
body: Whether I am walking to class or driving to work, I am always powered by music ringing in my ears. Spotify has always been my go-to when listening to my favorite artists or when I need simple study music to lock in for my next exam. Although I am an avid fan of the app I have found myself skipping over more and more songs with every listen.  Spotify, the king of all audio streaming services, allows its users to listen to millions of songs and podcasts from content creators all over the world. The ease of use, customization options and the fact that the app is free makes it an obvious fan favorite among college students and working professionals. Yet recently the streaming service faced backlash from the community over the app’s shuffle feature not truly being randomized.  Spotify is scamming its users by falsely advertising the shuffle feature as random, when in reality, it uses algorithms that manipulate playlists and often repeat the same songs.  Everyone listens to music in different ways on the app. Personally, I like to add hundreds of songs to my liked playlist and shuffle my list, but I’ve noticed that I get certain songs over and over while some play once in a blue moon.  At first I thought I was going crazy until I realized that this has been a problem within the community. As it turns out, Spotify weighs the scale to determine which songs to play so that the music blends together. As a result, Spotify acts as a digital DJ making us subject to jarring transitions.  While the thought is considerate, most people want a total random shuffle feature that isn’t weighed. I also believe that this scale isn’t effective as I have gone from Glimpse of Us by Joji to the Texas Song from Spongebob. These two songs have a totally different vibe yet Spotify paired them next to each other, so I question the accuracy of the Spotify shuffle button.  When users select the shuffle feature, they don’t want a curated playlist that automatically mixes the same ten songs. The issue with shuffle on a liked songs playlist is even more annoying since Spotify introduced their artificial intelligence DJ. The AI DJ is supposed to curate a playlist from liked songs and give commentary and new suggestions similar to them. With this, there is no point for the company to control playlist shuffles.  I’ve noticed this biased feature on more than my liked songs playlist. Whenever I go directly to an artist to listen to their music, I find that hitting shuffle just plays songs that I have previously listened to and added to my liked playlist. Oftentimes when I search by an artist I want to hear more of their niche songs that I haven’t discovered. However, every time I click on a specific artist I get the same songs that are already added to my playlist, meaning I have to skip over multiple hits in order to hear different music.  The Spotify community realized that this may be due to the fact that shuffle is based on the popularity of a song. This means that when I click on a famous artist such as Kendrick Lamar, I will keep getting his most popular songs or features instead of his earlier work that isn’t in the limelight as much. The community is becoming very frustrated with overplayed songs saying that they won’t go back to the app until the issue is resolved.  Since Spotify is their own company, they can do whatever they want with their app but I do find it interesting that the company hides their use of algorithms as they advertise their shuffle as “tracks play randomly”.  A main problem with this shuffle format is that users have to pay for premium in order to skip songs that are constantly repeated. Without Spotify premium users only have six skips per hour which can easily add up when most songs are from artists the user doesn’t even listen to. It feels as though Spotify purposefully triggers the community in order to get them to spend extra money on their app.  While this can be considered a good business practice, it also faces community backlash. The Spotify community is in an uproar saying the company doesn’t care about its users and that it is  just as bad as other music streaming services such as Apple Music or Pandora.  However, there is a point that Spotify doesn’t force people to pay for certain benefits in their app. Although this may be true, the company is still falsely advertising its services, especially for those who don’t pay.  Before I bought premium I remember each advertisement claimed there would be 30 minutes of uninterrupted listening when it was really two songs later that I got another advertisement. It got so bad that I would get an advertisement in the middle of my songs. Therefore, even if Spotify can’t actually force users to buy premium, they can certainly push their agenda to drive people crazy until they pay to make it end.  Spotify may still be the largest audio streaming service, but it’s important to recognize the false advertisement of the shuffle feature being random when they are clearly using algorithms that manipulate playlists. The company should listen to their fanbase and acknowledge their use of an algorithm rather than frustrate and potentially lose the users who want a truly randomized listening experience.  Jocelynn Messersmith is a freshman Journalism and Broadcasting double major. You can reach her at jocelynnmessersmith@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: The Electoral College should be abolished
author: Dawson Iasillo
body: In a country founded on the words, “We the people,” the Electoral College is anything but for the people.  The Electoral College was founded around the same time as the Constitution. While the country was working out its kinks, the Electoral College was the easiest way to make sure elections were properly done. The Electoral College has the power to certify elections. To ensure the early Americans were not voting for the wrong person right out the gate, the Electoral College was a compromise of powers between the government and the American people.  The Electoral College is divided between the states in an “all-or-nothing” type format. The number of electoral votes is dependent on the state’s population. The number of House of Representatives and Senators for each state is the total number of votes for that individual state. For instance, Texas has two senators and 38 representatives in the Texas House, so the state gets 40 votes in the U.S. Presidential Election.  In simpler terms, if the majority of the state population votes a certain way, all electoral votes go toward that candidate.  The Electoral College undermines the democratic principles that America stands on and invalidates the voice of the people.  Smaller states get much more of a say in elections than larger states because the Electoral College is not a direct population vote. Wyoming is the perfect example of this. Wyoming’s population is around 500,000 people. However, they are getting much more of a vote per person compared to a state like Texas or California. Smaller states get more representation because of each state’s guaranteed two senators.  This advocates for more conservative candidates, making it somewhat of an unjust system. The majority of these less populated, rural states, tend to vote for the Republican candidate. This leaves an uphill battle for the other candidates.  While the Electoral College is a representation of the population, it is not the popular vote. There have been very few cases where the Electoral College goes directly against the popular vote, but cases exist nonetheless, the most recent being the 2016 election. Donald Trump won the presidential ticket with 304 electoral votes. Hillary Clinton, however, took most of the country’s votes. With more than 3 million votes, Clinton was still defeated.  America is extremely reliant on serving its people and listening to them. That was the sole purpose of forming a new country from the beginning. It is nothing but hypocritical for a country that is derived from freedom to the people to go directly against what the majority voted for.  At the time the Electoral College was made, there clearly was not the technology to count votes in a timely manner. Therefore, the Electoral College made it quicker and easier to certify elections and allowed room for miscounting errors.  When America was first established, the Founding Fathers were fearful of putting the general public in complete charge. The Electoral College allowed them the ability to be able to veto the vote if they felt it was the wrong one. The Electoral College makes complete sense during the time it was formed.  However, given the modern-day technology we currently possess, it seems foolish not to take advantage and switch to using the popular vote as the primary way to elect our president. The Electoral College is nothing but outdated. A system that was formed over 200 years ago, written during a dark time in our country’s history, should be changed and modified.  There is an argument to be made that the Electoral College promotes politicians to reach the rural areas that often don’t get recognition. The battleground states and areas are often the states, counties and cities that get overlooked. Politicians are aware that battleground areas are the most powerful and influential parts of an election, therefore they spend the majority of their campaigns making appearances in these states.  With this being said, there are plenty of ways around reaching those battleground states without having the Electoral College in play. With social media, Zoom conferences and the efficiency of traveling, candidates would still easily be able to reach all of the rural areas that they need to.  It only makes sense to give fair representation to each individual and give the American citizens the opportunity for their voice to be heard. The U.S. needs to amplify what their morals are based upon and abolish the Electoral College. The Electoral College is an outdated system that does not advocate and benefit the people of America. It is long overdue to fix this system and to simply convert to the popular vote.  Dawson Iasillo is a sophomore political science and journalism major. Reach her at dawsoniasillo@dailynebraskan.com

title: OPINION: The elephant in the room: Tariffs
author: Dawson Iasillo
body: A major policy President Donald Trump preached about during his campaign trail was his effort to bring down the cost of living. He seemed outraged and astonished by the inflation and blamed the costs on Joe Biden’s presidency. Yet, Trump’s tariffs on the biggest trading countries like Canada, Mexico and China have done the exact opposite of his campaign promises.  Tariffs are the tax on imported goods from foreign countries. Contrary to popular belief that tariffs are paid by other countries, the consumers of the country that implemented the tariffs are those who pay them.  In this case, the average American citizen will be the one paying the higher prices. Trump first implemented these tariffs on Feb.12, 2025. He has since implemented further tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports that will begin March 12.  Trump’s tariffs will harm the U.S. economy and increase costs for consumers and businesses. In turn, this will disrupt global supply chains and hurt American exports. Tariffs pose a huge risk of landing the U.S. in a retaliatory tariff war.  There are without a doubt troubles when it comes to paying for groceries and products in the U.S. However, there are common misconceptions that placing tariffs on foreign countries will somehow lower the prices for consumers. In order for foreign countries to be able to afford these tariffs, the costs for consumers increase substantially.  Americans can expect to see more than a $185 increase in their annual grocery bills, over a $550 increase in big-box store purchases and significant increases in other items such as phones and computers.  Not only will tariffs affect the consumer's cost of living, but they will also affect American imports as a whole. In the event that Canada and Mexico retaliate as they proposed they would, Americans could see over 400,000 job losses.  Tariffs can be a great tool when necessary, but when the U.S. throws around tariffs like it’s nothing, trading partners will begin to recognize the unpredictability and move their trade agreements to other countries. American imports will become less valuable when few countries will trade with the U.S.  The U.S. is a major trading partner worldwide. Placing tariffs on other countries and retaliatory tariffs will lead to a global domino effect. With the amount of countries that trade with the U.S., consumers internationally will have to hike up their prices to keep up with the tariffs. This leaves the supply chain incredibly disrupted and inflation to increase at an infeasible level.  Trump claims that America can stand on its own and has all the resources domestically. Not only does the U.S. not have all of the resources domestically for what Americans need, but trade is a key component to maintaining allies internationally. Countries do not want to go to war with countries they trade with no matter how much they oppose them.  War is astronomically expensive. No country is going to want to war with a country they trade with simply because it makes it harder to get their imports. Furthermore, countries who trade with a country that is at war will help them financially so their trade deals can get back on track. Trade creates an economic motivation to maintain allies and tariffs make that relationship extremely rocky.  Tariffs may seem good on the surface but a deeper dive into tariffs shows the downsides. Trump’s proposal to bring down the cost of living for the average American citizen was nothing more than a political strategy and a way to take advantage of his voters. Tariffs will impose complete opposition to Trump’s goal of “Making America Great Again” and will only leave the American people more vulnerable than they already are.  Dawson Iasillo is a sophomore political science and journalism major. Reach her at dawsoniasillo@dailynebraskan.com

title: OPINION: The financial gender inequalities
author: Dawson Iasillo
body: Despite the recent steps forward in gender equality, the financial piece of the puzzle has yet to catch up with the times. Achieving gender equality is a long process and all boxes must be checked before we achieve gender equality. There are many aspects that have to catch up to the rest of the world when it comes to gender equality, and the financial breach is a huge part in being one step closer.  The gender pay gap is the difference in earnings between men and women. Historically, women were expected to fulfill household duties and not seen as workers. Instead, they were held to the standard to cook, clean and stay home with the children. Since women have entered the workforce, societal standards created on this gender inequality are not up to standard.  While the pay gap leaves women struggling more than men, pink tax is no help. Pink tax is a phenomenon formed in the 90s when products for females were priced higher than the same products for men.  Consumer and research advocacy originally discovered the strange increase between haircut prices. Researchers noticed that dry cuts for men were less costly than dry cuts for females. However, it was later when retail products’ pink tax was realized in stores.  The gender pay gap in the workforce is a huge issue in gender equality. Even if the work being done is on a completely even playing field, the misogyny of society seeps in regardless.  Women make approximately 82 cents of a dollar compared to men, creating a domino effect.  When women are aware they are not getting paid their worth, it discourages their talents and efforts that could be put forward for a brighter future. Women may be encouraged by society to go back to the outdated times of staying at home to do household duties.  In retail, there is a significant difference in prices for females and males. Women pay on average $1,300 more than men because of the pink tax in stores.  Prices of tampons and feminine products significantly increased in the past few years. Further than this, womens’ razors, body washes, shampoos and even pens cost more than the masculine version of those same products.  Insurance companies follow suit as they don't recognize some female health concerns. The odds are stacked against females to be able to get ahead in society financially.  Birth control is a reasonable medicine to help irregular periods, acne and pregnancy. Yet, most insurance companies do not view birth control as something that should be covered, though it can cost up to $2,400 annually.  While some may say that job differences and hours of work might play a role in the gender pay gap, it has been proven that the pay gap is still relevant. Women are clearly being put out by the financial state of the world and yet, barely anyone is taking action for this. There are plenty of opportunities for change across the board, but little measures have been taken.  Modern society needs to recognize that these financial systems are built on the foundation of gender disparities. They have to be reconstructed in a way that takes into account the financial discrimination against women and how much harder it is for them to get ahead financially.  Dawson Iasillo is a sophomore political science and journalism major. Reach her at dawsoniasillo@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: The Husker x Lululemon collaboration was a waste of time
author: Hannah Nazarenus
body: As a longtime Husker fan and an occasional Lululemon wearer, the Lululemon x Husker collaboration piqued my interest. Lululemon, one of the most popular brands among young people, partnered with one of the most passionate fan bases in the country. However, the reality of the grand opening left me feeling underwhelmed, unsure if it was worth the hype and like the drop was a complete waste of time.  One of the main issues with the Lululemon x Husker drop was its lack of creativity. For a collaboration that merged two iconic brands, the drop felt as though it was thrown together.  The collection was almost entirely standard Lululemon clothes with a hint of a Husker “N”. If fans are paying more than average for a piece of Lululemon, they expect designs that are new and innovative, something that truly represents Nebraska's spirit. Instead, they put out the same Lululemon gear you can buy in one of their stores with a subtle “N” on the corner.  While Lululemon is known as a pricier athletic brand with many willing to pay the price, a collaboration with a college team should have been more accessible for the average college student.  Some fans may have appreciated the sleek designs of the collab, but others found it hard to justify spending hundreds of dollars on clothes with just an “N” or “Husker” written on it. Husker fans want gear that shows off their school pride in a bold way, and with such a steep price tag and basic designs, Lululemon turned off many potential customers. Why spend $88 on a basic t-shirt when you can find more affordable, original Husker gear somewhere else?  On top of lacking creativity and having a high price tag, the drop was too exclusive with too little product.  Students in Greek Life were sent emails allowing them early access to shop the collaboration. Because of this, many styles and sizes were sold out for the public opening and left many fans disappointed. Lululemon should have known the collaboration would cause a buzz and ensured there would be enough product for both early entry and the grand opening shoppers.  Some may argue that this collaboration was a good thing because it puts Nebraska on the map and could create future collaborations. While it may put Nebraska on the map, that doesn’t mean that the first collaboration shouldn’t have been creative. Hopefully this collaboration opens the doorway for more creative brands to create pieces that Husker fans would actually be proud to wear.  Ultimately this collaboration was a missed opportunity from all sides. Lululemon had the chance to create unique and timeless Husker gear, but instead they created items that aren't memorable or worth the price. Instead of creating gear to celebrate the Huskers, it was an attempt to capitalize on fan and brand loyalty without offering anything of substance. If the goal of the collaboration was to merge Lululemon’s quality high-end clothing with Husker spirit, then this drop fell short. Nebraska's passionate fanbase deserves something that reflects their spirit, not a shirt with a small, generic logo.  Hannah Nazarenus is a junior journalism and ADPR major. Reach her at hannahnazarenus@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: The power of sports betting
author: Michael Tatten
body: It’s one of the world’s fastest-growing industries and it fits in your pocket. Sports betting is more accessible than ever, and it’s changing the way we watch, talk about and profit from sports.  Sports betting is rapidly transforming the gambling landscape, and it should be fully legalized across all states. Its growing popularity brings undeniable benefits–driving economic growth, increasing fan engagement, and creating a safer, more regulated environment for responsible gambling.  Now in its seventh year of regulated operations beyond Las Vegas, the U.S. sports betting industry has generated over $40 billion in total revenue from nearly $500 billion in wagers placed, showcasing just how powerful and profitable this market has become.  Surprisingly the gaming industry in the U.S. employs more people than the postal service or air travel, employing over 700,000 people. There are a wide range of jobs the industry provides, from technology and marketing, to hospitality and compliance. As sports betting continues to grow, it will create jobs across emerging technology fields like artificial intelligence, Blockchain and virtual reality, while also expanding opportunities in content creation, influencer marketing and entertainment.  Sports betting also brings in significant taxes. In just January 2025, taxes associated with sports betting were up to $350 million. New York has a massive 51% tax on sports betting, which has allowed the state to collect nearly $2 billion in just three years. If all states were to legalize sports betting, states would be able to collect a significant amount of taxes, which can help build up cities’ infrastructure and economy, while potentially lowering other taxes.  There has been a rise in engagement in sports and it is partially due to what sport betting brings to the actual games. Some people are just getting into sports because of sports betting, and in other cases, sports betting brought back the passion fans once had for these sports. 67% of NFL fans say they watch more games when gambling.    This has also led to an influx of new fans for sports. The options are endless on what fans can bet on. Anything ranging from football and basketball to UFC and boxing. Leagues, teams and organizations are all going to be more profitable due to sports betting. Sports betting brings new eyes to a lot of sports.  In 2006, President Geroge W. Bush signed the Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act (UIGEA) into law. The UIGEA essentially prevented certain online gambling sites on the U.S. market. But, there were ways around this law, such as betting on sites that operated outside of the U.S.’s jurisdiction. They would gamble their money in sites offshore, like Panama and Costa Rica, where gambling was legal.  It made sense for the original U.S. states to legalize sports gambling then, and it makes sense for the rest of the states who have not to follow suit now. The states would be able to regulate the market as they choose, while also reaping the economic benefits that sports betting provides.  However, not all that comes with sports betting is good. Gambling addictions can be caused by sports betting which can lead to mental health, financial, social and other personal problems. With the popularity of sports betting continuing to grow, a rise in gambling addictions has occurred. Gambling appeals to the younger generations, potentially causing early gambling addictions.  In order to counteract gambling addictions, the sportsbooks have opened up and supported  gambling helplines that can counteract gambling addictions. This helpline is available in all 50 states. Sportsbooks also work to make sure that the gamblers are of age and have the funds to support their betting. Though gambling addictions are a serious problem in our country, many people are working to make sports betting safe.  Sports betting should be legalized in all states because it can open up a whole new market that can help boost state’s economies, provide the spark needed for fans to be excited about sports again and create a safe, regulated environment for legal gambling.  Michael Tatten is a freshman sports media and broadcasting major. Reach him at mtatten2@huskers.unl.edu

title: OPINION: The SAVE Act is a step backward for voter rights
author: Dawson Iasillo
body: Republicans claim to be the party that supports women and marginalized groups and opposes Project 2025. Yet, their actions completely undermine that.  Marginalized communities were not kept in mind while drafting the Safeguard American Voter Eligibility (SAVE) Act.  The SAVE Act is a proposal that would require registered voters to provide both a valid driver’s license and birth certificate. The kicker is, each of these documents would have to match to a tee. The act would also require all individuals to register or update their registration in person. This would go along with severely limiting mail-in or online applications.  With the bill being passed through the House of Representatives on April 10, it is realistic to start thinking about how women will be able to vote if this law is enforced.  The act would make it nearly impossible for married women to vote. Most married women change their last names meaning that their driver's license would not match their birth certificate. This would hurt over 69 million women’s ability to vote.  This seems like a clear issue that would have been brought up while drafting this bill. However, there is nothing in the bill regarding this concern. Republicans arguing that they are a party that supports women only to go on and draft a bill that silences women is more than a contradiction. It’s undemocratic.  Voting registration in the U.S. is already extremely low. It is absolutely foolish for a democratic republic to try to further limit the amount of people who can vote. The SAVE Act would ban online registration or registering by mail. This would clearly limit the abilities of the disabled, elderly and even college students who don’t live at home.  The individuals who have every right to vote and have their voices heard should not be punished because they cannot show up in person. This is simply another law to silence Americans. But, if Americans’ voices weren’t so powerful, they would not try to silence them.  For many generations, marginalized communities have fought incredibly hard to obtain their right to vote. People have catalyzed and put themselves on the line for their children and grandchildren. The simple proposal of this bill is a horrific piece of history to be left in this country.  Let’s be abundantly clear. Voter fraud is nothing more than a myth. There is so little if any, credible evidence. Non-citizens have been banned from voting since 1924. Anyone who is afraid of voter fraud has bought into the propaganda. The goal of this bill is to ensure laws that are already in place. If it wouldn’t be so detrimental, it would be laughable.  If this bill is passed through the Senate, where will the line be drawn? Will there be literacy tests? Will there be a poll tax? We can’t keep taking steps backward that are going to silence Americans for generations to come.  As history has shown, any erosion of voting rights often falls hardest on those already facing systemic barriers. Women and those from marginalized communities are no exception. Excluding eligible voters who lack access to specific documents, face name mismatches due to marriage or divorce or live in areas with limited access to voting locations are all those who would be punished for no fault of their own. To preserve a truly representative democracy, leaders must ensure that reforms aimed at securing elections do not come at the cost of silencing the voices of millions of people. Especially those who have fought long and hard for their rightful place at the ballot box.  Dawson Iasillo is a sophomore political science and journalism major. Reach her at dawsoniasillo@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: Third-party protesting backfired in 2024
author: Bret Fulton
body: The spoiler effect, or when a third-party candidate splits the vote causing an unintended winner, has been a hallmark of American politics. In the 2024 presidential election, it’s possible we were witness to some of the ramifications of the Palestine third-party protest vote.  Protest voting’s use in the 2024 election season kicked off in the 2024 Michigan Democratic presidential primary. The “uncommitted” movement eventually won two delegates in the Democratic National Convention, signaling to the Biden Administration to change its policy on Israel.  Some activists extended this logic of protest voting into the general election in November. Activists such as Seattle City Councilmember Kshama Sawant threw support behind Green Party presidential candidate Jill Stein while making comments about Michigan being ground zero to defeat Harris.  Sawant was a vocal anti-Harris activist in her community after it became clear Harris would secure the Democratic nomination for president. While Sawant’s comments may have had minimal pull on voters in Michigan, the campaign as a whole did not, as many predominantly muslim communities across the state swung in favor of Trump.    America’s two-party duopoly has held a chokehold on American politics for decades, thus making it extremely difficult for third parties, such as the Green Party, to become real contenders for political power. Even while the Green Party holds less than 200 elected offices around the country, Stein has still run in the 2012, 2016 and 2024 presidential elections.  Many protest voters felt as though Stein stood in opposition to both Republican and Democrats’ policies on Gaza. However, her long-shot campaign's participation in the election set up a clear spoiler effect. As a result, it’s possible that Stein garnered enough votes to make Trump’s victory in states like Michigan much easier. Furthermore, the uncommitted movement’s campaign against Harris clearly had an impact in swinging enough voters to make a real difference.    Voters who support a third party must consider the impact of their vote. Casting a ballot in a tightly contested election for a candidate on the periphery such as Stein or Cornell West splits the core Democratic vote.  It’s an almost universal understanding that third parties don’t have the numbers to win presidential elections. Attempting to garner enough support behind a candidate who has ballot access in only 38 states with no pathway to victory was not a risky move. Instead, it seemed like a targeted, mismanaged approach that ended up swaying the election in favor of President Trump.  Third party, protest voters must take accountability for the role they played in spoiling election results. It's unfortunate that we find ourselves in a two-party duopoly. However, it’s plain math that any vote outside of the two major parties in the 2024 presidential election was a spoiler.  It’s important to vote for candidates you can negotiate with the most. While Stein may have been more receptive to the uncommitted movement, there wasn’t a pathway for her victory. Instead, we are in a situation today where the uncommitted movement has zero allies in the White House to influence Israel policy.  It’s vital to recognize that muslim voters, much like any other voting demographic, are not monolithic in the way they cast their ballots. The Biden Administration did not listen to voters in cities like Dearborn, Michigan, and as a result, they paid the price.  We also must accept the moral dilemma many felt while casting their ballot considering Trump and Harris’ stances on Gaza. However, it’s clear that Trump’s stated policy plan for the Israel-Gaza conflict was way more hawkish than Harris’.  There is blame to go around about the Biden Administration’s neglect to listen to muslim voices around the country since the onset of the Israel-Gaza war. However, a protest-vote campaign in the midst of the hotly contested 2024 presidential election made Trump’s more extreme stance on Palestine come to fruition.  Bret Fulton is a sophomore political science major. You can reach him at bretfulton@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: This NFL draft was wild
author: Michael Tatten
body: The 2025 NFL Draft last weekend was a wild one. This draft had one of the top prospects fall to day three, unexpected quarterbacks rise multiple rounds, crazy draft day trades and some of the most varied draft boards we have ever seen.  The draft is a three day event that took place April 24-26, 2025 at Lambeau Field, in Green Bay, Wisconsin, home of the Green Bay Packers.  This was the second highest attended draft since the NFL moved it out of New York and started sending it to various locations in 2015, amassing over 600,000 attendees.  All of these fans were in for a lot of unexpected drama as one of the top prospects coming into the draft, Shedeur Sanders, fell all the way to the fifth round of the draft. Shedeur was the quarterback for Colorado the past two years, changing the program with his father, Deion Sanders, who was the head coach for Colorado.  This came as a shock to many because Sanders was projected to be a sure-fire first round draft selection with ESPN’s draft metric giving him a 96% chance to go within the top 21 picks of the draft. Many mock drafts had Sanders going as high as number two or three overall in the draft.  The reasoning behind why Sanders fell in the draft is unknown to many NFL analysts that have ties with multiple teams. The fact that Sanders fell so far is baffling. Sanders was deemed as the most accurate quarterback in this draft by the majority of scouts.  Sanders absolutely has the talent and traits to have gone higher in the draft. The Cleveland Browns traded up to pick number 144, in the fifth round, selecting Sanders, ultimately ending his unanticipated fall in the draft.  The slide of Sanders, meant the rise of other quarterbacks in this draft. As quarterback is the most valuable position in the NFL, and there were quarterback needy teams, some unexpected prospects rose dramatically up the draft boards.  The most unexpected pick in maybe the entirety of the draft, was former Louisville quarterback, Tyler Shough. The New Orleans Saints selected Shough at pick number 40, shocking many people with this selection. Shough is an older prospect at age 25 and with multiple season-ending injuries in his career, many draft analysts didn't expect Shough to be taken this high in the draft.  A couple other quarterbacks that were surprising picks were former Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe being selected by the Seattle Seahawks, and former Oregon quarterback Dillon Gabriel being selected by the Cleveland Browns. Both are viewed as development quarterbacks with some potential.  In this draft, we also witnessed the second overall pick be traded by the Cleveland Browns to the Jacksonville Jaguars, where the Jaguars selected former Colorado star, Travis Hunter. Hunter is a phenom who is attempting to become the first NFL player to play both sides of the ball, full-time.  The Browns may have not gotten the two-way star, but they added a lot of value that can help them build up their team for the future. The Jaguars gave up a lot to get Hunter, but if Hunter turns out to become what they think he can be, the trade will be well worth it.  Many teams had players ranked very differently on their draft boards. Most years there is usually a consensus on most players, with a few outliers, but that was not the case this year.  The top five to 10 prospects were pretty much in agreement, but after that, one could have seen a team rank one player at number 10 overall on their board, and another team have that same player at number 50 on their board. This was the case for a lot of the prospects in this draft, making it an exciting draft to watch because of the variability.  On the other hand, the top five picks were somewhat known, meaning people had an idea what was going to happen, with prospects like Cam Ward, quarterback out of Miami, Abdul Carter, edge rusher out of Penn State and Travis Hunter rounding out the top three picks in the draft.  Scouts are also saying that the reason Shedeur Sanders fell was because of his father, Deion. Teams don’t want to have to deal with Deion constantly putting pressure on them to start his son. Scouts also say that many of the teams that were interested in Sanders were turned off by some potential character issues.  One anonymous NFL assistant coach said, “It was the worst formal interview I have ever been in in my life. He’s so entitled. He takes unnecessary sacks. He never plays on time. He has horrible body language. He blames teammates … but the biggest thing is, he is not that good.”  The fact that Sanders fell in this draft was baffling and those who say he is not a good quarterback are wrong. Sanders now has the opportunity to go out and prove all of his haters wrong by becoming legendary.  The 2025 NFL Draft was full of shocking moves that led to a dramatic draft. The slide of a top prospect, the unexpected rise of quarterbacks, big time trades and the varying draft boards made for a great draft and entertainment for the NFL.  Michael Tatten is a freshman sports media and communications and broadcasting double major. You can reach him at  michaeltatten@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: TikTok is the new Facebook
author: Hannah Nazarenus
body: Remember when Facebook was the center of everything happening in the world? Users shared news articles, political debates happened in the comments and viral misinformation spread like wildfire. Social media has always played a role in shaping public discourse, but Tik Tok has taken this to new heights. TikTok has become the go-to information source, often spreading misinformation for Generation z and Millenials, just like Facebook was for previous generations.  Facebook misinformation often came from clickbait media sites with sensationalized headlines. Even with this there was still an emphasis on written journalism, where users could click on an article and verify the information themselves. Videos on TikTok often skip this step entirely, giving influencers and creators access to the eyes of young users. Creators are able to create a parasocial relationship with these users, gaining more credibility in the eyes of viewers as they appear more relatable than a journalist.  Because of this, a significant portion of Gen Z and Millennials now rely on TikTok instead of historically accurate news outlets like The New York Times or the Associated Press. A 2024 study found that 39% of adults under 30 regularly get their news from TikTok.  Since TikTok doesn't have the same checks and balances as traditional journalism, it prioritizes engagement over factual reporting.  TikTok’s algorithm is designed to keep users engaged by showing content that aligns with their interests and beliefs. Unlike traditional news sites where readers can read a variety of stories from unbiased reporting, TikTok’s algorithm shows them content that they directly want to consume. This can reinforce the viewers own biases and viewpoints creating an echo chamber and leading to even more polarization between people.  TikTok’s misinformation problem is even worse than Facebook’s. Facebook faced backlash for its role in spreading misinformation. Lawmakers, journalists and the public pressured them into implementing fact checking on posts. While this feature isn't right all the time, it now works with third party face checkers in the European Union. and allows users in the United States to comment on the post’s accuracy. TikTok however does not have the same transparency, causing millions of people to consume unverified information daily, oftentimes without realizing it.  Despite its flaws, TikTok has done what Facebook never could: engaged younger audiences with news and brought attention to underrepresented issues. Independent journalists, activists and creators alike have used the platform to shed light on things mainstream media might have overlooked. It has given a voice to those who might otherwise go unheard. Even though there may be some benefits, this doesn’t outweigh the danger of unchecked information and the decline in trust of traditional sources.  While Facebook spread some misinformation, TikTok has made the spread even worse.  It has become the dominant platform where young people consume information daily. As Gen Z and Millennials continue to rely on TikTok as their primary news source, it’s more important than ever to develop media literacy skills, question the viral content and seek out reputable news sources. If this isn't taken seriously, there is a risk of living in a world where the truth is controlled by the most viral video, not by the most credible sources.  Hannah Nazarenus is a junior journalism and ADPR double major. Reach her at hannahnazarenus@dailynebraskan.com.

title: OPINION: True crime culture is warping our reality
author: Hannah Nazarenus
body: Anyone who watches true crime knows the feeling of turning off the podcast or Netflix documentary and immediately double checking the locks. Even though they aren't in any actual danger, the fear still lingers.  Over the past few years, true crime has become one of the most popular entertainment genres, especially among young women. What used to be a niche hobby has exploded into a billion-dollar industry, with podcasts, docuseries and influencer-run videos looking at real life cases. True crime content isn't just entertainment, it shapes how viewers think about safety, risk and fear, and it's not always for the better.  True crime stories often overrepresent rare, extremely violent crimes. The genre thrives on the most horrifying cases about abductions, serial killers and mysterious disappearances. The more shocking or violent a crime is, the more clicks it receives.  While statistically these types of crimes are incredibly rare, viewers who are constantly exposed to them can start to think they are more likely to happen than they actually are. Psychologists call this the availability heuristic where people make judgments on the likelihood of an event based on how easily they can recall similar instances.  When applying this to true crime, the more violent a crime is the more of a lasting impression it leaves on the viewer. This can then cause them to believe these criminal acts are more likely to occur. This is harmful for the viewers, because the more they believe danger is everywhere, the more they operate in a constant state of alert.  This change in behavior for the viewer isn't always healthy. After listening to hours of true crime podcasts it's hard not to see threats everywhere. Rachel Monroe, a true crime lover and author of Savage Appetites, believes true crime appeals to women in particular because it's almost a form of preparation. While holding car keys a little tighter at night or skipping solo walks may not seem like a big deal, when this fear starts to seep into daily life it can become paralyzing. The overconsumption of true crime doesn't make anyone safer, it just makes them more anxious.  Another issue that is often unaddressed is how true crime reinforces stereotypes, for both the victim and perpetrator. Many times these stories center on white middle class women who are seen as ideal victims. Meanwhile crimes against people of color, queer people or poorer individuals are ignored and underreported. Additionally, suspects are often framed in ways that play into harmful racial, mental health or class-based stereotypes. True crime can often paint a simplified picture subtly reinforcing existing biases that don’t reflect reality.  It’s true that some people argue true crime raises awareness, and in certain instances it does. Podcasts like Serial or The Murder Squad have looked at cold cases and drawn attention to the systematic failures in law enforcement and the investigations.  But, that's the exception. Most true crime content isn't driven by justice, it's driven by the shock value, views and revenue. When fear becomes entertainment, it stops citizens from trying to make the world safer and turns them into spectators watching behind a screen.  When used properly, true crime can bring awareness to injustice and give a voice to victims whose stories might be otherwise forgotten. More often than not it's become a form of entertainment that thrives on fear and the unknown. Everyone owes it to themselves to be informed, but they also deserve peace of mind. When viewers are constantly looking over their shoulders because of the content they consume it doesn’t make them safer, just scared.  So, the next time someone brings up the newest murder documentary or podcast, remember that awareness is a powerful tool, but only when it empowers, not when it paralyzes.

title: OPINION: Trump played voters with his part in Project 2025
author: Dawson Iassilo
body: President Donald Trump time and time again has boasted about his ignorance of Project 2025. Yet, everything he has implemented closely aligns with the more than 900 page writings of Project 2025. In fact, most of his cabinet members, down to his press secretary, have had a key role in constructing the documentation of Project 2025.  Project 2025 was constructed in 2022 by The Heritage Foundation and 140 former Trump staffers. The project strives for an extreme right-winged blueprint for the United States. The project rolls back federal agencies, federally funded corporations, several women’s rights protections, LGBTQ+ rights, immigrant rights, healthcare and racial equity to name a few highlights.  Trump has implemented more than a dozen policies that have closely aligned or flat out been written in Project 2025. Despite initial denials, Trump’s actions have followed through with Project 2025’s proposals to transform the government into his ideal conservative framework.  One of the objectives of Project 2025 was the dismantling of diversity, equity and inclusion. DEI is the federal program that advocates for fair treatment of everyone. Whether that be handicapped parking spots or flexible hours for parents, DEI is everywhere, often without being recognized.  On page 258, Project 2025 states its promise to eliminate DEI in federal workplaces and education and eventually further its boundaries. Trump announced at his inauguration that DEI would be banned shortly, and that promise was fulfilled shortly after. His most recent hand in eliminating DEI was sending a threat to public schools that continue to use DEI and will no longer be federally funded.  From pages 417-448, Project 2025 takes a deep dive into their extremism rhetoric in terms of climate change and environmental rollbacks. Trump has been widely recognized as historically the worst U.S. president for the environment. Despite his condemnation of Project 2025, the things he spews align perfectly with what Project 2025 states.  On day one, Trump pulled the U.S. out of the Paris Climate Accords, the biggest climate change alliance in the world with over 200 countries as members.  Another announcement on day one was his advancements in the “Drill Baby Drill” agenda. This would increase carbon dioxide to over 4 billion tonnes.  Recently, he is reevaluating the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and teetering back and forth with the idea of eliminating it as a whole. This is the agency that helps with relief for cities affected by natural disasters and emergency situations.  With this, he is also working to cut the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The latest rollback was the cuts of over 3,000 national park and forest service workers nationwide. This represents about 15% of this field. All of these environmental protections that were abolished are written out in one way or another in Project 2025.  Probably Trump’s most notorious action so far in his second term has been his extreme immigration measures. The way he goes about deportation is written out to a tee in Project 2025. From pages 137-151, Project 2025 goes into incredible detail about how migrants should be treated and “handled.” The document views immigrants, of any sort, to be deteriorating our country.  Trump has denied knowing anything about Project 2025 and has disassociated with any implications of it. However, his supporters, cabinet members and the proposals he is turning into law completely contradict this.  At this point, there is no denying Trump’s implications in Project 2025. The exact page numbers in Project 2025 align perfectly with what Trump is trying to accomplish. The parallels in the document and Trump’s actions are far too similar to be a coincidence  Trump’s second term initiatives reflect a comprehensive adoption of Project 2025’s framework. Trump is trying to make a transformative era in America and is using the writings in Project 2025 as a guideline.  The alignments not only fulfill these conservative objectives but also contradict the Constitution, federal agencies and executive authority. The U.S. would suffer immensely if even half of the things in Project 2025 were put into place. At the rate that these extremist laws are being passed, America should be alarmed for what is to come.

title: OPINION: Trump’s dark vision from day one
author: Bret Fulton
body: The tone for a new administration coming into power every four years is typically one filled with optimism and hope. This is symbolic of the peaceful transfer of power, and is a tradition that was broken this previous inauguration day. President Donald Trump proved in his speech to the American public and the world that he will be quick to abandon his base of supporters and basic American ideas along the way.  On Jan. 20, 2025, Trump gave his first address to the nation as president in his second administration. The speech was filled with both political and personal attacks on the previous administration, along with promises to implement policies that directly contradict American values and the Constitution.  It only took a few hours for Trump to implement an unpopular executive order ending birthright citizenship for a child whose parent or parents are in the United States unlawfully. Not only does the policy lack public support, but also lacks a legal foundation considering it is in direct violation of the Fourteenth Amendment’s citizenship clause.  It only took a couple of days before Federal Judge John Coughenour struck down the executive order. The signing of an order that is in such a clear violation of the Constitution is symbolic of what may be to come over the course of the next four years. Especially considering this was one of his first executive actions as president.  Symbolism enveloped every part of the inaugural ceremony. Technology industry CEOs such as Tim Cook, Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerburg sat just behind the first family on the inauguration platform. It is clear who his next administration will serve.
